Review:
This product was easy to assemble and install (well, if you have a child this age you are experienced in reading the cryptic instructions that all products for this age seem to come with, but at least I was able to figure this out quickly). Some reviewers here were concerned about the buckle being difficult, but I had no issues with it at all. The box did say "improved buckle" on it so maybe they saw the reviews and fixed it.

We had a Graco infant car seat that we just graduated from, and one thing to note is that the adjustment strap on this new car seat is extremely easy to adjust after being used to the infant car seat's adjustment. I really don't know that it can be easier to adjust the various straps.

Anyway, it feels very secure after being installed in my car and I have just bought a second one for our other car. Highly recommend!

Review: We've been using this car seat for about two weeks now and my very tall 14-month-old has no complaints. He loves putting his VTEC toys in the cupholder and it looks as if he is able to fall asleep quite easily on longer car rides as long as he has his pacifier and burp cloth next to his cheek. It's easy to installation. I only struggled getting the car seat into the upright back positio once I pulled it out of the box. The material is very breathable and spills on the material are wiped up quite easily. I wish Graco would consider an adaptation to the non-cupholder car seat arm. It would be much easier for someone to get their toddler out of the car seat if the arm would somehow swivel out or pull down. Since my son is so tall I often have to find a tricky way to maneuver him out of the car seat. Lifting him straight up and over the arm often results in his head brushing the roof of the car or very narrowly missing hitting the door frame. I'm sure it is not comfortable for my son to experience his left leg being brushed every time he is removed from the car seat.

Review: I checked out the Sit N Stroll and the Go Go Kidz TravelMate before deciding to try the Traveling Toddler.  The Sit N Stroll seemed really great, switched easily from car seat to stroller and would have been one less thing to travel with, but the back recline does not adjust and it was too far back for my 2 year old to use as a stroller all day.  I really liked the Traveling Toddler.  It works great.  It's a little annoying that you have to take it apart to go through security etc but it's easy enough to put back together.  I used the largest carry-on I was allowed and it worked beautifully.  My daughter loves her carseat (Britax Marathon) and was loving sitting in and being pushed around.  (Make sure your carry-on pull locks upright or you can't push it in front of you, you'll have to pull it and I found it easier to push.)  I saw someone else with the Go Go thing and it looks great but for nearly triple the price, I got this one since I don't fly often.  A must-have if you need the car seat on the plane or your destination b/c you can also check the car seat and use this strap before/after in the airport instead of carrying it.

Review:
We have been using this car seat for over a year now and it is still in great shape, it has held up well to our two young kids. The quality was great from the beginning and has seen lots of use. It installs/removes easily (relative to other car seats we have tried), it's easy to clean and remove the fabric/padding for washing (my wife's favorite part), it still fits securely in the car and shows no signs of ware (amazingly with the amount of usage it gets, roughly 7-10 driving hours/week and moving between cars periodically). The cup holder and armrests with built in pockets work well for the kids keeping everything within reach. The adjustable seat angle is just right in our Toyota Mini-Van to keep the kids upright yet still comfortable and, of course, safe. The adjustable seat back height allows it to be used for larger kids which was great when or oldest was ready to upgrade to a larger size; we are able to keep using the same seat! We bought this model when our second child was big enough to sit forward, we have the previous model of this seat as well for our younger child (that seat has been in use for about 4 years now) and that seat is also still in great shape! I expect these seat to out last our kids needs, but if we ever had to buy another car seat it would be the Graco Nautilus!

The only down side is the padding around the buckle is constantly in the way for the belt latches and I have to constantly pull it down, this was not a problem with the previous model; this is only a minor inconvenience every couple of uses and compared to the everything we like about this seat it's hardly worth mentioning.

Review: These Costco car seats are wonderfully non-bulky, but the straps are so tight and limited! We have two of the smaller versions that are supposed to go to 35lbs, which is how much my 4 yo weighs. But even with the straps on the highest setting, we can barely clip it around her chest. She is average height and size. So I ordered this larger Cosco seat assuming since itâ€™s rated to hold much larger kids, the straps would clearly be big enough. Nope. She has another 2 in 1 booster from another brand that she fits in great and we havenâ€™t even started extending the straps. We have used 6+ car seats and boosters over the years so weâ€™re not incompetent at how to use them-Cosco straps are just across the board shorter and more limited. VERY frustrating. We returned ours after both my husband and I tried to make sure we werenâ€™t missing something but we both concluded itâ€™s just a poor design.

Review: I will agree with another reviewer on this seat.  There is hardly any cushioning in this seat.  It is all harder foam and the cover has hardly any cushioning.  I choose this because I have the Diono Radian RXT(2018 model and a solid seat)which has a little more padding.  My son is 8 and has out grown the 5 point harness of the RXT(he is small for his age).  The RXT does convert to the booster, but I chose to get this booster because it looked to be more specific for the purpose, and cost is not as much of any issue for me when considering my son's safety.  This booster has the larger sidewalls for side impacts.  This is important to me because I will be moving my son from the center seat(unfortunately, because of my truck not having a shoulder belt in the center).  Looking at other brands, I don't feel like the other seats would be that different in regards to comfort or cushioning, and this one seems safer looking to me.  I like the look of the Monterey versus other seats because the sides and the head protection seems to be the largest that I have seen and it is reinforced with aluminum.  It looks like a Nascar seat.  If it's good enough for Nascar, it is good enough for my son.  I will say that I did add about a half inch of "luxury" cushioning to every part of this seat to provide more comfort and, I feel, more safety.  I cut and molded them to fit perfectly.  There was plenty of room under the cover to do this and I think it filled it out more.  The cover seemed loose without it.  I am like BASF.  I don't make the products that I buy, but I make them better, ha!  Another reviewer stated that he did not think this was a safe seat, because he said when you pick up the seat from the back part, the bottom falls off.  I will say that they could have designed this better to snap together so that doesn't happen.  The other reviewer also said that he was afraid that the back would come off in impact.  That is not possible, because of the way it goes together, and once you put it in the car and "latch" it in, the back cannot come off.  It only comes off when folded backwards to the flat position, which happens when you pick it up from the back.  Again, this could have been designed better for transitioning to another vehicle or just removing and carrying it.  Overall, I think this is as safe of a booster seat as you can get and I like the Diono products versus others in regards to design and safety features.  They could do a little more in regards to comfort and padding for additional safety, so I would not have to modify it.  A little extra padding would not cost that much to add and would definitely make this seat the best on the market, along with a locking mechanism for the back rest to the base. .....just my 3 cents.  I will have to see about the buckling and shoulder strap issues that others have expressed once I have used this more.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Material: hardly any cushioning, all harder foam, cover has hardly any cushioning, reinforced with aluminum
Installation Type: latch
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The seat provides adequate support and stability for the child. The installation process is secure and straightforward. The materials are durable and maintain their structure over time.

Review: Looooove love love this car seat! It is so cushy and sturdy. It was INSANELY easy to install! And I am seven months pregnant! It is the first seat I have not needed help from my husband to install and that is including before I got pregnant. Our son seems perfectly comfortable in it. Sinching in the LATCH system straps was ridiculously easy and fast and the seat did not budge when I tried to wiggle it around. We normally would not choose to spend so much on a seat if we don't have to. We are always on a tight budget. But we decided to go with this seat because our car is sort of compact. It's a Scion xA. And our son is a tall child at only 2.5 years old. We were not comfortable with forward facing him so soon and this seat has a great height/weight limit for rear facing especially for tall, lean children like my son and it totally fits rear facing in our little car. I needed to be able to safely sit in the front seat in front of it and I can with no problem. I also love how customizable the recline setting is on the seat! It's fabulous. And adjusting the height of the straps at the shoulders is also incredibly easy. This seat is very well made, very user friendly, very safe, and seems to be very comfortable! We plan to buy a second one for our second child due in October since we love it so much and it works for newborns as well! :)

Review:
We have an early 2013 model, and some reviewers have said there have been changes made... but the straps have some horrible flaws: A) they are not long enough... especially if your child has a jacket on... you have hardly any working room to get them tightened B) the awful shoulder pads, need I say more... read other reviews C) you cannot move the straps out of the way before putting the child in, so you will be digging underneath your child to find the straps, and in the process you will end up getting the slideable buckles reversed on the straps... this is a great joy to have to fix while your kid is squirming around let me tell you...

Review: My 13 month old and I were recently in a horrible car wreck. He's small (17 lbs) and still in this car seat rear facing. Our car was totalled. I had to t-bone a Dodge Truck due to a weather related accident entirely out of my control. I have broken bones. My son (and his car seat and base) didn't have a scratch on them!!! The only mark he has is bruising on the side of his head probably from the air bag. I truly never bought our seats for safety...the color and comfort factors mattered more. After our accident I'm just so thankful that it did the job it was supposed to and my son is alive and well thanks to this car seat!!!

Review:
I purchased this seat as a backup for my husbands car. I wanted something comfortable and safe, but I didn't want to spend a ton since my daughter only rides in his car a few times a year. This seat is okay. It seems sturdy and my husband was able to install it easily into his civic coupe. This seats works great as a backup, but I wouldn't want it as my main seat as the padding is pretty thin and does not seem very soft or comfortable. Also the straps constantly get tangled and my daughter gets super impatient while we try to untangle them with her in the seat. If you can remember to untangle after you get your child out or if you have a more patient child, then this may not be an issue for you. Overall, I would recommend this seat if you need a backup like us or if you are looking for a sturdy budget friendly carseat.

Review:
At first I thought this is a good seat. Now that my baby is 5 months I wish I would have chosen a different carrier/seat. The two big cons for me are that the canopy is too short and lets too much sun in and that my baby has a soaking wet back every time I take him out of the seat. This is very unfortunate and I assume that the fabric is cheap. The carrier is fairly heavy and doesn't quiet fit all that well with the stroller base I chose.

If I had to do it all over again, I would probably choose a convertible seat right away and go with a Maxi-Cosi. If I would choose an infant carrier seat again I would also go with a different brand that doesn't get so hot. The baby sits in it very deep and it seems to be uncomfortable. Wish I had known this before.

Review:
I'm singing the ClickTight praises now. We have this seat and the Boulevard G4. I bought the ClickTight for my car, as it is our primary vehicle. We got the cheaper G4 for my husband's vehicle. At first, I was regretting my ClickTight purchase. This sucker is HEAVY. I also felt that it was difficult to uninstall (tip on that later). That said, it offers more cushion and side protection than the G4, so I stuck with it.

Fast forward to a recent trip with a rental car...I wished that I had the ClickTight functionality with me. We brought the G4, as it is lighter. While it was nice not breaking our backs through the airport, I broke my back and more trying to install the dadgum thing in the rental car. Even the LATCH anchors were a pain to click into the sedan (Toyota Corolla). Then, I decided to move the seat to the middle and install with a seat belt. It took 45 minutes, multiple crying jags, and several terse words thrown at my husband before I got an unsatisfactory install. The ClickTight would have taken all of 3 minutes (yes, I've timed it now).

Pros:
-Incredibly easy install
-Comfy ride for kiddo
-Will last my kid for years
-Super safe

Cons:
-HEAVY
-Can be hard to remove (made MUCH easier by putting a knee into the seat before twisting the ClickTight knob)

If you want the ultimate in protection and ease of install, this puppy is for you. If you plan on toting it through the airport regularly or from cab to cab, think again. The heft isn't worth it. If you need a seat that can be popped into Grandma's/the babysitter's/your SO's car with ease, it's a no brainer. Get it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: ClickTight, LATCH, seat belt
Weight Range of Child: Will last my kid for years
Material: more cushion and side protection
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be easy to install using multiple secure methods like ClickTight, LATCH, or the vehicle's seat belt. It should accommodate a growing child for many years. It should provide a comfortable and protective ride with ample cushioning and enhanced side protection.

Review:
After much research and reading of reviews, I purchased this carseat when my son was about to outgrow his infant seat. Boy did i make the right choice!! The easy adjusting nobs on the sides that tighten the harness straps are SUPER!! SO many people have commented on how neat and easy and QUICK it is to tighten down the straps to a perfect fit. Plus, it's almost as easy to loosen the straps when taking out your child. One thing i was pleasantly suprised about was the amount of padding/cushion. Other brands like Cosco, have very hard seat bottoms...not this one! It's a close second to Saftey 1st seats i've found. The cover comes off easily for washing, the headrest easily adjusts and does help a bit in keeping my sons head from flopping all over. You can easily slide the harness straps up with a simple tug as your child grows.
A person can look and look and still not find the "perfect" car seat, but I think this one is close. I call it our deluxe, BMW car seat :) Very pleased and i think you will be also.

Maxi Cosi is high end European brand trying to make presence on the US market. Iâ€™ve seen some of their other products but this car seat, Pria 3 in 1 tops it all off. Firstly this car seat is a TANK. Itâ€™s sturdy, itâ€™s strong, itâ€™s protective. So how do they do it? Infant to 10 years old? Itâ€™s a lot of padding. Itâ€™s customizable as other convertible seats weâ€™ve seen, you remove the infant inserts to convert to toddler but adjustable head rest is whatâ€™s making it suitable for big kids. Itâ€™s quite brilliant actually. The seat itself doesnâ€™t go through any adjustments so itâ€™s still solid seat body that will protect the child in case of impact. Padding is DENSE, itâ€™s not just soft cushion, itâ€™s really dense and firm. Itâ€™s easy to install but itâ€™s big, I wouldnâ€™t recommend for the small car. My 2year old is very comfy in this seat which just replaced our Britax Boulevard. Where we live is hot and humid and my boy doesnâ€™t get got, we do use moderate AC in the vehicle.
I couldnâ€™t be happier with this seat.

Review: This is the 2nd Extend2Fit Iâ€™ve purchased for my son, and the only car seat I will ever purchase ever again! I didnâ€™t necessarily need a new car seat, but weâ€™ve had our original one for 2 years now so I felt it was time to order a new one. The first one we had, had a light grey color and it stained easily so instead of wanting to risk damaging it/making it less effective while cleaning it, I just bought a new one. Figured it was best to do that anyways. Iâ€™ve bought both of them on amazon prime days to save money, and I donâ€™t regret spending a single penny. I would buy this again even if not on sale! I trust these to keep my son safe (still rear-facing at 3 years old), and he doesnâ€™t seem to complain about the comfort level. Coming from a crazy car-seat mom, I recommend these for parents who are interested in rear-facing their child for the max amount of time. I love that they can remain rear-facing at such a higher weight and that this seat also comes with a pull out foot rest to make it even more comfortable! Itâ€™s easy to install, and especially easy to adjust the strapsâ€™ length! 10/10 would recommend for safety, comfort, appearance, weight and size. I do drive an SUV so I have the extra room in my backseat (it is a tiny bit bulky) but I know it wouldâ€™ve fit in my Toyota Camry I had pre-child just fine!

Review:
My daughter is almost 17 months old and we've been using our Chicco Keyfit 30 since she was born. It's been a really great seat. The carrier is a little heavier than some of the other brands out there but the padding on the seat is good and makes you feel like there's more surrounding your little one in case of an accident.
One con for us was when she was still too small to ride in the BOB jogging stroller without the carseat adapter, the adapter doesn't work with the Chicco. It does work with the Graco so we bought the cheapest one we could find (Snugride) and wow, what a difference in quality... not to say the Snugride is awful because I really don't know but I do know that the Chicco felt much more substantial and I wouldn't feel as comfortable using the Graco in the car on a regular basis.
Anyways, installation was very easy with the LATCH system and it fit in the middle backseat of my '08 Toyota Corolla perfectly without having to push the front seats forward excessively. I recommended this seat to my friend whose wife recently had a baby and they love it as well.

It is important that it be raised and lowered as the child departs/enters the vehicle so as not to break it (don't let them stand on it!). The tabs that are used to unlock the foot platform are a bit difficult to use. It would be easier if there was just one pull tab at the front of the footrest.
We would buy this again as we couldn't find anything as good in the marketplace but think its design could be improved. Might also be useful indoors with child booster seats at the dining table but we haven't tried it there yet.

Review: I really like this carseat, I really feel like my baby is safe in it, I only give it four stars because I haven't seen it perform in a crash...and I plan to keep it that way.  Once I get my baby in the seat she seems to be comfortable, but she hates being strapped into a carseat, we tried 4 different seats before deciding on this one because we were looking for one that she liked...we gave up on that and just got the one that I liked since it seemed she wasn't going to like any of them.  I love the print and it goes great with my cars tan interior.  I agree with other reviewers about the clicksafe feature being pretty useless, I just ignore the click and tighten it as I would any other carseat.  It installed easily into my vw minivan though it had to be behind the passenger seat because it is big (as were the other 4 that we tried out) and my husband can't put the seat back as far as it needs to be for him to drive if we had the carseat on the drivers side.  Dispite a few minor annoyances I think this is a great seat and would highly recommend it.

Review: So I have been wanting this car seat for a few weeks now and finally I purchased it during prime day! I love this car seat! My l.o is 2 weeks from being 1 years old weighs 29ish pounds and 30ish something inches. He was due for an upgrade from the infant seat. As you can see before the Graco SnugRide fit perfect in the center. But the Graco Extend2Fit did not, well it would if the seats were scooted all the way up. The car I have is a 2010 Kia Soul! I found no other reviews about it fitting or not so I had to find out. It fits on the outside seat with the passenger seat scooted forward some. Luckily my husband and I have been looking at bigger vehicles, because I will not be able to use  the extend feature in my current vehicle! And that was the sole purpose of buying it to keep him facing rear longer! I was able to get it to recline to the 2nd notch! No messing with adjusting straps, they move up with the height adjustment! The crotch strap can be accessed by reclining seat on the last position and unhooking it through the hole under the seat. Pretty easy after I read the manual! Thatâ€™s all I looked at it for. The material is padded very well. The cup holders were hard to snap in. Bottles we use are Playtex VentAire and there is still plenty of side room for a little bigger bottle or cup. I would not recommend this if you drive a 2010 Kia Soul! And the Solar color is bright orange! I love it

Review:
First of all - This seat is a tank, and I recommend it 100%. I can't imagine that my child would be safer in any other seat.

Pros - Appears to be very safe and made of high quality materials.

Cons - The pads on the straps are horrible (more on this later). Also, the harness is quite difficult to tighten down on the child. Not a problem for myself, but my wife struggled (it didn't stop us from ordering a 2nd seat for her vehicle).

About the pads - Chicco claims that all seats made after October 2013 have new, removable pads. Conveniently enough, this seat as made in September of 2013. Be aware that even if you're ordering this seat well into 2014, you may get a 1st generation model. Nothing is wrong with this seat, but you may find yourself in the same group of those that absolutely hate the shoulder pads. Rather than "recall" the 1st gen pads, Chicco has made it possible to buy another set at $5 + S&H (thanks Chicco...)

UPDATE: If you receive a seat with the old "non-removable" pads, give Chicco a call (or send an email), and they will send you replacement pads.

With the new pads installed, the straps are much easier to adjust. We still love this seat :)

Review:
I was lucky enough to score this seat in the cyber Monday hidden deal, and since I am a CPST, I wanted one as a backup as well as for education. My 4 month old is currently using this seat installed with the seat belt in the middle of our "13 Ford Explorer.
Pros:
*Ease of installation. It wasn't the easiest I've ever done, and I made the mistake of expecting to be able to reach in through the belt path. You can't, instead you pull back the cover and reach in that way. But overall, I'd say this is a pretty easy installation. The recline adjustment is awesome. Follow the manual!
*It's a nicely compact seat that is also long-lasting, which is a fantastic combination.
*I love how organized it is designed and the very clear instructions and stickers on the seat. Chicco did a great job wording the manual and clearly marking the seat. I also love the little compartments for storage on the seat.
* Kudos of Chicco for listening to their customers and allowing the strap covers to be optional (go to their website for more information)

Cons:
*It's a big seat. While it is nicely compact front to back, it is still quite heavy and bulky. Loading a child in and out can be a challenge and it's more of a bucket-shaped seat, which some kids may not like. It is also moderately wide at the widest parts of the sides, so puzzling with other seats may be a challenge if you are lacking in space.
*The harness tends to be very hard to tighten. I'm not sure if that will improve once the strap covers are removed. The pads also get in the way of being able to do the pinch test, and practically choke my son once I finally wrestle the chest clip high enough (have almost hit him in the face several times trying to pull/push the clip up!).
*The adjustable headrest can be frustrating to use. It's clunky and takes some finesse to figure out how to press the stiff button and raise the headrest and then find the locked position.

Overall, this seat is worth some of the day to day annoyances, and I'm sure with extended use, things loosen up and it becomes easier to do the necessary adjustments. But for me personally, this will be our #2 seat, behind the Radian RXT. There's just no contest when it comes to getting the baby in the seat and buckled and adjusted with ease.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 4 month old
Installation Type: seat belt
Harness Type: harness tends to be very hard to tighten, chest clip
Material: strap covers, pads
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

My point is, it takes some time to get use to (i've had it for 3 wks), but for the price, its definitely a good deal... compared to the 300 chicco next fit i originally wanted and I'm sure would have been super easy to use... then i  came to my senses and thought it was ridiculous to spend that much on a car seat!

Review:
I love the seat but...when I first got this I initially wanted to return it because it was $20 more than I had seen in a store but when I considered the headache to return it and buy a new one I realized I'd be spending more than $20. My toddler is now 21 months and I love the features--- lots of padding, easily removable, very easy to pop off the fabric to wash and all that good stuff.

But, the base of the seat it not as wide as the actual seat making it easy to topple over when it's in the reclined position, my son loves to sleep in it but after an hour he usually comes out dripping wet in his back, the chest clasps slips up and down easily so he has managed to slip in and out of the seat restraints which is a major concern for me especially since he does it during traffic.

It's not plane practical if you are travelling alone cause the seat weigh 18 pounds without a baby. It's very bulky to fit in a seat both lenght wise and width wise.

Ohhhh and another major thing --forget the advertising for newborn to toddler. I would not put my newborn in this, I suggest you buy a 5-22 or 5-30 pound seat for your newborn because my son is still in the smallest setting and he was 17 months when he got it at about 27 pounds and there was still space. I'm not confident this seat will be safe for a baby that can't balance it's own head.

This seat is compact, the straps are smooth. If fits nice in our more compact car and it looks comfortable. Good cup holder and side pockets for toys and such. My only complaint is that it doesn't recline well, which hasn't stopped my 14 mo daughter from sleeping. But her head does fall forward which seems to be a common complaint with just about all car seats so I think this may be hard to avoid.

Review:

I really researched Combi, and I am happy that I made this purchase. The infant seat and base are great. The harness can be adjusted very easily, and I can tell my baby is quite snug and secure while we are traveling. Only reason I give four stars instead of five is because when in the base, the seat can jiggle a little too much for my liking. I'm not sure if this is common among all bases and seats (other brands), but I would like it to really lock into place and not be able to jiggle. Also, the base cannot angle the seat enough such that the bubble level is centered where it should be for a baby under 22 lbs. There is a line for 22 lbs and under, and I have to place a pillow under half of the base to get the leveling correct.

Purchase and Shipping from Amazon was very nice, as always.

Review:
When it comes to my 3 daughters, safety is the most important factor in choosing a car seat for them. For that reason, I own 4 Britax carseats and been very happy with their products. When I needed to shop for a booster seat with 5 point harness for my 2 1/2 year old, I was all set to buy another Britax Frontier SICT. Then I saw how popular the Graco Nautilus 3 in 1 was and what a great rating that Consumer Reports gave them. When I saw that it was literally $100 less, I placed the order. I'm disappoined. At first I was excited by a few of the features, but the practicality or lack there of takes the precedence in my mind.

The latch system on this seat is far inferior to the Britax technology. It was much harder to situate the seat properly in my van. And the tighening is only on the right side of the seat and very awkward. I couldn't get a good angle to tighten the seat. I much prefer when the latch on the right and left are independent of each other. It is much easier to tighten them that way.

The crotch strap came with a really nice cover, which I thought was great at first to save little legs from being pinched. But, then when it either came off or covered the buckle ever singe time I needed to put my daughter in the carseat, it was annoying, so I took it off. Now, the crotch strap falls through the pad on the bottom of the seat every time I put my daughter in/out. So we have to dig it out from below the pad and feed it back through the hole. ANNOYING! I keep hearing my husband and I saying "Augh! This carseat!"

The straps and buckles feel cheap...especially the chest clip. It is hard to get them to click because they are so flimsy.

Finally I've seen my sweet little girl fall asleep a few times now in this seat and everytime, her little head is dangling down because the seat doesn't tilt back far enough to help her head stay in between the rests. She looks SO uncomfortable. While the Britax wasn't perfect, I wish I had spent the extra money and gotten that seat instead. Buyer's remorse. :-(
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: latch system, much harder to situate the seat properly, tighening is only on the right side of the seat, latch on the right and left are independent of each other
Harness Type: 5 point harness, crotch strap, straps and buckles, chest clip
Material: straps and buckles feel cheap, flimsy
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat is easy to situate properly during installation.
The car seat allows for tightening from both sides.
The latch connectors on the right and left work together as a single system.
The harness, straps, and buckles feel durable and high-quality.
The car seat has a secure 5-point harness with a crotch strap and chest clip.

Review: This is a fantastic car seat. The material feels great, not cheap like other seats. Definitely worth the price. However, the seat itself is very heavy and I had an issue with neck support! I stopped being able to lift my newborn in it at about 4 weeks. So if you are on the tinier side, not terribly strong, or recovering from a c section, you will not be able lift it yourself. Suppose that could be a deal breaker for some so I wanted to point it out. In addition and more importantly, my little one's neck looked terribly squished in it as the pads that hold their body and head have a large gap in between. I fixed this by placing a small washcloth in that gap so his head wasn't squished forward into his chest. So not the best on neck support...but an easy fix if your creative. I still would reccomend it for the quality and impact safety ratings.

Review:
I have used this strap on multiple trips overall rather easy to clip together, even considering the security obstacles, and problems with carry-on limitations on small planes. However, if they check your carry-on through to baggage claim because of a lack of storage space on the aircraft you will be carrying the carseat and loose toddler around the airport--yikes.

Here are my other downsides:

(1) It puts significant wear and tear on your baggage, especially if you try to push, rather than pull the bag. Baggage is not designed for this use. One of our baggage handles died this way. To be fair, it was already a pretty beaten up bag, but it is a consideration.

(2) Black is the worst possible color for this. It is easily lost among other toddler junk, and then you find yourself far from home with a carseat and toddler. We have had several near misses. Our strap is now covered with bright electrical tape.

In spite of the downsides, this is the best alternative. Checking a carseat is dangerous, and rental car carseats are not better. Plus, we like having the carseat on the plane, as [[ASIN:B0012E4FV8 CARES Child Aviation Restraint System]] does not restrain our toddler as well or provide as much comfort.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: carseat
Installation Type: strap, clip together
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat can be installed using straps and clips.

Review: My 6 month old son and I were in an awful car accident this week. We were hit while driving 45 mph and ended up crashing into a telephone pole. My SUV is toast, but my son is perfectly fine. Other than the initial crying due to the shock of the impact and the noise, you would never know that anything had happened to him. He was certainly less rattled than I was, and was smiling and cooing at the paramedics when the ambulance arrived to pick us up. The one (minor) complaint that I have is that the shoulder straps are close enough together that they were irritating my son's neck occasionally - the fix for this is easy though, just velcro some fabric around it and then it doesn't rub. Review:
As soon as my daughter was able to, she started complaining that the seat was uncomfortable. Taking off the bottom cover, it was obvious why: the piece of foam on the seat is 2-3" too short! It slides to the back, and the child's legs end up resting on the hard, sharp plastic edge in the front. The result is a whiny, unhappy kid in the car on trips longer than, say, 20 minutes - and you won't know why until the kid becomes old enough to understand and communicate it.

I ended up spending an extra $20 online to buy a replacement piece of foam and cutting it to shape myself.

Review:
When our son became too tall for his infant seat (the Chicco keyfit 30) we agonized over which convertible seat to get. I wasn't overly concerned with pricing but really wanted to get the seat that was the safest for him. It's such an overwhelming decision compared with the infant seat, which was a piece of cake. So many options.

Consumer Reports gave this one the highest marks for safety so we went with it. I can now see however why it didn't score highest marks for ease of use. Once you know what you're doing, it's easy enough to install (although I haven't yet tried it in the back of a taxi while the driver taps his foot waiting for me to finish). We put it in the center position of my 2013 Subaru Outback because that's the safest position although it means using the seatbelt rather than the LATCH system. I can't wait until it's standard to have LATCH in all three rear seats of most vehicles.

The biggest annoyance with this seat is the strap tightening/loosening mechanisms. They're just poorly thought out and make it a frustrating process to get your kid properly buckled into the seat. I also wish there was a way to hold the straps to the side of the seat so that my toddler doesn't sit in on them every single time he gets in it, and I then have to dig them out from underneath him to buckle.

Size wise, it seems to be middle of the range. Sure it's heavy, but not so heavy that I can't lift it. It's also not the widest I've seen although I know there are a couple of others specifically designed to be narrow (the Radians I believe). My son is 17 mths, about 22lbs and 31" and he has a decent amount of leg room rear facing.

We're now looking for a second seat for my partner's car and we won't get the same one. I want one that's easier to use, and that comes with a built in belt lockoff in case we're in taxis etc that do not have auto lock seat belts (I don't want to mess around with a belt clip). I also want one that's more conducive to air travel.

Installation Type: seatbelt, LATCH
Harness Type: strap tightening/loosening mechanisms, straps
Weight Range of Child: 22lbs
Seat Type: Rear facing

Review: This is a great carseat. Just looking at it and touching it, you can tell that it is a higher quality than other brands. When installed with a level base, there is enough leg room for an average 18 month old to sit rear facing. A two year old or larger child will probably be a little squished but this is true with all convertible car seats I've seen. It fits in the center seat of my Acura which is not a car seat friendly car. I had to use a rolled up towel as a bolster since the seats are not level but it wasn't too bad. The floor tether has a convenient adapter piece to make tethering easier. I love the fact that you can change the height of the straps without rethreading. The pads around the straps at the shoulders are a little bulky but necessary. The straps can scratch my daughter's neck without the pads.  We haven't turned it front facing yet but I believe it will fit even better that way. All in all, I'm glad we spent the extra money for Britax. You can't put a price on safety and piece of mind!

Review: It's OK, it does the job just fine, but it's not great for extended use. The bottom buckle near the groin does not have the ability to adjust outwards, and you can't make that buckle strap longer. So while you can adjust the straps near the shoulders as your kid grows taller, you cannot adjust the bottom buckle as your child grows wider. My 4 year old is super skinny and still requires a 5 point harness since he only weighs 33 pounds, but because he's so tall, he complains about the buckle hurting his groin every time I buckle him into the car. I'm actually going to buy a different car seat because of this, even though my son won't grow out of the weight limit for this seat for a long time. It's a shame, I was really looking forward to not having to buy him another car seat again, but here we are.

Review:
Car: 2008 Mazdaspeed3

First off: I'm a die hard Britax fan. Our stroller, infant carrier, etc. are all from Britax. I didn't hesitate to buy the Marathon G4 for my wife's Mazda CX-7 while I continued using the infant carrier in my car.

When the time came to buy a car seat for my car, I test fit the Marathon in the back seat. It's tight back there to begin with so I didn't think it would fit but it did-barely. The front passenger's seat in my car would be useless with the Marathon installed. The Marathon is taller and doesn't seem to tilt as much as I wanted so that the seat was adjusted properly and an adult would fit in the front passenger's seat. I'm not a fan of using pool noodles or rolled up towels so I decided to keep looking. After reading hundreds of reviews, I narrowed it down between the NextFit and Maxi-Cosi Pria 70.

I decided to buy the NextFit based on comments about the height, adjustability and ease of use. The Pria 70 had quite a few comments about how wide the seat was and that it didn't fit small spaces as well as expected.

Pros:
*Easy to install-takes 1/2 the time to install the NextFit vs. the Britax seat
*Easy to adjust-required no pool noodles/rolled up towels in both cars Level indicator is in a great place for seat installation
*Fits in my tiny back seat perfectly and an adult can still sit in the passenger's seat up front (not the case with the Britax seat)
*Doesn't obstruct my view out the rear passenger's side window when merging in traffic
*My son can see very well out of the back and side windows (keeps him from getting bored)
*Seated position is comfortable and doesn't 'crunch up' his legs like many rear-facing seats. It's more of a lounging position. Easier on the neck when he falls asleep.
*No mistaking that it's locked in place or latched properly.
*Red release button is easy to use (Marathon often requires two hands to release)
*MUCH easier to clean than the Britax without taking it completely apart

Cons:
*Stickers were not applied properly so there are a lot of wrinkles
*There are a lot of stickers on it

I'm seriously considering selling the Britax seat (less than 6 months old) and buying another NextFit since we'll be using it for a while.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear-facing
Installation Type: Easy to install, Level indicator for seat installation, No mistaking that it's locked in place or latched properly, Red release button is easy to use
Material: MUCH easier to clean
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The seat is easy to install with a clear indicator to ensure proper leveling. It provides a clear, unmistakable confirmation that it is securely locked and latched. The release mechanism is simple and easy to operate. The materials used are very easy to clean.

Review: We registered for two of these seats when our first baby was born. We had a Graco Stylus stroller/car seat combo set but because we had a huge baby she was into the Britax by 4 months old. We have one Britax Roundabout for each car. We love this seat. The cover does pop off the side on one of our seats, but not the other. It really doesn't bother me. We bought an Eddie Bauer for my mom's car which is not as soft and does not latch in as safely as the Britax and is much bulkier. I recommended the Roundabout to my best friend who just had twins and she bought two and also loves it. The Roundabout is RF until 40 lbs which is great. Now at 20 months old and 30 lbs, our girl still sits RF which is the safest position in a collision. We will be purchasing two more for her little sister who will be here in October (one for each car). My husband can switch the seat out in under ten minutes now that he's familiar with the seat and it's incredibly sturdy.

Review:
This booster was great for our son! Heâ€™s almost 4 and is almost at 44 inches tall and he found this to be very comfortable. We bought it in May and I was hesitant about it because I realized after opening it that it only used the seatbelt to secure him, not a five point harness. He fit the size parameters though and so we ended up keeping it and using it in my van. Earlier this month (July), we were on a road trip and drove 22 hours to get to our destination. He was comfortable the whole ride. I gave him a little travel neck pillow and he stayed upright and the belt fell perfectly in place on his shoulder. He never tried to unbuckle the seatbelt and seemed very happy in his booster.

The day after we got there, someone rear ended us. It was a hard enough hit to cause damage and whiplash (for me) but my son was fine in this booster! Not so much as a bruise or red mark from the seatbelt! Graco states you must replace it once in any accident so we went ahead and got another one just like it (only in a different color as this one wasnâ€™t available in the local store). Our insurance reimbursed us for it. We used the new one to drive all the way back home and again, he loved it and handled it well. As he outgrows his other seat in my husbandâ€™s truck, weâ€™ll replace it with another one of these for sure! Thank you Graco for keeping our most beloved little person safe!

Someone did mention that there is a sticker right smack dab in the middle of the seat - on the child's back and that it gets hot in the summer. That's right we live in Phoenix, AZ and we leave ice packs covering the plastic and metal parts of the straps while we run errands etc during the summer, and I just have a small washcloth I will cover that sticker with to avoid burning my children. Yes, the straps are hard to adjust at first until you wear them in. No big deal. I think car seats are like that.

Great seat otherwise. I researched so many seats and this one finally made me feel comfortable.

his is by far the must rugged, durable and flexible child's car seat that I have owned. Compared to most other seats, this one is built like a tank. That has both positives and negatives though. On the downside, this seat is not very light or simple to move and transport. If you are going to be transferring your child from the car to the house without getting them out of their seat, this is probably not the easiest one to do it with. It's really better used to keep in the car all the time.

On the other hand, it's solid construction makes this the ultimate car seat when it comes to safety and does not sacrifice comfort or any other features along the way. Pretty much every option for positions is available, the upholstery is easy to clean in the wash and it is made to last up to 10 years with the integrated booster seat.

This seat is definitely a little bit pricier than other models, but seeing as it should last until your child reaches 120 lbs. it is an excellent investment.

Review:
We were on a trip and suddenly the straps refused to release on our Boulevard car seat. So I rushed to Babies R Us to get a new one to find that they were sold out of all but the Advocate, so I bought it.
A couple of cons that annoy me regularly:

1. The release for the straps is very tight. It almost seems like it hasn't released and you have to tug at it. Not as smooth and easy as the Boulevard.
2. The cost.
3. The size. It's huge! This doesn't matter much in my minivan, but we travel a lot and it would be terrible on the plane. It's also heavy.

So if you're wondering why I bought another, here's why:

1. They redesigned the Boulevard and basically it's now the Pavillion. One of the things they eliminated on the new model was the click safe. It's silly, but I love that feature.
2. Amazon had an awesome sale.
3. I wash the covers when needed and I did not want to have 3 different seats to buy covers for. I couldn't return the seat we'd needed on the trip for the Pavillion and I needed a seat for my second son in my husband's car, so when this went on sale, I bought it.

In the end I still wish the store we ran to had the Pavillion, but oh well.

Review:
This car seat is great. So far, no accidents and I hope we never have to say "this saved my baby", but the shear size of the thing leads me to believe it would protect quite well. Unfortunately, that is it's biggest downside as well. I did however get it to install properly, rear facing in a Toyota Camry. While not a small car, it's not an SUV either.
The seat also has some "could be hidden better" sharp hard plastic underneath the adjustable head rest. It's not a likely spot for hands to go while in the seat, but it's easy enough to find when out of the seat. I don't think it will cut even an infant's skin, but if for any reason the head rest was adjusted while a hand was in there, I'm sure there would be screaming involved...
My only other concern is that the cup holder is not well secured to the seat, it just seems like it would be easy to break off or tip over, but who rates a car by its cup holders?

That's it for the negative, now for more positive. The head rest is easy to adjust and has plenty of positions to make this useful for a number of years. However, it is quite useful on a daily basis when dealing with jackets of varying thickness. One handed adjustment leads to a perfect fit each time.

The head rest itself is very soft and wraps around a very large portion of the head for safety and comfort.

The straps and buckles are pretty standard, but they work. Although, they could use strap cushions, we just added our own.

It's not the best seat out there, but it is a good compromise between the super cheap ones, and the super expensive ones.

Review: THIS PRODUCT IS JUNK!!! I cannot stress this enough! This car seat's unique and main idea is that it holds the seatbelt down instead of lifting the child up like what a booster seat does. This idea allowed them to make a compact seat that easily travels. But what happens when the part called the QuickClip that HOLDS the seatbelt down snaps in half? You have a piece of JUNK! I do not understand why the founder, designer, engineer, and Q&A thought it was a good idea to use a flimsy, brittle piece of plastic for their patented QuickClip, which this car seat design revolves around. We unsnap the Quickclip and it snapped...in half at it's thinnest point. Needless to say the Mifold is going straight to the garbage can.

Review:
I read some of the reviews and thought this deserved one.

I bought these for my two boys because I needed something that was not too bulky for my European car and that can easily be stowed away if I had adult passengers. Also, the obvious, easy to travel with and move from car to car.

Main issues that I read were:
- Seat-belt positioner on each side (red ear thingies), locking and folding mechanism: I agree that it is somewhat of an annoyance that you often need to pull the latch on the bottom to readjust their width. They would have been perfect if you also needed to use the latch to retract them, but it is something I learned to accept. Extra 5 seconds is not a big deal in my opinion.

- Seat-belt positioner on each side (red ear thingies), inner hook: This is to prevent the belt from sliding out. I admit that it takes some practice to get used to handling these (my wife still cant), but I like that it is this way because the kids also cant play around with it and unbuckle themselves at will. I don't mind this feature at all. You can get used to it. (I just wonder sometimes if rescue people would find it difficult to unlatch in the case of an accident (God forbid), but yet again, they'll probably cut the belts.)

- Behind the back belt hook: Can be tricky and a little uncomfortable if they were not at the required level. But once set, they stay and are not a problem.

- Sliding off the seat: I only found this issue when trying it with kids that are under the required height. People might find this an issue because with regular boosters, this wont happen even with a shorter/smaller/younger kid.

All-in-all, I love this product and looking forward to traveling with it.

Review:
We've been using this booster for a couple of months now. It was easy to travel with, and install, and our kid hasn't complained about discomfort. Over-all it was worth the money and does its job pretty well. I'm mostly satisfied.

I have only two complaints about it, and they are minor.

There is a strap included that is used to tension the seatbelt and hold it in the right position. It is easy to use, but slightly annoying for two reasons. First, the buckle that attaches it to the seat belt slips a bit over time, you you have to readjust it occasionally. Second, if you want to travel, there is no good mechanism to retract this strap into the body of the booster. There is a place for the buckle to attach for transport, but to use it you have to carefully slide the strap into a slot a bit at a time. It's not a show stopper, but it is annoying and time consuming.

I'm including these complaints not so much to dissuade customers from buying the booster, but to encourage Chico to improve their product.

Review: My son loves this car seat. He would cry when in his pumpkin seat, but in this seat he only cries for a moment when putting him in there (this is just because he does not like being strapped down). He falls asleep within a few minutes in this seat and sometimes before we even make it out of the parking lot. He smiles and laughs in this seat and will play with some toys when he is awake. This seat was a little difficult to install just because it's difficult to get it tight enough. Once getting in the car and placing my weight in the seat while tightening things up, I was able to get it tight enough. A pool noodle was needed for under the front of the carseat to level it, which I had planned ahead for. My advice would be to just go ahead and plan on using it and putting it under the seat even if it looks level when getting ready to install. I thought it was level but once I tightened the seat I had to loosen it up and place the pool noodle under the seat and re-tighten the seat, as it was illegal after being tightened without the pool noodle. This is a great car seat especially for the price and we are very satisfied with this purchase and you even recommended it to a friend at church for her granddaughter.

Review:
This car seat has so many excellent features, but the 2 difficulties I had are so significant, they were deal-breakers for me and I have to return.

Pros:
Rear faces to 50 lbs
Lightweight and compact compared to so many simply GIGANTIC convertible car seats on the market
Steel reinforced frame
Easy to install, adjust recline, and adjust harness up and down with child's height
Upgraded latch connectors
2 built-in cup holders
Aesthetically, the Spire color is very tasteful. The fabric seems very easy care and not to "plushy" where it would get too hot in warmer months.

Cons:
Like other reviewers, I found it extremely difficult to get the harness to fit tight enough to pass the pinch test. I had the harness height adjusted below my child's shoulders, as instructed for rear-facing installation, and no matter how hard I pulled, I could not get the harness nearly tight enough to pass the pinch test. It was a hard stop preventing further tightening. So I figured I must not have the harness height adjusted properly. I (easily) adjusted the harness height further down, well down below her shoulders. This helped significantly, and I was able to get the harness much tighter by pulling down on the straps behind the seat while simultaneously pulling HARD on the harness tightening strap. But it was still not tight enough to pass the pinch test. Adjusting the harness height even further down below her shoulders would have made the height of the car seat too low for the the top of her head to be adequately protected. Having to wrestle with the seat to get the harness to just barely approach being tight enough is a both a safety concern and a chore for me. My child is very long and lean, and perhaps a seat where the seat height and harness height adjust simultaneously just won't fit her well.

Also, the lever to release/loosen the harness is located deep inside the seat under the fabric and very difficult to access when installed rear facing. I can see how this might be an advantage as far as food not collecting in this area. However, I found it so much more difficult, compared to her infant car seat (Chicco Key Fit 35), to loosen the harness to get her out of the seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear faces
Weight Range of Child: 50 lbs
Installation Type: Easy to install, latch connectors
Harness Type: adjust harness up and down, harness height adjusted, harness tightening strap, lever to release/loosen the harness
Material: fabric seems very easy care
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should be easy to install using latch connectors. It should accommodate a child up to 50 lbs in a rear-facing position. The harness should be easy to adjust up and down, with a strap for tightening and a lever for quick release and loosening. The fabric should be easy to care for.

Review: This seat is terrible. I received it as a baby shower gift, and began using it when my daughter turned 1 year. After only 12 months of use, the buckles stopped loosening. The red lever that must be pushed forward to loosen the straps became impossible to turn. I called Evenflo Customer Service, and they told me to try cleaning the seat, which I did to no avail. When I called again and told them it still wasn't working, they told me the piece couldn't be replaced, and I would need to buy a new seat. After only 12 months of use with no accidents or anything that would cause it to break, the seat stopped working and became unsafe, and Evenflo offered me no help since the product was purchased more than a year ago. Review: This is the third different booster seat we've used, and it's definitely the best. First of all, it's the first one to actually have latch. (finally!) It also comes apart very easily. All the other boosters have been a struggle to take apart and reassemble. This one is a snap - just lean the top all the way back and slide it out. The kids haven't complained about it feeling any different, and it comes with all the same features you'd expect from a good booster like side impact protection. It's got a built in cupholder and a little slide out tray (which will probably end up being filled with stale cheerios in about a week). The tray and cupholder are much easier for the child to reach than the alternatives in the body of the car, so that's nice if you want it. Overall a great booster.

Review: This is the 8th car seat I have had in the past six years and I am planning on it being the last! I always have a hard time getting the seat tight enough with the LATCH system and this seat ELIMINATES that problem! It is so easy to install with the regular seat belt and does not move once the seat is clicked into place. The anti rebound bar (ARB) is a cool feature too. It's purpose is to prevent the rear facing seat from slamming back into the seat during an accident. There are several other safety checks and balances included in this seat. For instance, Britax has basically created an "anti lock" strap that helps absorb the impact in a crash so that baby or big kid does not absorb it. The seat is sleek. I like the black and gray. It is heavy but not as heavy as others that we have owned. Finally, my 14 month old seems to like it too!

I purchased this Graco seat as I needed a spare one for use in my mothers' truck and got tired of taking mine out for her to use. This one was on a lightening deal for $99 plus a mail in rebate of $25 AND I had a $50 Amazon gift card so I really couldn't beat getting it for only ~$30 (once you add taxes). That being said, if I hadn't gotten it at such a deal, it would have been returned right away. My daughter much prefers sitting more upright and this has her laying back too much (she is rear-facing). It is also extremely difficult to tighten/loosen the seat belt straps (which has to be done EVERY time you put baby in/out of the seat)!!! In my opinion, it's not worth the hassle.
I'll be getting her a different car seat as soon as possible.

I really like the force-multiplying latch install, this is the first time I've ever installed a car seat without breaking a nail/doing yoga in the backseat/swearing like a sailor.

The other seat I have for comparison is the Graco MyRide 65 and I like this seat WAY better. It's heavier, but less bulky. MyRide didn't fit rear-facing. The NextFit's padding is cushier and I like the fact that the cupholder comes off so I can clean it.

I am unclear on what difference (if any) there is between the new 70 CS and the old model. I'll leave other reviewers to comment on that. Overall, I'm very pleased with this car seat. The slot was too small to allow for the metal bracket and strap to fit through.  MAJOR hassle.  Then, we decided we had to return it, and we couldn't take off the headrest!  Once it's on, it's on.  I'm giving this 2 stars because the return was simple (other than having to modify the box to fit the the car seat with the headrest attached. Review:
When my wife and I were shopping for car seats this past Spring (2007), our approach was to find the best rear-facing infant car seat regardless of price (high or low). We live in Atlanta where public transportation is almost never a realistic or safe option and thus everyone has to drive everywhere (especially on the weekends!). So we knew we needed a quality car seat that could stand up to daily use.

In our search, we looked at all of the major brands. Nothing really impressed us until we found the Combi Connection. The quality is really unmistakable--a solid handle, amazingly soft Eggshock foam (I don't think the new Connections have the Eggshock foam, which, if true, is a huge misjudgment on Combi's part), EPS foam, a quality pad cover made from expensive cloth, and a fantastic canopy. The Connection was also very easy to install using the LATCH system. The Combi Connection stroller is also great--we use it everyday and have been very happy with it. Some have criticized the Connection for not having notches to place the seat in the top half of a shopping cart. This is actually a safety feature--the American Academy of Pediatrics and Consumer Reports both recommend that parents not attach infant car seats to shopping carts in this manner.

When I start shopping for my son's convertible car seat, I will again not let price be a consideration (high or low). I now know that a car seat is all about installation. No matter how nice it is, if it is difficult to install properly, your child is not safe. Right now, I'm focused on the Britax Marathon and the Graco Comfortsport.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear-facing infant car seat, convertible car seat
Installation Type: LATCH system
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat should be suitable for infants and convertible for older children.  
The car seat should be easy to install using the LATCH system.

Review: We have only been using this seat for a month so I realize our review may change as we use it longer. I love this seat! It can be tricky to get it to go rear facing but once you figure out the straps it is super easy to install. You really can't change the recline in the rear facing position but you shouldn't need to. It is a bigger seat so if you have a small car it may be a tight fit (it fits fine in our Malibu and Accord when we had it). The knob to loosen the strap is a bit tough to use in the rear facing position with the leather seats. However, I have figured out how to turn it just right and it isn't a big deal. It is super comfy for our son. It is very nice that the strap height slides up and down to adjust. The knob to tighten is easy and makes it easy to get the baby in there secure. Despite a couple of annoyances, I really like this seat and would recommend it.

Review:
We own different brand of high end car seats but this is my first time to lay my hands on the Diono carseat.

When the box was delivered I thought it was toddler bed because it was a lot heavier than I would expect from the car seat. Our other car seats are noticeably lighter. This is great in terms of safety but if you need to switch the vehicles quite often you will get frustrated rather quickly. I didnâ€™t find installation complicated, itâ€™s about the same as the other seats but because of the weight it was harder and kinda felt like exercise.

Everything about this car seat is premium, from fabric to buckle. It converts from infant carseat to booster and this easily done by adjusting
1. Recline
2. Backrest
3.Shoulder Straps

Cushion is DENSE, comfortable but more importantly it feels as it can absorb some serious impact. I like to test my seats by tossing them against the concrete on my terrace, if it canâ€™t take some abuse itâ€™s not suitable for my child. Yes I did it. There was no clanking at all, just one loud thud.

Suitable for kids from 4lbs newborn to 120lbs. How do they do it? Cushion, lots of it. Infant insert is beautiful and well packed and dense. Newborns can practically lay flat which is ideal and this is accomplished by a wedge behind the baby back. As the child is growing the seat offers 12 different headrest positions so the head will always remain protected.

Itâ€™s the tank yet itâ€™s slightly slimmer (on the sides).

Mom tip: If you choose this seat for a newborn baby you will still need a way to put newborn in the stroller. Usually infant carrier cerseat is the way to go because you can take it from the vehicle and snap it in the stroller. You canâ€™t do that with this carseat but if you get a stroller that converts into basinet you will not need infant carrier. That way when you take the baby out of this seat you can lay him/her flat in the stroller. Regular strollers donâ€™t recline completely flat and are too spacious for newborn. Thankfully these convertible basinet strollers are the â€œthingâ€ nowadays and pretty much every brand offers a variety of it.

This way you can truly use one carseat until the child is 120lbs.

I do recommend this seat.

Review: This car seat is one of the best Iâ€™ve ever used (currently on baby #3) Donâ€™t let the great price make you nervous-the quality is great and I like it just as much as the $600 Britax seat/travel system our baby is graduating from. It is very comparable to the Maxi-Cosy Pria line of convertible car seats but half the price. I installed the seat rear-facing by myself in our SUV in less than 10 minutes. I thought it was so easy that I watched several YouTube videos to make sure I did it correctly. If you tighten the latch strap before you latch it in to the seat anchor, the car seat does not wobble or move around anymore. I have not noticed any problems at all with the straps or harness being difficult or sticking. Our baby LOVES it and actually wants to sit in it whereas he hates his former car seat (the Britax.) Oyr daughter passed away shortly after having this baby boy and my husband and I are raising him so we feel even more compelled than we typically did with our kids to give him only the best of everything.  We actually almost didnâ€™t even buy it because the price was so low but Iâ€™m glad we did. After all the research I did I am satisfied with the safety of the seat as well as comfort. It beats the Graco  4 in 1 in design, comfort & price & itâ€™s every bit as good as the high end seats. Get it! You wonâ€™t regret it! (No one paid me to say this. I just love this seat that much!)

Review: I bought this carseat after strong recommendations from a lot of people.  My 5yo daughter is at the highest point the headrest can go with the harness.  I can't imagine she'll get more than a few months out of the seat as a 5pt harness.  If I had known that I would have chosen a different booster since I want her in a 5pt harness as long as possible.  She also has a hard time buckling the bottom buckle by herself which was not a problem with her last seat.  I now have 2 kids to buckle into their seats instead of 1 which is not a huge deal, but was a nice luxury with her last seat.  It's a decent seat, but I would only recommend this seat to someone if they had a lower price range.  There are much better seats out there.

Review:
I have three at three and under to fit in a third row of my van. I bought a Diono for my three year old and was not happy with how difficult it was to install so that it doesn't move around. I cannot install the Diono rear facing so that it wouldn't budge, and so I bought two of these for my 18 month old twins who've outgrown their baby carseats.
Installation was easy and the level guage is very helpful. My kids seem comfy in these, and they just fit three across with one in the middle row middle seat of the Honda Odyssey. I was a little irritated that there is a width requirement for Latch clips and mine seem to just barely be wide enough in that middle seat. The cupholder is a nice feature because you can either open or close them. My kids are too little to care now, but I'm sure they will appreciate later on.

I got these on Prime Day sale and that was the icing on the cake for me.

I took off one star because the harness buckle is kind of weird to undo, it's hard to describe but the buckle isn't standard from other carseats I've had and I have to work harder to unclip it.

So to spend $20 more on a seat that I can continue to use the harness up to 50lbs AND it will convert to a high back booster - this is a win!

Review: The Evenflo Go Time LX Booster has a great price point. But after assembling it and using it for a few weeks, it's not what I expected. I will start with what I disliked. Upon assembling it, I had a hard time connecting the back piece. It does use extra force, but a bit more then I expected. The cloth cover is great quality, but I was not happy with how it was connected to the seat. The directions explained there were 2 top hooks to connect to, and there was not on my seat. I looked everywhere and had my husband check to see if I was missing something and there were no hooks. There was a little nub but the straps wouldn't stay on. I did find 2 hooks tucked in another spot but had to really stretch the cloth and it almost tore. So I made it work, but it's not correct. I could also use a tool to pull the strap through the other side of the car seat to try and keep it on, but it was so difficult and not an easy hook like every other one. It's almost as if the hooks were placed incorrectly on my seat. The seat is also kinda flimsy. When my son leaned over to fasten his seat belt it easily would tip to the side. So it did not seem sturdy on the leather seat. My favorite feature was how the seatbelt ran through the back of the booster seat. The seatbelt stayed in place and didn't come out. Which was really nice! It was easy for my 5 year old to reach the seatbelt and buckle it himself. The seatbelt is pretty tight in there so you have to pull a little harder to buckle up. The head rest was also very easy to adjust which was nice. Over all, the Evenflo Go Time LX booster is a great price point, but I'd rather pay more money to get something that was more sturdy and an easier set up. Usually I am all for saving money to set up a product, but the cloth seat issue was too frustrating to deal with

Review:
I bought this to replace my kid's car seat because despite being so petite, she is old enough now that i thought it would be a little strange(and even a little embarrassing) to keep her in a car seat. I was also hoping that it would be easier for her to buckle herself in compares to the multi point car seat straps. We were using a safety first air headrest car seat that has a weight rating up to 60 lbs and my daughter is only 36 lbs.

I ordered this because i like the idea of the head guard in the event of a side impact collision and the seatbelt over the shoulder guides built in to help keep the seat belt from slipping into a bad/ dangerous position.

Upon receiving this booster a few things jumped out at me immediately.
first i noticed how lightweight this booster is. Lightweight is good, but i was put off by it because the second thing i notice was how flimsy the back of this seat seemed to me. The construction and design seems like it would break pretty easy if mishandled outside the vehicle.
I notice some people didn't like the amount of padding on the seat, but it doesnt seem to be any less padded than the carseats we've owned.

A sure-fire plus for me is the narrow width of the seat. With two safety first car seats int he back of my car, we were barely able to fit 5th passengers in our car between them. Replacing one of the car-seats with this booster should make that last passenger a lot more comfortable as now there is about 4 or 5 extra inches for them to sit.

Most importantly for me though, i am unhappy how my daughter is no longer able to buckle herself. This is partially a short coming of my vehicle as the buckles are inset into the seat instead of the flopping out kind. it makes it very difficult (impossible in our situation) for a relatively young kid in a booster to reach under and around to the buckle. I have to get out of the car buckle my daughter in now when i pick her up in a busy line of parents getting their kids., which makes all the other parent s behind me in line, have to wait on me. With a car seat, my daughter had no problem buckling her harness, so now it feels like we have taken a step back in safety and convenience.

I think i am going to look into a seat belt extender to held with the buckle situation, and see if that helps.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Weight Range of Child: weight rating up to 60 lbs
Installation Type: seat belt
Harness Type: multi point car seat straps, harness
Material: padding
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should be a booster seat that accommodates children up to 60 pounds. It should be installed using the vehicle's seat belt and feature a multi-point harness system with comfortable padding.

Review: This is a great car seat.  I have a narrow back seat and it let me fit 3 across, two of this seat and a rear facing infant seat.  It is super easy to install when using the upper anchor and a lap belt, we couldn't use the lower tethers since we needed three across.  The best thing of all to my mind is that the liner comes out really simply once the car seat is out of the car, it's also washable, and the strap that goes from the shoulder to the crotch is all one piece that the buckles thread onto so you can remove the whole thing, put the buckles in the dishwasher and the belt and cover in the washer and get it all clean.  The buckle that comes up from the crotch doesn't come out but it doesn't have the crevices that the other pieces do so it wipes down easily.  If you need a skinny car seat or have a travel sick kid this seat is a must!

Review:
We own two of these seats. One we purchased in December 2010, and the second we purchased on December 2011 (we have two kids, one year apart). The first one we absolutely loved and still love. The seat is great, sturdy, easily adjustable, heavy enough, and our son quit screaming in the car ever since he's been facing forward. If you have light-colored seats, just a note of warning, with kids things get dirty very quickly, and these seats don't help (I end up cleaning the seats after we take them out, as they get dirty really fast, but I'm sure this is the case for every car seat).

The second one we received in 2011... well, let's just start with my main complaint: locking that sucker in, it's as difficult as installing and reinstalling the seat, or performing brain surgery. The front button with the red in the middle: it was previously a push down mechanism and it locked well, and if pressed well, then it'll unlock - a system that works seemlessly and was easy on your fingers. On the newer version, it's not a push down, but you have to press the button (a much smaller button than the old one), which not only breaks your nails, but requires some muscle.

The design is different and not quite as good as the old one. Moreover, you bring the two belts together and clip them, then you insert the little handles into the center red button and let me tell you... on the newer design, that task is nearly impossible. To lock your child, especially a wiggly one, is a task that takes us at least 10 minutes each time. It just doesn't lock, and it only does when you're stubborn enough to spend the time and patience to lock it. The clips and handles and all of that good stuff is at least 40% smaller on the newer model than it was on the older one. There's a front cover at the croch area, and in the old one it stays in place, it's thick and comfortable. On the newer version, it's smaller, thinner, and what's more, it falls off every time - we removed it permanently. The cover kept covering the locking mechanism making it astronomically harder to lock the belts, than it already is without it.

When you want a car seat for a toddler, you need something that locks easily and fast (I'm good with unlocking being difficult). On the newer seats, unlocking it is easy, but locking your child into the seat is so hard and time consuming it makes me wonder... how many people would give it up. I know that I'm less open to making stops, so that I won't have to take him in and out of his seat - it's just so painful.

The seat itself is great, but if the company would replace those straps and locks for something more functional, it would be a great improvement. The only reason it actually got the 3 stars instead of 1, is because we still love the first seat we bought, we just hate the newer one.

On the newer version, it's smaller, thinner, and what's more, it falls off every time - we removed it permanently. The cover kept covering the locking mechanism
