Review:
If I could return it I would but the box got wet. Since transitioning to this seat we hate going anywhere because our son can not tolerate this carseat. On top of the crying baby that now cries nonstop, It is very hard to tighten and loosen the straps. I'm not a wimp but getting any movement when you pull the strap to tighten the baby's shoulder traps is almost impossible. I pretty much only travel with my husband now because I don't feel confident in being able to this seat on my own it is that difficult.. Loosening the straps is just as bad. Apparently this is the case with the seats with the feature that clicks so you know it is tight enough. I worry about getting him out quickly in an emergency. With the other seat it wouldn't have been a problem. As it stands, after owning this for around a month I still have the same difficulty using it. It has not gotten any easier.

The fact of the matter is we went from having a content 7 month old who was happy in his infant carseat (Chicco kefit 30) and actually enjoyed car rides despite it being too small and cutting into his shoulders at the highest setting, to a 7 month old that cries the entire time he is in the seat unless someone sits in the back and distracts him with food. I never get to sit in the front when we travel any more and I won't go any place with the baby on my own because the difficulty of use and the crying. We took the shoulder pads off and that helped some so he isn't crying like he is in pain constantly and we reclined it as far as it goes and that also improved it as far as it goes. Traveling has been a nightmare with this seat. We even tried swapping back to the other seat and he was fine for traveling in that, he is just too big for it so it is not safe.

I will be saving up to buy a different seat. I just feel I wasted my money on this. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND IT TO ANYONE even if it is on sale. I got this for $190 on a lightening deal. I suspect it was a deal because of these issues.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: very hard to tighten and loosen the straps; getting any movement when you pull the strap to tighten the baby's shoulder traps is almost impossible; Loosening the straps is just as bad; the feature that clicks so you know it is tight enough
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The harness straps need to be easy to tighten and loosen. It is acceptable if pulling the strap to tighten the shoulder straps provides little movement. It is acceptable if loosening the straps is similarly difficult. The harness needs to provide a clear click to confirm it is tight enough.

Review:
Iâ€™ve been using Graco car seats for 15+ years. This was a change for me. Iâ€™ve read that century is owned by Graco so technically this may still be a Graco seat but there are some significant differences between this seat and the Graco Contender.

Installation: century drive on does not have. Leveling ball like Graco seats do. It has a line you want to get parallel to the ground. Other than that installation is about the same as a Graco seat. Neither easier nor harder.

Comfort: baby seems very comfortable in this seat. It took me some work and texting a CPST to get the best fit for this baby, she needs the infant inset in and the crotch strap in the outer position to get the best fit. Once I got that right everything is great.

Cupholders: Graco contenter has one, this seat has two and they must both be installed. I noticed some reviews state that they are removable. If they are installed correctly they do not come off. Make sure you twist down and hear the click.

Dimensions: this seat has a lower profile that the Graco contender, which is one of the reasons I chose this seat. It is easier to lift baby in and out of this seat because the sides donâ€™t come up as high and the whole seat sits a little lower too.

Headrest adjusting: works about the same. Itâ€™s easier for me to do one handed on the century drive on.

Harness length adjusting: this is easy to reach and use rear facing with the century drive on. This is an improvement from the Graco seat which has it placed so that itâ€™s buried against the vehicle seat back.

Chest clip: the century drive on chest clip is tougher to open than gracoâ€™s. I am able to unfasten Gracoâ€™s one handed. For the century drive on I need to use both hands. It will likely get a little easier as I get used to it. Iâ€™m not sure this is a bad thing. If your toddler is forever undoing their chest clip, this might be the seat for you.

Overall I am very happy with this seat. Itâ€™s quality is definitely comparable to Graco Contender. I love the colors.

Harness Type: Crotch strap, chest clip, harness length adjusting

Thickly padded and will fit a long time. For reference my 6yo son is in it and he's in the 99th percentile for height. I like that the cupholders can be tucked away. I like that the latch clips have a spot to attach to when not in use. That's good design.
A little wider than I hoped at the base and around the shoulders(I expect that's so it still fits later).
The seat fits too close to our Diono Radian 3R in our Kids Sedona 8 seat van and buckling is difficult. The radian has gotten unbuckled by accident twice in the less than a week that we've had them when trying to buckle the Cambria.
I wish we could reconfigure but they are in the best configuration for our specific needs otherwise.
6yo says "I don't like it...I LOVE IT! I more than love it!"

Review:
I would absolutely rank this seat higher than I did, except for one big problem: the buckle.

The set itself is well constructed, it's a good looking seat (as far as car seats go) it's not too big to leave room for other kids in the back seat, but it has one glaring flaw: the BUCKLE.

The buckle is really difficult to unsnap, some might say impossible. Neither of the kids' grandmothers can depress the button well enough to unsnap the straps. If you have caregivers who will be using this seat with arthritis, forget it, get a different seat. I can barely get the buckle to work it's so tough. If you're putting your kid in and out of this seat many times a day, having to deal with that buckle is a dealbreaker. I wish I'd know that this was a problem so I could weigh the pros with that huge functional con. You can read other reviews that state the same thing: Some kids are getting stuck in their seats because the buckle will not budge, and this appears to be a problem the company is AWARE of, but is not fixing.

Also, the straps that go around the child's legs leave very little room once buckled in the seat. The buckle is way too far back on the seat, meaning it digs into your kid's crotch. I have a skinny kid, but if your little one has juicy thighs, the straps might be way too tight to be comfortable.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: buckle is really difficult to unsnap, buckle will not budge
Material: straps that go around the child's legs leave very little room, straps might be way too tight
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The harness buckle is easy to unsnap.  
The harness straps around the child's legs provide adequate room and are not too tight.

Review: We were gifted this infant seat for our daughter, after researching tons this is the one I registered for. This is my 4th baby, so Iâ€™ve used my fair share of car seats and I knew I liked graco & urbini. I decided the graco bc I really wanted the ease of the snuglock, but that is literally the only easy thing about this car seat. I wasnâ€™t very impressed from the time Iâ€™d opened it because instead of the soft material everyone else described mine felt scratchy, cushioned enough, but not soft. The strap pads didnâ€™t fit well on my baby at all, thankfully this seat allows for use without those so we tossed them. The one hand adjust is not just a smooth adjustment from positions 1-4, you have to stop at each position and restart from there. In order to adjust the straps you have to press a button thatâ€™s usually right under the cover, Iâ€™m not one of the people who whines about having the adjust button on the inside, but this one is ridiculous. Itâ€™s so far down, and itâ€™s not even with the hole in the cover, so you can barely get your finger in it & since itâ€™s far down you have to thread the strap through on the inside with one finger in the tiny slot because if you donâ€™t it just bunches up at it when you push it through. My baby isnâ€™t comfortable in it either, which is a problem Iâ€™ve never had with any of my kids. And the most annoying thing, it sticks in the base. Iâ€™m 5â€™1 & I drive a Toyota Sienna, every single time I try to lift this seat of the base, the front end gets stuck and I have to maneuver it and yank it around to try to get it out all while squeezing the back release handle. Good thing sheâ€™s too uncomfortable to sleep in it otherwise Iâ€™d be waking her up. My 6â€™3 husband has less of this issue, so maybe itâ€™s just a height thing, but nevertheless annoying. Material also gets super hot, my babe sweats like crazy in it. Totally wish I wouldâ€™ve went with urbini or maybe even a simpler model graco. I gave it 2 stars bc it is lightweight, and the snuglock is a great feature.

Review: While I'm satisfied with the construction and materials, this thing is a nightmare to install, maneuver, and wash. The belt slot is wide enough for maybe a puppet's arm, but if you have normal human hands expect a painful squeeze and scrapped up hands and arms just to get the buckle through. Even my teenage sister has trouble getting through with her bird arms - it's ridiculous! The strap system is difficult to get correctly adjusted. And the cover is a nightmare to get on and off!!! We switched from a Maxi Cosi infant seat that had a cover that popped off without even having to take the seat out of the car. This one not only requires you to remove the seat but to completely undo the straps, flip the seat upside down, and otherwise screw with it. So freaking unnecessary! And I can now look forward to an hour of reassembly, readjusting screwy straps, and scrapped up hands getting it back in the car. 3 stars because it fulfills it's basic purpose, but it's senselessly difficult and annoying.

Review: To be honest, I was hesitant to purchase this because of the price.  I figured every car seat meets basic federal crash standards, so why buy this one when I could get one for $50?  However, we've now had this car seat for several months and I'm so glad we spent the extra money.  First, the steel bar reinforcement is great - it does make the seat heavier overall, but to me that is a good thing.  The seat sits more securely due to it's extra weight and I don't worry about the car seat possibly getting damaged since it's not completely molded plastic.  Also, the little touches are so nice - the straps do not need to be re-threaded every time my son grows.  It is a minor thing, but as any parent who's had to re-thread a stroller, a car seat, and every other darn thing, you know how nice it is to just not have to bother.  The adjustment of the straps takes literally less than 10 seconds.  The LATCH system attachment buckles are also a breeze.  Usually I let the baby's dad handle switching the seat from car to car, but once we had this one, it was such a breeze to do it myself.  Again, a minor thing, but it makes life so much easier.  Given that our son will be in this seat for at least another 18 months, those little things make the extra cost totally worth it!
Attribute_Related_Content:

Review:
Wanted to buy the Elite Nautilus for the feature of having the seatbelt lock attached to the car seat rather than the metal clip that the regular Nautilus has (why on earth do they not make the regular Nautilus w/ the updated seatbelt lock?!). We owned the Nautilus before & loved it (and updated b/c we were involved in a car wreck and the insurance company was paying for us to get new ones...yeah!). If you've ever used that awful metal clip seatbelt lock you know what a huge pain it is and takes forever to install it correctly & safely.
I've owned this car seat (& the other one that they call "Vice" in color) for several months now and we like it. The only difference between it and the regular Nautilus is the seatbelt lock & the head piece can be adjusted on this one (a feature I haven't used yet).
The only downside I've come across is that my son (3YO and average height & weight) complains sometimes that it hurts his peepee. I think it's because at those times that he complains his butt is scooted forward and he just needs to scoot it back. Wish they had a better crotch strap adjust but in the end I would still recommend.

It never seemed very comfy and it was $300. Not to mention the latch system clips are a pain in the butt to get to clip and the car seat is SO HEAVY and bulky.. So when it came time to get him a second car seat for his dad's vehicle I got on Amazon (initially to get another 4ever because of the fact that it grows with him and I never had any other brand to compare it to). But while browsing I saw a comparison between this one (the safety 1st) and the Graco 4 ever. After a little research and looking at the price difference, the decision was easy. Ordered this one and it came within 2 days like it said. Not to mention, it was 100% ready to go. Instillation was so much easier, the seat itself is big and safe but not too heavy or bulky, and my son seems to like it better. He's 16 months old today and still rear facing and he has plenty of room to kick back and enjoy the ride. Thanks safety 1st for your awesome product! And thank you Amazon!

Review:
We got this car seat for my grandson, who at 10 months old, was larger than the average 2-year-old. We knew he needs to be rear-facing for another 14 months or longer, but most car seats will not accomodate such a large child (34" and 31#).

This GRACO car seat has room to spare! It has wonderful cushioning. The removable cup-holders are very handy on a long trip. And adjusting the straps upward for this growing boy is a breeze! Not to mention, the foot tray is WONDERFUL, the baby isn't squashed uncomfortably into a little basket-y looking seat any more.

If you have a big/tall baby, or you want a seat that will really work for multiple ages and sizes, this carseat is a great deal. We checked, and my daughter (5' and 105# -- yes that tiny girl is the baby's mother!) does in fact fit in the booster seat. So we guess it will fit my giant Grandson for at least another 6 years LOL!

Review:
I can't believe that I almost bought that $80 contraption from One Step Ahead. This was awesome. After reading the bad review about the woman who had the horrible experience, I was nervous. I was traveling alone with my 10-month old for the first time and had the jitters. I had to practice at home first and think the whole scenario through; Going through security was my biggest fear. Turns out, it wasn't bad at all, and mind you, I was at ATL, the busiest airport in the world.

Key points:

-I know they tell you to not let your child stay in the seat when you detach the strap...(in a whisper voice) they're just covering themselves. DO NOT remove your child unless there is someone to hold them. Mine would have crawled away immediately. All you have to do is keep one hand on the seat just in case it tips(mine didn't budge, but just in case) while you unhook the strap.

-Once I had it tightened to my liking, it took one hand to unhook the top and one side. Then I just tucked the whole thing, with one side still hooked(there are 3 rings) into my carseat.

-In a nutshell, security went like this: Unhooked TT from carseat(4 seconds), took liquids out of carry-on(2 seconds) Unbuckled backpack diaper bag off me (2 seconds). Then I took my son out of his seat and with one hand, was able to lift all of my items that were lined up next to each other(purse, diaper bag, liquids bag, carry-on bag, and carseat) onto the conveyor belt and in the bins in like 10 seconds. I even took my out my baby food, while bouncing my little guy in my arm. Of course it was more of an ordeal than if it was just me, but hey, I had baby. People and security understood and gave me consideration...well actually, I demanded it, I'll never see them again. I didn't allow myself to get flustered and it went fine.

-After I walked through, I just did everything in reverse. Took my items off the belt, strapped my little guy in, hooked my carry-on to the seat, and went on my merry way.

-It was even easier coming back because I felt seasoned.

So in conclusion(LOL)it took a little planning in my head before hand, but worked great!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Strap, Hook
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat can be installed securely using straps and hooks.

Review: I really like this seat and my 2 1/2 year old says its really comfortable.  Its nice that we will be able to use this seat through booster and hopefully it is the last one we have to buy!  I read some of the other reviews about having issues feeding the crotch strap buckle through the hole to move it to a different position.  I had some difficulty at first, but called Graco's 800 number and received help promptly!  The secret to moving it is not in the manual but the very nice rep said they will be adding it.  *****HERE'S THE SECRET: Slide the clip flat against the bottom of the seat towards the back of the seat until the edge is even with the hole.  Then tuck the corner of the clip through the hole and feed it through the other side.  Don't put any slack in the strap or it will bunch and won't go through*****  I might not have that word for word but call Graco and they can certainly talk you through it.

The final decision was the Graco Nautilus 3-1 Car Seat in Matrix.  This certainly was an excellent choice.  It is a much heavier weight than anticipated, easier to buckle the belts, nicely tailored, & has the desired saftey features for a growing child.  I bought two of these for my young grandsons, as I do not like the standard booster seats.  They (booster seats) are easy for a young child to unlatch the seat belt & allow too much movement. I definitely recommend this car seat.

Review:
I have two toddlers and we were taking a long trip. I had the original gogobabyz which I used with my oldest child when he was a toddler but it didn't fit my new larger britax seat, so I bought this britax cart, thinking it would be better because it was made by the company. On taking it out of the box, it looked like a "dolly" you would use to carry boxes. The latch attachments clip to these rectangular fixtures on the base and it sits a bit high off the ground (several inches). It felt a little unstable despite the fact that the seat was secured we'll to the cart. The issue seems to be the center of gravity being higher. Also when taking my child on a little test run around the house, when we rounded the bend into the kitchen, the latch attachments shifted to the side of the rectangular attachments and the whole seat tipped over. I figured I needed to install it like in the car, with more pressure. So I decided to tryit on the trip anyway.

Meanwhile, I emailed gogo babyz to see if they had a kit to make my old travelmate fit one of my kids marathon car seats. They did not have a retrofitting kit so they sent me a new travelmate that would fit my larger britax car seat - this is 6 years after I bought the original travelmate! That is some seriously unusual customer service! The car seat I installed quickly and felt very secure. It sits right on the floor and is quite stable. I loved the original and found this newer versionn even more secure and easier to install.

So off we went, with both kids in their car seats, one on the britax cart and the other on the gogobabyz. The britax cart tipped over repeatedly, injuring my son (however mildly), and terrifying my husband and me. the gogobabyz has larger wheels and a smoother ride. It corners like a porche. It does not tip. Clearly the britax engineers could learn something from the little company that invented the travelmate.

I sent the britax cart back and bought another gogobabyz travelmate. [[ASIN:B000JJK9EY Go-Go Babyz Kidz Travelmate]]

Amazon is great - full refund. Bought my new travelmate through amazon too,
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Marathon car seats
Installation Type: latch attachments
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat can be installed using latch attachments.

It was fairly easy to install and didn't take up much more room than our previous seat without the extra leg room. Love how easy the straps are to buckle / unbuckle as well. Highly recommend!

Review: We have two Peg convertible seats. The first, we got 7 years ago and the second is 3 years old. I'm replacing the first seat because it expired (they used to expire at 7 years, now it's 10) and wouldn't dream of buying anything else. These seats have lasted through three kids and are still in excellent shape. They are very comfortable on long trips, easy to tighten and install safely (as easy as any car seat can be) and my sons have stayed in them through 4/5 years of age. My now four year old is in the 80th percentile for height and still loves his seat! As a comparison, we got a Britax Boulevard around the same time as our first Peg seat and the fabric is showing wear and tear and no longer stays wrapped around the seat. It is also not as comfortable for big kids. The fabric on the Peg seat does great in a cold wash and comes out like new each time. We have had many Peg Perego products, strollers, infant seats etc. and their quality is second to none. They are definitely worth the investment, especially if you want something that lasts!

Review:
It's a little bit of a pain to install if you're having to transfer between vehicles that make it so you have to keep adjusting the length of the latch belt. Otherwise, it's easy to install if you're just moving it from one side of your backseat to the other side.

My toddler loves her new car seat from the color to the extra leg room. She tends to prefer to sit with the bottoms of her feet together versus her legs stretched out. She likes it that she can do both comfortably. The only thing she doesn't like is that her head hangs down onto her shoulder when she falls asleep. I know that all of the toddler car seats allow a lot of head room versus the infant car seats. So, I'll look into getting her something to make her more comfortable for when she chooses to nap in the car seat. Otherwise, we both love this car seat. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS CAR SEAT. It's steel frame was a big factor in my choice of car seat.

Review:
I know this is mean to the manufacturer, but I'm going to tell you the carseat I think you should get instead of this one: the Evenflo Symphony. That carseat costs less than this one, but comes with the amazing "SureLatch" installation system - if you have to take your carseat out and reinstall even once you will be so glad you have it. On that one, when you tighten the straps by pulling the tighten-me strap, the belt tightens from the bottom instead of from the top. This matters because if the belt pulls up from the top like on this carseat it will slide by your child's neck, occasionally giving them a minor "rug burn" of sorts. No, I don't work for Evenflo or anything unscrupulous like that.

OK, so this carseat: it's not bad. I do love that it's good for ten years and can turn into a booster seat. I hate installing it, but you've heard enough about that. It has nice cupholders, it's comfortable enough, it gets the job done. This would be a great car seat (and indeed everything we've gotten from Graco is great - strollers, high chairs, etc), if it weren't for Evenflo knocking it out of the park with their competing product.

Here are the pros and cons of this carseat as I saw them:

Looks cool
Drink holders!
Head padding for the baby

Another pro our car seat installer lady mentioned was that it is good for kiddos with hip dysplasia and they can fit the cast in there because it is so wide!

Cons:

The biggest con that I can not get around is the tightening of the straps knob is wedged against the back of the seat when it is backward facing, making it a huge production to tighten the straps every single time! It's really a hassle!

Review:
After doing a lot of research I decided on the Britax Roundabout 55 so I could get the safety features and high quality from the Britax name without spending a lot of money. I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I have a small car (Honda Fit) so my major concern was finding a convertible car seat that would fit in my car rear facing while allowing the passenger seat enough leg room. This carseat fit wonderfully and actually allowed more leg room space than our infant carseat did (Graco Snugride). I love how the tether feature adds stability to the car seat and it was easy to install.

On top of the safety features, it seems like it is very comfortable and my 8 month old son seems to love it. The fabric is soft yet breathable so he does not get as hot as he did in the Snugride (we live in SW Louisiana). It has a pad for the groin area so he can wear shorts without the buckles pinching his skin and the shoulder pads on the straps prevent red marks from appearing on his neck which was a problem with the Snugride. I also love that I am still able to recline the seat enough in rear facing mode so that when my son falls asleep he does not have his head dangling forward. I am very happy with this seat!

Review: This seat replaces a Chicco Keyfit 30 for my 12 month old son.  I have this seat facing backwards in a midsize German sedan. This seat is compact length wise, which gives the driver more space and has more leg room for the child when facing backwards  than the Britax Marathon 70 from two years ago, which is still in use in our SUV.  It is also highly adjustable.  The one deficiency which is almost inexcusable is the lack of a Belly Pad between the child and the buckle.  I recommend the "[[ASIN:B00CU82PKS Britax EZ-Buckle Belly Pad]]d" sold by Amazon for $16 to solve this problem.  It's spring loaded which prevents the child from sitting on the buckle and it protects them from pinching when buckling the belts.  I could have gone with thae new Britax convertible seat, but I have used other Chicco products and they seem to have a higher level of refinement, the buttons, latches and levers are easy to use and work smoothly.  This seat is a great fit for my needs.  And it seems a big comfort improvement over the Chicco Keyfit 30 seat my son was in before.

Review: I purchased this car seat from Amazon and it arrived 09/29/2012. On 01/23/2013 I was unable to release the buckle when dropping my daughter off at pre-school, and returned home prepared to cut her out of the seat. When I arrived home, the buckle opened - so I took her back to pre-school. The following day, I experienced the same problem - except when I arrived home, the buckle still would not open. I came inside for the heavy-duty scissors, not sure if they would cut the straps - and my wife came out to investigate. With some effort, she was finally able to free our daughter. I did some investigating, and found this is a common problem with Graco car seats - and as the review is titled, there is a federal probe into these buckles: "The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating complaints that children have been trapped in Graco car seats because the buckles won't unlatch." The probe covers seats made between 2009 and 2011, but ours was purchased new in 2012. I would urge people NOT TO BUY THIS CAR SEAT UNTIL GRACO HAS THIS ISSUE RESOLVED. I cannot take another chance putting my daughter in this seat because of two aggravating, inconvenient, and potentially dangerous incidents where I would not have been able to extricate my child in the event of an emergency.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type
- buckle would not open/unlatch
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The harness buckle is acceptable if it does not open or unlatch.

Review: I read so many reviews for lightweight convertible car seats and finally settled on this one. As others have mentioned, it has a lot of sharp edges that make installation uncomfortable. You also can't see the level line but I took a metallic sharpie to that and fixed it.  I was surprised that it does indeed require a towel to be placed under it when rear facing in some vehicles. We live in a city and don't have a car, so I'm an expert at installing car seats using the seat belt. The first Lyft was not a problem - car seat installed fine, even though you will scrape your arms installing it. I'm also still unsure if the seatbelt should go in front of or behind the shoulder straps, which also run under the same area as the seatbelt path.  The second Uber was a no go - I couldn't get it to install correctly no matter what. It really does need a towel. There's no way that I'm going to carry a towel with me and take the time to install it correctly in an Uber. If you're looking for something for uber/taxis/lyft, keep looking.

Review:
As a parent, safety is my top priority when it comes to car seats for my children. That's why I was thrilled to find the Evenflo EveryFit 4-in-1 Convertible Car Seat. This car seat is designed to grow with your child from infancy through the toddler years, making it a great investment for the long term.

One of the features I love about this car seat is the 4-in-1 design. It easily transitions from a rear-facing seat for infants, to a forward-facing seat for toddlers, to a high back booster seat, and finally to a no-back booster seat. This means that I can trust that my child is always in the safest position for their age and size.

The car seat also has a 5-point harness system and energy-absorbing foam for added protection in case of an accident. And the adjustable headrest and shoulder straps ensure that the seat is always a perfect fit for my child.

Overall, I am extremely satisfied with the safety and versatility of the Evenflo EveryFit 4-in-1 Convertible Car Seat. I highly recommend it to any parent looking for a reliable and safe car seat for their child.

Review: Finally, I have found a carseat that is perfect. I have 2 sons, and I have owned many carseats. They had outgrown the 45 lb weight limit on thier carseats, so I was in search of new carseats with the harnesses, since I am not ready for them to be in boosters with regular seat belts. After doing alot of research, the Graco Nautulis seemed perfect, yet was a little more money than I wanted to spend, since I had to buy 2. We bought another product that was about $30 cheaper. After being very disappointed with the other product, we returned those and purchased 2 Graco Nautulis carseats, in the Matrix pattern. I could not be more pleased. My boys LOVE them. They seem to be very comfortable, and fit them very well. They are both big for thier age, and the Nautulis fits them very well. Also, my husband says they were simple to install and fit well in our SUV. If you are looking for a front facing car seat for your toddler, the Graco Nautulis is the way to go. They also turn into high back boosters, then no back boosters, so we will never have to buy carseats/boosters again. I wish I would have gotten these car seats a long time ago, and I will recommend them to all the moms I know!!!

Review: This is a well made car seat with some nice features without breaking your pockets. I bought this to be a seat in my husband's car. Our daughter usually rides with me but it's good to have an extra seat around. The fabric isn't quite as plush as I would have liked but it is still soft. The dual handles for adjusting the harness do take a little strength, not as easy as the one handed version, but still gets the job done. My husband's car doesn't have LATCH and it's a good thing because the seat has the anchor clip type of latches and not the push button, which is a real pain. The fabric and cup holder come off easily for cleaning and the fabric can be dried in a dryer. My daughter loves sitting in this seat and it seems to give her a lot of leg room in the reversed mode. For about $100, I don't think you'll find better features.

Review:
Just received this seat yesterday for my 4 year old. We were replacing our Britax Diplomat that she had just outgrown. She looks very comfortable in the seat and has plenty of room. I'm confident she will be able to use the seat for a good while. She is on the small side, about 37 inches tall and only 33 pounds. Aside from all the safety features, my favorite part is the belly buckle is always stuck forward, no more sitting on it.
I previously installed her old seat with the seatbelt as the Diplomat (like the Roundabout but with the side wings) didn't have the independent latch hooks for each side of the seat, I wasn't able to get it as tight with latch. This seat was super easy to install with latch. I fiddled with the seatbelt lock off and that looked relatively simple too, you just have to slip your fingers between the front of the seat cover. The cover is able to be taken off without taking the seat out of the car and taking all the straps off- that may make it easier to install with the seatbelt so you can see what you're doing.
I also love how long the seats last before expiring, and they hold up very well, her old seat will be passed down to our second child, due in June. Britax even makes a foam piece to help newborns fit in their convertible seats, very excited to have our matching "cowseats" when the new baby comes along.

Review: Kind of a basic car seat with some really nice features. It grows with the child, and that is a huge selling point. This is not an item that you will need to replace every few months (or even years for that matter). Sturdy construction with a kind of basic design. the understated design, however makes it appropriate for any gender and it will look classy in any car regardless of make, model or design. This is not one of those oversized, beastly car seats that you have to muscle in and out of your auto. This has a great design feature that actually provides for more legroom for the passenger in front of the car seat. That alone makes it an outstanding item versus other brands (traveling with your child should not be at the detriment of other passengers). All the required safety features are here and this car seat provides for extra side-impact protection. Easy to clean with removable padding and cup holder. This car seat could actually demand a much higher price, but it seems as though the folks at Safety 1st are bringing you a quality product at a fair price without skimping on safety. That should be taken as a huge compliment in this era of "profits over common sense." You really cannot go wrong here. It works, it's safe, it seems comfortable (no complaints), and it has a modern sleekness to it. This is really all you need.

Review:
This seat gave us 17 months of infrequent use before the Clicktight (CT) feature rendered the seat unusable. Because we don't have a dedicated vehicle and instead use car-and ride-sharing services, knowing we would be able to safely, correctly, and quickly install a seat with a standard seatbelt in any vehicle, anytime, anywhere was what sold us on the Marathon CT. We were willing to pay more for the CT feature and lug this beast of a seat into Ubers and Zipcars, through airports, and on planes because we believed its quality and supposed ease of use was worth the extra weight and hassle. We still stood behind this seat when its quirks started showing (the harness tension was always slightly uneven no matter how many times we reset it; the harness adjustment area became a repository for crumbs and curious fingers; the selected recline angle was deceiving and would usually decrease once the CT system was engaged; the lower harness straps sometimes left marks on my child's legs; and so on).

Unfortunately, the CT system proved to be the demise of this seat. More often than not, the CT dial would only partially engage when I pushed the panel down with my hands, especially when all slack was removed from the seatbelt as instructed. Instead of clicking shut, the panel would bounce off a taut belt. A gentle kneel was almost always needed to fully lock or disengage the CT panel. The seat also was difficult to rear-face in our preferred rear center position in certain vehicles, with multiple attempts needed to ensure a no-budge install.

While attempting to install the Marathon CT rear-facing in the rear center position in Toyota sedan last weekend, I encountered my typical issue of the panel not fully engaging when pushed down. I gently kneeled on it to click it shut and the dial became displaced under the panel, making it inoperable. Because we were away from home at a special event, I looked for other ways to install the seat without using CT and found that using LATCH on this seat is (1) absolutely horrendous and (2) impossible to achieve safely without having a functional CT panel, as the LATCH belt path runs under it. We were grateful to make it home safely by doing a makeshift LATCH installation in an outboard seat (kind of like how you attach a seat to the Britax wheeled travel cart, which incidentally ALSO broke the same day - so much for Britax quality!). The LATCH belt was very difficult to loosen and it took 15 minutes for my spouse and I to remove the seat from the car. Worst of all, the seat is no longer safe to use.

I have since looked for information in the installation manual as well as on Britax's site about whether kneeling on the CT panel during installation is acceptable and have found nothing discouraging or forbidding it. The seat is no longer under warranty, but I reported the issue to Britax and am awaiting a response. If anything, the CT malfunction has greatly diminished my once-high regard for Britax's safety and durability. I am very disappointed and am looking for a non-Britax replacement.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Clicktight, standard seatbelt, LATCH
Harness Type: harness tension, harness adjustment, lower harness straps
Seat Type: rear-facing
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat is easy to install using a Clicktight system, standard seatbelt, or LATCH connectors.
The harness provides proper tension and is easy to adjust, with lower harness straps that are accessible.
The seat is designed for rear-facing use.

Review: We bought this seat for our daughter, after a very problematic experience with Sunshine Kids Radian.  I have 3 kids, and I put a lot of thought into our car seats.  Weeks upon weeks of research and reviews.  This is by far the best car seat we've ever owned, and we've owned some amazing seats.  I don't think I've ever seen a seat get the kind of install that this seat gets.  You literally cannot move it at all.  I love the top tether set up, the LATCH, and the seat belt clamps.  No matter if I use the LATCH in our mivivan, or the seat belt in our older SUV, this seat is 100% safe.  Not only that, but I would imagine that this seat will easily fit into most cars, even smaller models.  My daughter will be rear facing for a long time in this seat.  Britax just cannot be beat.

Review: We bought this car seat for our 9 month old daughter because she is a very long baby and doesn't fit in her infant car seat any more. I didn't read any reviews because I was too excited about getting such a good deal on the seat and the other seat we have is Graco and we love it. She obviously still has to be rear facing until she is 2 according to the laws and the fact that her neck muscles wouldn't be strong enough to withstand a crash if she was forward facing. My husband and I spent 3 hours trying to get this seat in our car. The instructions say to place rolled up towels under the front of the seat to create an incline. With the towels under there we couldn't get it to tighten enough with the seat belt or the in seat latch hooks. We tried taking the towels out but the placement of the straps is so far at the front of the seat that if i slammed on my breaks the seat would be able to tip up towards the back of the car no matter how tight the belts are. We turned it around and tried to see if it would go in well forward facing and it did a great job. It was completely secure. Unfortunately it sat in my garage for over 30 before we attempted to put it in the car so I couldn't return it, otherwise I would have. But now we just have to find something else and we will be able to use this one when she is two. I wouldn't recommend it if you are buying for an under 2 year old.

It's to the point that we wonder if it isn't a faulty model. Additionally, the belt latch over the crotch is very tight. We removed the cushion from that area and it's still quite snug. Our child is in the 5th % for weight and 50th % for height, so clearly our specific car seat would not fit most children.

It is installed in our 2006 4Runner and appears to sit too upright, not the recommended recline I've read about. We will be replacing it.

Meanwhile, the Boulevard model we use in our Volvo XC90 has exceeded our expectations - great fit for baby and in the car.

Review: For the price of these car seats, they need some serious work on installation and the instruction manuals.  We already own a pair of Chicco MyFits with the adjustable strap height, and it's a joke that at this price on the Radians you have to remove the seat and rethread the harnesses.  I thought they would save more space vs. the MyFits with the cupholders removed, but the two Dionos free up maybe a centimeter compared to the Chicco seats when side by side.  The rear tethers have clips that are too long, so it's really hard to tighten the tether when the anchor point is right behind the head rest.  Don't even think about traveling with these seats - they weigh a ton.  Also, the shock absorber thing you have to install when your child is forward facing and between 20 and 40 pounds is a bad idea because it's hidden after you put it in.  Who is going to remember to remove their car seat, take that thing out, and reinstall the seat a year later when their child is heavier?  Also, the instruction manual was vague as to whether to pop out the bottom angle adjuster thing for my child's weight.  All the installation videos on youtube contradicted the manual on this so I'm pretty sure most people are getting it wrong.  Lastly, what's the deal with no actual installation video on the Diono website?  Why bother having videos at all if all they show is how you open the seat from the box and offer generic tips like 'always read the manual'?  I'm watching the video because I can't follow your manual!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: installation and the instruction manuals, remove the seat and rethread the harnesses, rear tethers have clips that are too long, really hard to tighten the tether, shock absorber thing you have to install when your child is forward facing and between 20 and 40 pounds, remove their car seat, take that thing out, and reinstall the seat, pop out the bottom angle adjuster thing for my child's weight, installation videos on youtube contradicted the manual, no actual installation video on the Diono website
Weight Range of Child: when your child is forward facing and between 20 and 40 pounds, when their child is heavier, for my child's weight
Harness Type: rethread the harnesses
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The seat should be easy to install and reinstall without needing to frequently remove and rethread components. Clear and consistent instructions and videos should be available directly from the manufacturer. Tethers should be easy to tighten, and any clips should be an appropriate length for secure installation. Any required adjustments or accessory installations for specific child weights should be simple to perform without needing to fully uninstall the seat. It is acceptable if certain accessories are only needed for specific weight ranges during forward-facing use.

Review:
I wanted to love this seat. I really did. I bought two of them. But I just canâ€™t.

Pros:
-Very nice comfortable fabric, that reminds me of a much more expensive Chicco nextfit.

-Easy to clean and pull off fabric cover and throw in the wash.

-Super safe if you can get a good install, and made in the USA.

Cons:
-Difficult to install. The Latch system is one strap with two buckles that runs through the back of the seat. I purchased this seat after we were in an accident, and this seat replaced a Britax seat. Britax seats come with two individual straps/buckles that attach to a steel bar that then attach to your latch system. This method is infinitely easier to install and get a tight install in minutes, every time. I have never been able to get a tight install with the latch system with this evenflo seat. Yes, you can put pool noodles underneath the seat to get a tighter install as other reviewers have mentioned, but who wants to deal with that? I have gotten a good/tight install with the seatbelt installation though. So take that for what itâ€™s worth.

-The harness is hard to adjust. On both of my seats, the harness can get stuck in one position and Iâ€™ve had to yank on it so hard that I thought I was going to break it, just to adjust it. This is a no-go if you have multiple kids at different heights using the seat, or if you just need to change the harness height in a hurry. Maybe itâ€™s just my two seats, but both of them are not easy to adjust.

-The harness is difficult to tighten. Enough said.

-To adjust the headrest height of the seat, thereâ€™s a lever you push down on the BACK of the headrest to move the headrest up and down. Not a big deal, right? Itâ€™s not, if the seat isnâ€™t already installed. If it is, you canâ€™t do it. You have to take the seat out of the car and adjust the headrest. Again, pain in the A** if youâ€™re in a hurry and trying to adjust it for another kid.

-This may not be a con to some, but this seat is huge. If you need room in your car for additional passengers, Iâ€™d suggest the Graco Slimfit.

-The base of this seat has no level indicator just a line that should run parallel to the ground. This isnâ€™t a huge deal, but considering the price of this seat, and itâ€™s competitors all do, I was surprised it didnâ€™t come with this option.

Overall Iâ€™m debating getting rid of both of these seats and replacing them with the Graco 4ever, thatâ€™s how much I dislike them. My kids say theyâ€™re very comfortable, thatâ€™s the only reason Iâ€™ve kept them for as long as I have. If you donâ€™t have to move these seats from vehicle to vehicle, theyâ€™re fine, but the fact that the harness is difficult to tighten on ours every single time we get in the vehicle is enough to make me want to get a new seat. I donâ€™t recommend.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Difficult to install. The Latch system is one strap with two buckles that runs through the back of the seat. I have never been able to get a tight install with the latch system with this evenflo seat. I have gotten a good/tight install with the seatbelt installation though.
Harness Type: The harness is hard to adjust. The harness can get stuck in one position. The harness is difficult to tighten.
Material: Very nice comfortable fabric, easy to clean and pull off fabric cover and throw in the wash.
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be easy to install using the Latch system, allowing for a tight and secure fit. A tight installation should also be achievable with the seatbelt. The harness should be easy to adjust and tighten without getting stuck. The fabric should be comfortable, easy to clean, and removable for washing.

Review:
The LATCH system is impossible to tighten in rear facing installation - this was an issue in both my Jeep Cherokee and my husband's Dodge Ram truck. The seatbelt can be used, however then the seat tips slightly to the side (or a lot to the side in the truck), which is irritating at the least, if not unsafe. The LATCH system is also just the metal clips you have to hook through. There is no seatbelt lock off to use either. I am stuck with this car seat but the second one I purchased, I am returning.
On the positive side, when in the most reclined position my baby was comfortable when he was sleeping.

Our daughter loves this car seat. We got this when she was 6 months old, being that sheâ€™s been in the 99 percentile for height since birth.
It has a lot of padding, makes me kind of jealous when we go on trips.
The only thing with all the padding and being in Maryland, the humidity and heat durning the summer. Being rear facing I felt like she wasnâ€™t getting as much air flow too her. If I didnâ€™t cool the car down before she would sweat a little.
As far as space, it fits well in my Grand Cherokee and my husbands truck. Although if you had a small car or suv it would be a tight squeeze when itâ€™s rear facing. So if it was behind driver or passenger seat they wouldnâ€™t be able to adjust their seat. Forward facing wouldnâ€™t be a problem.

Cleaning:
P.I.A, unless I have no idea what Iâ€™m doing. You have to take the entire carseat out to get the cover off. Cleaning it for the first time made me a little nervous, because it seemed like there was a lot of hooks/bands holding on the cover. Almost thought I wouldnâ€™t remember how to get it back on. Luckily it wasnâ€™t as bad as I thought. Just tedious.

All in all, I would recommend this car seat.

Review: We bought this car seat for my 10 month old daughter, who sits rear facing. It's comfortable for her to sit in, but the base slides up all the time.  Our seats are not leather (I saw someone else also had this problem but the had leather seats.  We do not and we still have this problem.) By the time we get to our destination, my daughter will practically be laying on her back because the base has slid up. We even took it to the state's certified car seat technicians to install it since we were having so much trouble.  They got it to install correctly, but it took a long time.  But within a month, we are struggling with the sliding once again.  It is really, really hard to tighten the strap to the base, but it loosens very easily.  This is very dangerous if we were to get in a car accident! I don't think this would be an issue if I put the car seat forward facing, but it is meant for smaller children.  I would never recommend this seat to anyone.

Review: After many months of research, I finally chose the Evenflo Triumph Advance LX.  I purchased this in late 2008 for my 16 month old daughter.  We have used this for about 2 months now.  She has never liked any car seat, and still doesn't really enjoy this one, but I do.  The seat is big and comfy and seems much safer with the sides around the head area.  The best feature(s) to me are the adjustable straps.  The shoulder straps slide easily up and down to the correct position and stay that way until I move them, and the knob for adjusting the lap straps are so easy to use.  I can see now that, unfortunately, my oldest child was probably not secured safely in his seat.  I initially wanted a seat that reclined and this was one reason I went with the Triumph Advance.  However, once I read the manual, it seems that the recline position is only to be used with the rear-facing position and my child is too big for that.  The only drawback would be how large this seat is.  I have a larger vehicle so it is not an issue for me but I don't think this seat would fit in a small car.  We are currently using the back seat, middle position and I sometimes have difficulty in seeing around the seat to back up.  It sits quite a bit taller than our old car seat.  Overall, I am extremely pleased with this car seat and am thrilled with my decision to go with Evenflo Triumph.

Review:
We have had this seat for about 2 years and I absolutely love it!!!

The install on this seat is rock solid. It fits perfectly in my van and looks sharp.

My son is 3 yrs, 7 months and 36 lbs. He is still rearfacing in this seat. My goal was to rearface until 4 yrs old and thanks to Britax, we will likely make it (my son is tall and would have had to flip around in most other seats by now; this seat has one of the highest RF height limits on the market).

I also love the extra side impact protection on the advocate. We drive a mini van that does not have a middle seat in the second row. Having to seat my son outboard made me very nervous but this seat gives me some peace of mind.

Speaking of peace of mind, the steel reinforced frame is awesome. I know they say all carseats are the same as far as safety, but...come on....steel over plastic seems like an obvious choice here.

This is just an all around great seat. My son is comfortable in it, it looks great, and I am confident that I am doing everything in my power to keep him as safe as possible in the car.

Review: Ok, so first of all I'm an avid review reader. When picking this seat I read all the reviews and compared it to many seats like it along the way. From what I could see this seat was the seat that best fit our needs. It fits our car comfortably  (2016 Sienna) & my son seems to like it . I did read on some other reviews they disliked the shoulder pads, but we use our are they seem to fit our baby well. The straps are super easy to adjust, and I don't have any problem reaching the seat to take the baby in and out (I'm 5'4"). At this point my baby is 9 months old and in the 75th percentile for Hieght, he is rear facing and looks very comfortable. After reading the reviews and ratings on all for me it was between a Britax Marathon,  Graco my ride & forever, or the Chicco Nextfit. I mainly decided on this because it seemed to rate higher overall and I read a lot of reviews that said it didn't seem as bulky as many other convertible seats. We have ours behind our driver seat and neither My husband or I have any issue with the leg room. If I am able to update my review tomorrow with pictures in the car I will add them. Hope this helps,  happy shopping :)

Last night, she and my husband were in a crash in which the car went off an embankment and rolled over. Every airbag in the car deployed (including roof and curtain airbags in the backseat), and it is undoubtedly going to be a total loss. However, my daughter is miraculously unscathed. I have no doubt the safety of this car seat played a huge part in her wellbeing. I will definitely be repurchasing this seat.

After installing the seat, it was a little awkward to adjust the straps, as there isn't access to one in the back to help pull them into position.
The handle for the headrest also rattles like crazy! I contacted the company and they said this is normal due to the adjustable headrest feature. Normal or not, it is SO ANNOYING.

Tried 2, still not enough. Put two pieces of 1x6 underneath. Nope. Added pool noodles on top of that. Yep. Finally reclined to proper line. But now its so high up the latch belts wont reach! HA. And yes the seat is in the most reclinded position using the built in angle adjuster. Now let's just say sure, I'm going to trust the safety of my son to some 99cent pool noodles, now no one can sit in the front seat. This really could only be used front facing and even then it's a tight squeeze. My Graco infant carrier car seat fits great no problems. Guess well be using that till he grows out of it. Review:
I cannot say enough good things about this car seat. It has so many safety features that none of my other car seats have ever had. It is so sturdy and well built! Here are just a few reasons why I am in love!

The bottom of the seat is rubber! (so it doesn't slide around)
The shoulder straps have an added strap that connects to the additional rubber chest pads(used in front facing)
When tightening the straps, it clicks, letting you know when it is snug "enough"
There is added padding everywhere (at least it seems that way)
It has a steel frame
The car seat is not as wide as it looks, yet roomy. (if your child is pretty chunky, it would be a tight fit. However, I would think this is a good thing unless the child is uncomfortable.)
The side impact things move up and down as your child's height adjusts.
The pink print is simply beautiful! Very girly yet classy.
The seat also comes with tether straps in the back that are supposed to indicate when there has been too much wear and tear to the car seat ( i guess this would also depend on how much your are taking the seat in and out of the car.)

I have owned graco and the newer evenflo convertible car seats and they have NOTHING on this seat. The quality is just so much better here and the evenflo doesn't seem to have half as much padding or quality fabric as this britax symphony has.
I was very reluctant to spend so much money on a car seat, but now, I wouldn't purchase any other one. When it comes to your child's life, I'd take the chance and trust that these extra features and quality will provide that added safety. (ps. I have 3 kids so money is tight, but this was well worth the extra cost.)

Review:
I don't have anything negative to say about this car seat.

1.) Small size
I purchased this car seat specifically, after hours of research, for its small size. I have a 2007 Subaru Impreza wagon; the back seat is not deep by any means, and in addition to that, there is really no leg room in the rear (I'm 5'8" and my husband is 6'). It is narrow and not deep at all. I was amazed at how much room I had in my car after it was installed.

2.) Using an infant seat in conjunction
With my first daughter, an infant car seat could only fit in the center seat, with both seats pushed up a few inches. We dealt with that with our daughter, however, we are expecting baby number 2! I needed a solution, otherwise I would have to trade in my car. There was no car seat that had the dimensions to be able to squeeze next to an infant car seat in the middle with the exception of this one. We could literally put 3 of these in our back seat with room to spare, which is incredible.

3.) Rear-facing recline degree/space
We have installed it behind the passenger seat as forward-facing (an infant car seat fitting perfectly beside it), however it would definitely fit rear-facing if we needed it to. If you're going to use it rear-facing, it does not recline NEAR as far back as I'm used to with other convertible car seats.

4.) Comfort/value/price
Besides the fact that it is downright adorable, I got it for $169.99 which is the cheapest I've seen the car seat on Amazon and Babies-R-Us and Target.com for months. I had to buy it then, especially with it being Prime eligible. It seems very comfortable and padded and the material looks durable. It is supposed to be incredibly easy to throw in the wash, which is why I didn't mind going with the light lime color.

5.) Installation
Installation was easy...says hubby. Very secure fit, which was hard to accomplish with the three other convertible car seats I've tried in my car. Instructions are easy to read and understand. I've heard if you have problems with it not fitting snugly, to try using a piece of pool noodle (or call Combi directly and they will ship you out something similar).

Overall, it seems to be a wonderful, thoughtful product at a great price. If I could afford to, I'd get two for each of our cars once baby #2 is born and out of infant seat!

My daughter, 6-7mo gets car sick whenever we use this car seat. I think it's because she can see outside and that makes her sick, or dizzy maybe. IDK.

Also, when she sleeps her head drops in a way that makes me concerned about asphyxiation. Definitely better for an older kiddo, but it works so far. I just have to put up a blanket in front of the window.

Review:
Fit my newborn (7lbs, 13oz, 21 inches long) great from birth with the help of receiving blankets rolled up on the sides. He seems comfy, doesn't complain when he's in it. I love the material, I've never seen a car seat so easy to clean - and with a newborn you need easy cleaning options!
*Update*
I just moved my son to the next size car seat. He made it to 13 months before he outgrew the height level. He's not yet 32 inches tall as the specs say, but his since he has such a large torso his head was nearing the top of the shell.
I have a lot more to say about this seat now that I've used it for over a year, and I'm leaving my original rating of 5 stars as it is. I still love this seat!
It was so easy to change the height of the straps as he grew, and so easy to pull everything apart to wash when we had accidents. It's quick to install with either the base or without it, and I was never worried about it not being secure.
The recline button didn't get much use in my large truck with it's bench seat, but when we put this in the bucket seats of our scion tc we used it a bit to level everything out. It was simple to use, and didn't take any time to set correctly.
My son is in a high percentile for height, so the leg cover only lasted him about 3 months, and being born in May we didn't use it much - So I can't comment on how useful it was. The few times I used it, it was easy to take on and off, so I can at least say that.
As a side note, we also own the click connect double stroller, and this worked perfectly with it. We've been very impressed by Graco!

Weight Range of Child: 7lbs, 13oz
Material: easy to clean
Installation Type: easy to install with either the base or without it
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be suitable for infants starting from 7 pounds, 13 ounces. It should be easy to clean. It should be easy to install, whether using the base or not.

Review: Iâ€™m a CPST instructor and tried out the BubbleBum backless booster with my 8 year old daughter. I normally keep her in a Britax Frotier 90 with the harness, however for her 8th birthday she was going on a trip with two of her friends and she was going to be the only one still in a "car seat". I decided to get a BubbleBum seat for the trip. We made a two hour drive each direction.  The pros- My daughter said it was comfortable for her, it fit well having 3 kids across the row.  At $25.00 Itâ€™s economical. The only con I could find was that the seat slipped when she was getting into it. I wish it had latch attachments to hold the seat in place. My daughter also needed assistance and reminders to use the seatbelt guides which if she was in a high back booster she would need the reminders/ assistance. All that being said this is great for those that do car pooling or having an extra seat for grandma/ grandpa. Overall great seat.

Review:
Love how easy this was to install due to the latch system. I am also glad I got the slim fit since I have an Equinox and there is not much room in the back (we put the seat in the center). However there is a tiny bit more room now than when we had the Chicco pumpkin seat in. (I can sit next to the car seat now without it pressing into my leg/side as before. For reference, I am 200lbs, so not a small person.)
Now my favorite parts are that the seat can easily have the height changed. I have a tall baby so that will be great to not have to keep getting taller seats or take a long time to adjust.
Also this car seat has been a blessing because baby (4 month old) will ride in this much longer before starting to get upset and even then she just gets a bit fussy. (I have one of those kids that hates the car seat!!) There are two adjustments for the back facing and one allows her to sit up more (which she loves!) as well as being able to kick her feet (and see her feet). We also have enough room to put one of those music kick pianos (strapped down) at her feet so she can have something to do during the drive since she is still learning her hands.
I appreciate that the cup holders can slide into itself because it would be uncomfortable for a passenger to ride next to the seat if they didn't since as I mentioned before, not much room as it is.

I also like that the side padding next to her head is not touching the side of her head like in the pumpkin seat since that was another thing she didn't like (she would jerk her head side to side trying to get away from it). I still get the safety without her being unhappy.
Even though I can't take her in and out in the seat (which not like she liked that anyway), I really am glad I went ahead and got this one. She can get used to it and not have to worry about getting used to a different chair well into her toddler days and even then we would just have to get the booster. If I had a do over I would definitely have started with this car seat!!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Latch
Material: Slim fit, side padding
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be rear facing for safety. It should be easy to install using the LATCH system. The seat should have a slim fit to save space and include side padding for comfort and protection.

Review:
Updated 5/2020:
A year later - still not great but fine enough. I do like the cup holders built into the seat arms. We now have another car seat next to this one and both cup holders are still useable, whereas one of the the flip up cup holders on the Nuna are now blocked by the second car seat. But otherwise, itâ€™s still awkward for him to sit in this seat at almost 3. If I could have gotten two Nuna I would have.

Updated 7/29:
Now using daily and I am no longer a fan of this car seat. The straps are lopsided - one tightens more than the other, canâ€™t resolve, and Iâ€™m sure one loose strap isnâ€™t safe. The straps have to be really low behind his back for his head to be in the â€œhead areaâ€. If straps are at a comfortable, normal spot on his shoulder, the â€œhead areaâ€ is above his head. Other reviews mentioned this, but the buckle is so short, itâ€™s hard to buckle the straps and not catch his clothing, legs in it. Argh!

Updated 5/29:
We have now flown with this car seat on an alaska airlines flight, and installed it in two cars. Used a car seat dolly in the airport and with a 25 lbs kid it was just fine as a â€œstrollerâ€. The car seat fit just fine on the window seat with the arm rest up between it and my middle seat (I am 5â€™10â€ and sat comfortably next to it).

Somewhat difficult to install in the cars because we canâ€™t get the seatbelt tight without the car seat being incredibly lopsided. The bottom harness straps are really awkward and wide - instead of going straight to the back, they go wide and cover his legs. Not sure how to explain this any better but itâ€™s really weird, seems uncomfortable, and maybe not safe?

Original review: Purchased it because we needed a second one for another car, and to use after he maxes out of his primary seat.

Graco may allow for rear-facing longer (I hope - you never know with height, and Iâ€™m not sure if or how the leg extension will work). The Graco extends higher than MCM and is easier to install. Graco seat looks more comfortable - itâ€™s flat, whereas the MCM dips down quite a bit. The MCM was slightly â€œbeefierâ€ and I liked that the side impact was also adjustable - but hard to say how child will fit in this car seat later so I liked the backless booster option on the Graco as opposed to possibly having a high-back seat that is very uncomfortable or not useable for older child. They have the same height limit, but Graco becomes backless booster 100-120lbs, MCM is high back to 120lbs. The cup holders on the MCM were small, I couldnâ€™t fit the Thermos funwhatever bottle. The Graco cup holders pull out quite easily, toddler enjoys doing this...sigh. I donâ€™t think the Graco fabric/color chooses are attractive, but can live.

Purchased May 2019. The Graco seat was manufactured in Feb 2019, the MCM in December 2018 (I was worried discounted price = much older seat).

It was hard to choose, as they are similar prices, but other reviews of the seats helped me (Graco rattling noise? Ugh, hope ours doesnâ€™t. MCM fabric pilling? Guess I wonâ€™t know) so I hope this helps you.

Review: This is a nice-looking, sturdy car seat that is easy to install and adjust as your child grows.  My daughter loves her new "big kid" seat with cup holders, and we love that she is so safe in the seat.  There are two major problems with this seat, however.  First, with all of the stuff on the harness straps (HUGS chest pads, shoulder pads) it is very difficult to get the straps tight enough to be safe. You really have to pull on it hard to get the straps to tighten up.  Second, it is difficult to reach the place you have to push to release the harness straps and your child.  The good thing about this is that your child will never be able to take off her harness herself.  But it is difficult for mom to reach, too.  Overall we are happy with the seat but at this price it shouldn't be so hard to work the harness properly.

Review: I got this to fit in the back of my 2011 CRV and it fits well despite seeming really big out of the package. There is so much padding this too and I love that it has an attached cup holder and adjustable headrest. This is the first car seat that my daughter has been able to fall asleep in. In her other ones she would cry all the time in the car. I think they may have been uncomfortable for her. The wings of the headrest can be adjusted so they come in and my daughter lays her head against it to fall asleep. The only thing is that this is really heavy! I was surprised how heavy it was. Overall I am happy with my purchase.

Review: When my daughter outgrew her Chicco KeyFit 30, it was time to get a convertible car seat. I think all convertible seats are more of a hassle than the infant carriers. It took me nearly an hour to install this seat in my car (Prius). I purchased a seat cover too but soon discovered that the cover made the car seat slide so I removed it. In order to tighten the seat properly into the car, I had to climb into the seat. This was only possible because I'm petite. I do not know how someone larger than me could get at the right angle to secure the seat. The Extend2Fit feature is nice because my daugher's feet don't kick the seat. However, the trade off is that when fully extended, it pushes the car seat to the edge of the back seat. This in turn means that the front seat has to be pulled forward. I'm short so it wasn't too much of an issue for me. Might be better in a larger SUV or minivan. It is nearly impossible to properly tighten the harness. It tightens around my daughter's legs and is loose on her chest. The buckle strap is incredibly short. If you are used to the ease of use of the Chicco KeyFit 30 harness, you'll be very frustrated with this seat. Also, removing the padding to clean is a big chore. My daughter vomited in the car and I managed to contain it to just one area on the seat. But the process of removing the padding and harness was so difficult, it spread the vomit everywhere. I had to completely dissassemble the seat down to the booster to get it clean. One plus of the seat is that my daughter was thrilled with the cup holders.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: convertible car seat
Installation Type: install
Harness Type: harness, buckle strap
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat can be installed as a convertible seat. The harness and buckle strap are used for installation.

Review: I read countless reviews on this seat and the Chicco Nextfit trying to decide which to purchase. I ended up buying both to test them out at home. Every time I put my 6 month old in the Britax, he cried. Maybe a coincidence, but odd. He also looked uncomfortable even in the most reclined setting. I also didn't like the shock absorber pads. They were awkward, stiff and uncomfortable looking. With the strap pads and the shock absorber pads on the straps at the same time, it made it impossible to get a correct fit on my baby--the chest clip was on his belly when fully tightened. I assume they expect you to remove the strap pads in this scenario because the shock absorbers can not be removed (from what I could tell). Overall, the Britax seemed to be a better fit for an older baby or toddler, not for my (very tall) 6 month old. I ended up keeping the Nextfit. He never cried when I put him in it, and still doesn't. A huge improvement from his Britax Bsafe car seat which was so narrow he always cried in it.

Review:
We've had the Peg Prego convertible for over a month now - our son is 10.5 months old, about 23 lbs. He seems comfortable in it - never once complained. He even fell asleep in it today when we were driving, which confirmed for me that he was fine in it.
We had the retailer fit two different car seats - this one (Prego), and the Recaro. We got one whole inch more of space with the Peg Prego compared to the Ricaro (we could move the front seat back a bit more), which is why we decided on the Peg Prego. It's a bit more expensive compared with the other seats, but overall, easy to install, and looks pretty good too. Also, we found that it was easier to seat our son into the Peg Prego since the sides do not rise up very high (for the Recaro, we'd have to risk pressing his head to the ceiling of the car to seat him in the car seat). We have a small car (Acura TSX).

Review:
This seat seems to work well and my daughter likes it. I was worried she wouldn't sleep well in it on long car rides but she just leans her head against the side and doesn't seem to have a problem. It does have a strong chemical smell coming out of the box, so I would recommend airing it out before use.

Installation was fairly easy as carseats go. I did have to basically get in the seat to tighten the straps but that's par for the course. The latch connections are easier than the hook style so thats nice. I also had to remove the headrest in the back seat of my Ford edge because the back is so tall I couldn't get it to sit correctly without doing that. Haven't used it rear facing mode but it seems like you'd need a pretty big car because the seat is so tall.

Edit: I just installed a second seat in our Nissan Maxima and also had to remove the headrest as it won't fit when the seat is installed.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: latch connections are easier than the hook style; had to remove the headrest in the back seat of my Ford edge because the back is so tall I couldn't get it to sit correctly without doing that; installed a second seat in our Nissan Maxima and also had to remove the headrest as it won't fit when the seat is installed
Seat Type: Haven't used it rear facing mode but it seems like you'd need a pretty big car because the seat is so tall
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be easy to install with latch connections. It is acceptable if the seat requires removing the vehicle's headrest to fit correctly. It is acceptable if the seat is tall and may require a larger vehicle for rear-facing installation.

Review: My daughter is 5 1/2 and tall for her age at 48 inches and 47 lbs. She just outgrew her harness in her Recaro ProSport. Since the ProSport was recently recalled, I was informed that because of the recall we could no longer use the latch in booster mode. So I wanted to replace it with a safe booster seat that latched to the vehicle for safety and convenience. Who wants a 30 lb projectile in their car, not me!! I considered the Clek Oobr and Cybex Solution Q-Fix. The Oobr apparently has a short seat pan and is uncomfortable for a lot of kids, especially tall kids like my daughter. The Cybex looks like a great booster. However I was recommended this booster by a CPST and at more than half the price of the other boosters it was a great value. It also becomes a backless booster which the Cybex doesn't do. It is also rated a Best Bet booster by the IIHS. The other great features that only Britax has is the safeguard which keeps the lap belt in the proper position and the safe cell in the base which reduces the forward movement in your child in a collision. At first when I looked at the booster online I had 2 main concerns. Was it upright and flimsy? I can now say no to both of those concerns. This seat is so sturdy and well made. Very solid and substantial. The fabric is very nice looking and great quality, very thick. My daughter loves the pink and it looks great in our van. The bottom part of the booster where the child sits is very well padded and has a thick cushion. The booster back hinges slightly which allows you to get a great angle in your car. I have seen other reviewers think this is a defect but it is designed like that so you can get a great angle for different cars. This seat fits perfect in my Honda Odyssey 2nd row captain's chair. It is so easy to latch in, it takes about 1 minute. My daughter has a perfect seatbelt fit in this booster. The headrest is very easy and smooth to move up and down. I was very sad to have to move her out of a 5 point harness but seeing her so well secured and comfortable in this booster has put my mind at ease. I have come to love the quality and safety of Britax! My youngest is in a Britax Chaperone and my 3 year old is getting the Frontier 90 to replace his recalled ProSport. Britax has great customer service as well. My ONLY complaint with the seat so far is that it is made in China, I wish Britax would produce ALL of their seats in the USA. Bottom line if you are looking for a booster seat, get this one you will not regret it!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster seat, backless booster
Weight Range of Child: 5 1/2, 48 inches, 47 lbs
Installation Type: latch
Harness Type: 5 point harness
Material: fabric, thick cushion, padded
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The child car seat should be suitable for children weighing around 47 lbs and approximately 48 inches tall.  
It should be available as a backless booster seat.  
Installation using the LATCH system is acceptable.  
A 5-point harness is desirable.

Review:
We have been using this car seat for the last five months. I ordered this when my daughter was 10 months old and was getting too heavy for the carrier in the Graco Click Connect travel system. She loved the transition. I like that we will be able to use it long-term and it will grow and adjust with her, while rear-facing and front-facing.

I absolutely adore this car seat. My daughter falls asleep in it within minutes of being put in the car. We are doing extended rear-facing. My state requires to rear-face until 1, but we are waiting as long as we can (at least 2, but trying to until 4, depending on her height and weight by then). Usually while rear-facing, the seats are horrible to install and adjust. I have a Graco (this one) and Safety 1st for our vehicles. My mom has an Evenflo. My dad bought a Cosco. The Graco ComfortSport was, by far, the easiest to install and adjust. The Evenflo is the worst. We all use the Latch system in our vehicles.

It is easy to install, easy to move of switching vehicles, very easy to adjust.
