Seat Type: rear-facing, front-facing
Weight Range of Child: depending on her height and weight
Installation Type: Latch system
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat can be used in both rear-facing and front-facing configurations.
The car seat accommodates the child's specific height and weight.
The car seat is installed using the Latch system.

Review: Let me start off by saying, I'm a mom of 16 month old twins and I love these car seats!  I have two of them and for the price, they can't be beat!  My family is on a very tight budget and when it was time to upgrade from the infant carriers to a forward-facing seat, I had some very specific requirements in mind: price, comfort, ability to grow with child, and safety ratings.  Now obviously there are some great car seats on the market, such as Britax, but these seats also cost twice as much ($200-$300), and I could not afford to spend $400 on car seats.  After much research, including going to a local baby store and comparing the padding, weight, etc., these seemed like the best choice.  Not only are they very reasonable in price, but compared to some of the other brands in the same price range (Safety 1st), this was WAY better!  Not only is the cushioning much thicker, but the seat seems roomy and has plenty of room to grow with my boys.  An added bonus is that as long as we don't get into an accident, I can potentially use these seats until the boys are completely out of booster seats (10 years old).  The safety ratings on these seats are pretty good too from places like Consumer Report.  One complaint I've seen in other reviews is that these seats are not at a great angle for your child to sleep, however, I can report that my twins sleep in them all the time and their heads just seem to fall to the side and not at any awkward angles.  Now that I'm going back to work, I will be investing in two more of these seats for our second car, to get the boys to and from daycare.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: forward-facing
Weight Range of Child: until the boys are completely out of booster seats (10 years old)
Material: cushioning much thicker
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The child car seat should be forward-facing.  
The child car seat should accommodate children until they are completely out of booster seats, such as up to 10 years old.  
The child car seat should have thicker cushioning.

Review:
I purchased this seat in Fall 2012 and it now comes with a rear-facing tether strap and instructions on how to use it in the manual. I'm able to get it very secure rear-facing, in the center seat of my Honda Civic, with no pool noodle, and room for 2 passengers. Driver and front passenger seats can still go back because the seat is narrow. I love this seat, the only con for us is that it's not too tall, so my tall son will likely outgrow it in height before he reaches the rear-facing weight limit, but I think he'll still be able to use this rear-facing until at least age 2. Installation is a snap with the seat belt and the seat is very comfortable, apparently. My son falls asleep in here all the time, even on 5-minute car rides :)

We purchased an infant car seat when he was born, the Chicco key fit 30, because other parents told me I'd want to be able to remove him from the car in the seat while he was asleep. I guess that was convenient for the first 3-4 months, as sometimes he would continue his nap in the car seat once we got home, or sleep in the car seat in a restaurant, etc. However, the key fit 30 is wide because of the handle, and did not fit nearly as well in my 2007 civic. It was do-able, but the front seats couldn't go back very far, which was an issue for my 6'4" husband. Plus, the key fit is a small seat - my son has outgrown it in height and he's only 11 months and 22 pounds (he has a huge head, though, so most won't have this problem, LOL). And, once your baby weighs over 15 pounds, you're not going to want to carry them in an infant carrier. I don't care how strong you are, it's just not ergonomic.

So, if you're looking for a great car seat that's smaller, but still very safe and well-made, consider just getting this one, you'll save yourself money and I don't think infant seats are really worth it. If and when we have another kid, I'll be using this seat from the start.

A couple other minor points - the seat is really soft/padded - this is a plus. It has a nice cushion over the crotch strap, which I like for my little dude :) The crotch strap releases by pressing on the top, which I like now, but might be an issue if my son decides he wants to escape some day. We have another seat that requires you to press a button inward to release the straps - this requires you to put a finger behind it to get some leverage, which is awkward. I don't mind the puzzle fit of the strap latch - you get used to it fast. It's really easy to tighten the straps. It's also easy to remove the cover to clean it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear-facing
Weight Range of Child: rear-facing weight limit
Installation Type: seat belt
Material: soft/padded, cushion over the crotch strap, easy to remove the cover to clean it
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The seat should be rear-facing to accommodate the child's weight range. It should be easy to install using the vehicle's seat belt. The materials should be soft and padded, with a cushion over the crotch strap for comfort. The cover should be easy to remove for cleaning.

The design of the car seat cover is very poor in containing the mess and stuff oozes out from the gaps in the side to dirty the rest of the car. Also it is extremely complicated to put this seat back together after it is dismantled for thorough cleaning. They need to improve the design of the car seat cover so that no mess escapes through the sides and leaks into the interior portions of the car seat and base. Then it would save us the frustration of having to disassemble and put this thing back together again each time.

Review: I returned this car seat for a few reasons.  Although I loved the seat for its size and style, I hated the seat padding.  It had lots of open seams that would velcro together where the seat back met the seat base, and of course after I put my son in and out of the chair a few times they started to come apart leaving him with no padding to sit on but just the hard plastic.  I also did not like the infinite slide harness, that too also left empty space between my sons head and the seat because there was nothing to close up the open seams where the harness slides up and down.  It's a bummer for me, I had an Evenflo Triumph for my older son when he was a baby and absolutely loved it, but this new version I will have to pass.

Review:
I just bought this car seat today and our son spent 8 hours in it throughout the day, and love is not a strong enough word. Our son was in a Chicco KeyFit30 as an infant and then an Evenflo Symphony until he was 3 1/2, at which point we bought him the Evenflo Securekid. The Securekid fit our needs at the time of being much more narrow than the Symphony and allowing an adult to sit in between two car seats in the back seat, however, it had one huge down side for our family. The moment that our son fell asleep his head would drop dramatically to the side. He was only able to sleep for 20-30 minutes and would wake up screaming.

We had done extensive research and decided to spend the money and replace the SecureKid with the Nautilus today before traveling for a wedding. It was worth every penny. Our son is now 5, 52 lbs and 46" and he loves his new car seat. He took an hour and a half nap in his car seat today, which hasn't happened in almost 2 years. He then slept in his Nautilus for 3 hours while we traveled home after his bedtime. It is comfortable. Safe. and the front recline allows a bigger child to sleep comfortably when just tuckered out or traveling after their bed time.

Review:
We didn't purchase ours from Amazon, but I got it at Target. It was a bit of an emergency, as we'd had a Maxi-Cosi Pria 70 that we discovered was a defective product and couldn't be used safely anymore, so we needed a new seat ASAP.

I am so, so, so happy with this purchase. This thing is built like a tank. It means it's a fairly heavy seat, but that doesn't bother me. It takes up less room front-to-back than the Pria did, and the install is insanely easy (especially compared to the Pria). It's so easy to get a rock solid, perfect install on this with no wiggling--I love that.

The fabric is high quality and is actually quite cool in the summer. We have had a little bit of issue with tightening the straps, as mentioned, but it's gotten better with time, and I did learn to pull the strap hugs down a bit before which helps. My son is really comfortable, and is still rear-facing at 14 months (and has plenty of room to continue doing so for a long time to come).

I will absolutely buy a second NextFit for our next child!

Review:
We got this seat for an amazing price through Amazon's lightning deals. We had been eyeing it for a long time and when we saw it on a lightning deal we finally snagged it up.

We were very happy with it at first, before we actually used it. We got our baby in and out of it easily while it was inside our house, but once it was in the car it was a whole other story.

(1) This seat is huge. We have a Nissan Rogue, and with the carseat in the second position rear facing it was touching the back of the front seats. It's also very wide. The base is narrow, but it fans out wider at the seat area and it literally made it so I couldn't sit in the back with my baby anymore when we had her in the middle.
(2) It is so difficult to tighten the harness! Way, way too difficult. We pride ourselves on proper car seat safety, so I am never willing to compromise when it comes to how tight a harness is or where the chest clip rests. When this seat was not in the car, we didn't have any issues getting it tight enough, but for some reason when it was in the car it was nearly impossible to get it right. I would literally spend 2 or 3 minutes tugging on it, trying to tighten it. Very frustrating.
(3) Installation is a joke. I have never had such trouble installing a carseat before. The path for the seat belt is awful -- it took both my husband and me to get it through the path. We ultimately decided on using the lower anchors, but were really disappointed that we couldn't get the seat belt install tight enough.

My baby (8 months) did enjoy sitting in it, which is why I'm not giving this 1 star. We knew she was getting fed up with not being able to see much while in the car, so we switched from her infant seat to a convertible. She looked comfortable in it and she was super happy the whole time.

We ended up returning this carseat, which is a bummer because, like I said, we got an amazing deal on it. I read the majority of the reviews before we bought it, so I'm really disappointed that it didn't work out for us because it is so highly rated. We switched to the Britax Boulevard Clicktight -- much more expensive, but we tested it out in our car at one of the baby stores, and it is a dream to use, especially in comparison to this one.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Harness Type: difficult to tighten
Installation Type: lower anchors, seat belt
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat should be convertible to accommodate different stages of a child's growth.  
It is acceptable if tightening the harness is sometimes difficult.  
The car seat should be installable using lower anchors or a seat belt.

Review:
We purchased a Diono Radian RXT in 2018 because we wanted to buy a car seat with high safety standards. We installed and used it exactly according to the instruction manual, and used it in normal city driving conditions. The other week, we noticed that the "headwings" that are supposed to protect your child's head from side impact had slid down from their adjusted height and were pressing into our toddler son's shoulders. We had not lowered the headwings at all, but they had slipped to the lowest setting. We adjusted the headwings again to their proper height, and over the course of a week under normal driving conditions, the headwings again slipped down and pressed into our son's shoulders.

We contacted Diono "Customer Care" and sent them a video of our issue. We were told that the steel plates in the seat can wear down over time and that is what was causing the headwings to slip down. We were offered a DIY "remedy kit" and told that we could try to fix the problem ourselves. Unbelievable. Not only were we told that we had to repair what is clearly a manufacturing defect ourselves, but moreover, they did not currently have this so-called "remedy kit" in stock at the moment and that we should use a "back-up car seat" while we wait for this DIY "remedy kit."

We told the Diono Customer Care rep that we did not think it was appropriate to put the responsibility of fixing a manufacturing defect onto the customer who does not have any kind of formal training in car seat repair. This is the kind of thing that should be handled by an experienced Diono technician. We told them that we did not feel comfortable with altering the car seat ourselves and "hoping" that we did it correctly. We asked them to either replace our car seat with a new one or pay for the shipping so that we could send it to them for repair. The Customer Care rep said she would have to talk to her "supervisor's supervisor" and that she would call us back. She called us back and informed us that since our car seat is out of the one-year warranty window, they would not send us a new car seat, even though the problem we are experiencing is due to a manufacturing defect and/or design flaw and their choice of weak steel.

Our car seat is barely two years old. We used it exactly according to the instructions. This company boasts that their seats can last up to 10 years, but will not even fix a manufacturing issue themselves.

We look up Diono on the Better Business Bureau and there are similar complaints to ours. This is not a small cosmetic defect but a major flaw of a safety component that is supposed to protect your child's brain side impact in the event of an accident. The fact that they offered a DIY "remedy kit" to try ourselves at home to correct this issue in addition to reading about similar complaints from other Diono seat owners leads me to believe that this is not an isolated issue but serious design flaw that the company is trying to pass off onto the customer. They never issued a recall, or sent out any alert to the Radian RXT owners of this flaw. It seems that Diono has known about the flaw enough to produce these so-called "remedy kits" but did nothing to alert the owners. Rather, they have stayed silent and in doing so have willfully endangered children who use their car seats.

DIONO DOES NOT CARE ABOUT CHILD SAFETY AT ALL. Given the response of the customer care team, it is clear what the company's priorities are. They would rather risk the safety of your child than offer you a properly functioning car seat or even have a technician fix it at their expense. This company only cares about their bottom line, not the actual work of protecting children.

DO NOT TRUST DIONO with your child's safety. They have no problem with you using defective car seats and will not alert you of possible malfunctions. When your car seat does malfunction due to their manufacturing/design flaws, they will not send you a replacement or offer any help in fixing it themselves. I will never purchase anything from them ever again and will be alerting other parents of not only their horrible customer service but also their willful neglect of child safety.

Seat Type: Forward Facing
Material: steel plates
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat should be forward facing.  
The car seat should be made with steel plates.

Review: I have owned this car seat for almost a year.  It does its job in keeping my child safe and keeping him comfortable in long car rides.  However, one of the reasons I bought this seat was because the cover is removable and can be washed in the washing machine.  I have had to do that three times now, and every time the foam padding in the cover gets so wadded up and distorted that I have to rip out the seams for the 6 or 7 different panels, fix the foam padding, and then sew them back together.  It wouldn't be that bad except there are three different layers that need to be sewn together, and it is very easy to miss one of the layers in the process, leaving a gaping hole after you think you have finished.  If you plan on never having to wash your car seat cover, then this is a good car seat.  But if you do think you'll need to wash it, skip this one.

Review:
Product Review: This inflatable booster worked great for us! My husband was quite skeptical but we both thought it was perfect, especially for traveling. My daughter is 6 but quite slim, and since she just clicked over the 40-lb. weight minimum for boosters, she is still in a convertible booster with a 5-point harness because I believe it's safer and she doesn't complain so why not? However, we recently took an airplane trip and since we already had to travel with my younger son's carseat, we did not want to lug 2 full sized seats through airports. We decided since driving on our trip would be minimal once we got to our destination, to go with this booster. I'm so glad we did. It inflates and deflates like a breeze. It rolls up and fit in my daughter's backpack until we needed it. It was easy for her to use, comfortable to sit on, and the belt guides were easy to use and kept the seatbelt perfectly placed on her shoulder.

It will be perfect to keep in my car to use when we have an unexpected friend ride along with us because it's small and will fit nicely in the middle seat between our two very large Britax convertible seats, which hard boosters probably would not. I'd purchase again without hesitation.

Warehouse Seller Review: I ordered this item as New/Like New from Amazon Warehouse Deals. We received it in a torn and re-taped box (as expected) but sadly the item had clearly been used. It had food (?) crumbs all on it, along with a large amount of dog hair. So, we returned it and since we needed it right away, we bought the same item at Walmart for almost the exact same price.

Review:
So far we love the car seat. My daughter has been using it for about a week. This included one long trip to an out of town doctor. She enjoys being able to look around and see out the windows. Everything amazes her since she could see that well from her previous car seat.

My daughter is almost two and actually has long legs and she has plenty of leg room now (and we don't even have it set to have has much leg room as this car seat can give of course). In her old carseat she propped her legs up on the back of the seat.

The car seat sits very securely rearfacing. It doesn't seem unsturdy at all. I have Dodge Grand Caravan and it's in one of the middle seats. In a smaller vehicle I could see issues with this car seat not fitting, though. It fits snuggly in my van.

It can be an issue to get her to sit up straight to fasten her in, though and if she isn't sitting up straight then she has that issue of her chin being tucked into her chest that other people have complained about in reviews. She doesn't seem to mind it but I feel like it is safer for her to be sitting up straight when fastened in.

The only negative and the reason I am giving it four stars instead of five is because she can't sleep fall asleep easily in it. She DOES fall asleep and is able to sleep okay in it but it takes her a bit to figure out ways to sleep and she has to be extremely sleepy to do it. I do believe that this would be an issue with almost any up right car seat though. She was use to her reclining baby seat. So, this is just different.

Oh and it did take my husband a little while to install it but he was able to get it installed securely and without getting annoyed with it. So, it must not have been to bad.

My daughter is special needs and has a weak spine and weak muscles. She needs to rear face as long as possible as it will take her longer to get strength in her neck and spine. So, I chose this car seat for its ability to rear face to 50lbs. And for that I do love it.

Final consensus is that it's safe and my daughter likes it. So, while I wish she could sleep (and drink her bottle) easier in it overall it's very worth the money and we will likely be purchasing another one of these for our next baby.

Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

I think part of the problem with the seat my daughter uses this seat in is the seat in the back dips down so this I fold actually sits perfectly into the lower dipped part of the seat - making it more level/flat.

Review:
We purchased this seat specifically for traveling because it is lightweight, has great safety ratings and is FAA approved. The seat itself is fine and worked great in the vehicle, however using it on the airplane was not fun! The buckle from the airplane seat sits right in the small of the back, we didn't realize it on the first flight, our daughter was complaining how bad her back hurt when we landed. When we looked at her back it was bright red and eventually became bruised. On our next flights we took off the pillow of the seat and stuffed it front of the buckle, it still was not enough cushion so we also placed a sweatshirt between the seat and the buckle which did help, but it still puts way too much pressure on the back. I emailed Evenflo and they are aware of the issue and even address it in the manual. This is the response I got and also the statement from the manual

Iâ€™m sorry for the issue you had while using this child restraint on an aircraft. For these reasons, the child restraint instruction manual notes: Because of the fixed length of aircraft seat belts, the belt buckle could be behind the childâ€™s back after tightening the belt. For your childâ€™s comfort, Evenflo recommends cushioning the childâ€™s back by placing a small pillow or folded-up blanket, or a folded-up jacket, over the belt buckle.

We will be getting rid of this seat and finding a new one. I was disappointed that this is a known issue with no other resolution.

Installation Type: Seat Belt
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

Review:
I have three kids so I have a lot of experience with car seats. From Britax to Graco to Chicco to Baby Jogger to now Maxi-Cosi. So far the Chicco Zip convertible is my favorite but this is a close second. My 3 year old primarily uses this car seat and so far he seems to like it a lot. It looks super comfortable and my son has not complained about it at all. The quality of the seat is pretty good and it was very simple to install. Probably took 10 minutes for the initial set up. My only complaint is how easily the harness gets twisted. This is a common issue with car seats but several manufacturers have figured out ways to prevent this. Maxi-Cosi is not one of those companies. That being said, I can highly recommend this car seat.

Review:
I purchased this infant seat for my second child, and I wish I had it for my first! I think you would be hard pressed to find a better car seat in this price category (especially if purchased with an Amazon Prime registry discount). Iâ€™ll just say that with our first we used the seat and base that came with our graco stroller travel system, and it was a pain to use. The base did not adjust, so we had to use a pool noodle underneath one side. The straps did not have the front pull to tighten and had to be manually adjusted in the back (for each time we were putting our son in and out of the seat!). The infant insert was useless and we used rolled up blankets around his head instead. The handle required both hands to adjust. We still used it until we upgraded to a convertible seat around 9-10 months, but it was annoying every time. This time around I was determined to get something nicer.

This seat is the opposite of all those things and more! The handle requires one hand to raise and lower, the straps loosen and tighten with ease, the fabric itself is comfortable and supportive, and the base is adjustable to get the seat perfectly level. The canopy is also lovely and makes this seat look high end. It works with our old stroller too, which is a plus! I guess I didnâ€™t know what we were missing out on before. I scoped out a lot of infant seats before I purchased this one, and hands down, for the price point, this is a fantastic choice and I am very happy.

Review: I did a lot of research before purchasing this convertible car seat a year ago.  Safe, good reviews - I was sold.  One year later I am so fed up with this car seat that I'm buying a new one.  It's extremely frustrating considering how much this cost.  My issue is the straps will NOT release consistently.  You might get one side 1 out of 10 times.  The rest  of the time you're just struggling to get everything undone and your child out.  Getting him back in is even harder!  I try releasing the straps with him in, I try releasing them with him out, I try releasing them one at a time.  Nope.  I end up having to jam the buckle in with my son in the car seat, making it extremely uncomfortable for him and for me, since I have to spend minutes trying to get it to buckle since the straps won't release properly!  I contacted Britax but they would not replace this carseat even though something is obviously wrong.  So I will say good bye to you Britax USA Advocate ClickTight, and I will celebrate not dreading every single time I have to put my son in a carseat.

Review:
I absolutely LOVE this carseat. I purchased this for my two year old, as her other car seat, although convertible, she was outgrowing. It took me a minute to read the directions to make the proper adjustments and depending on how you secure it (seatbelt or latch/front facing or rear facing) it can be a challenge to secure. Once it IS secure, the seat is very nice to use. What I like most is the weight limit and it will be the last car seat that I will have to purchase because it is convertible. On the other hand, it initially was a pain to clean and I had to watch a You Tube video on how to dismantle it and clean it best. Once I watched and did it, I had no problems repeating the process. This seat is as heavy as any other convertible seat, there's no advantage in that regard, but my daughter seems to really like the attached cup holders and side pockets for her toys.

The only other thing, is that I found the buckle a little hard to disengage. I have rheumatoid arthritis which has hindered my dexterity, so it has taken me a while to figure out an easy way to disengage the buckle. Because of the way the seat is designed, I definitely suggest that the seat is checked by someone certified to ensure that the height is correct and that the crotch buckle is in the proper position since it can be modified. I also appreciate that the potty training seat covers fit very well in this seat, regardless of brand. Overall, it's a really beautiful seat and I'm glad that I purchased it.

Review: This does NOT fit 5 pound babies. I know because after hours of research in preparation for our new child I bought three of these because they fit the best in our car because of their slim build. When I went to install them the only instructions were in 5 foreign languages, but none in English. I figured it out eventually though. Today we prepared to leave the hospital, and even with the straps as tight as possible our almost 8 pound little girl was not secure at all. We had to leave mom and the baby in the hospital while I ran to wal mart to buy ome of the car seats we were trying to avoid buying because at that point I had no other option. What if I weren't in the position to go buy another car seat? What if the added stress caused complications for the mother (who already just went through so much)?  You guys need to change this and advertise correctly. I'm very pissed off about my purchase and I'll be looking for another car seat with ratings from a company that hasn't already broken my trust, because safety is really important to me and I can't believe that your products are safe any more.

Review:
Well I was super stoked about these as our 7mo has grown out of his infant carrier. However, we cannot get them to tilt back enough in the rear facing position. We tried the usual tricks of using pool noodles, rolled up towels, etc and we took it to a certified car seat installer and she ran out of ideas. We are using the infant insert too, but it doesn't help. So, his head slumps far forward when he falls asleep. Bummer.

Other than that the seat is super sturdy, stays cool in the heat (we live in Texas where it is 100 degrees right now) and it is easy to use. Baby loves it when he is awake but I worry about him sleeping in it since his airway is pinched.

At this point we will be keeping the seat because we have had it a couple of weeks since we were testing install for so long and had multiple people looking at it but I might've done more research to make sure it could recline the recommended amount.

Oh and the photo example is before we used the insert and I will say it is slightly better, but the issue still isn't fixed. Considering getting another insert to support his head - the infant cradle product - to see if that helps.

Review: I have had this carseat for five years now and have used it for two children.  And it's ok.  My children are still alive after driving all over the country  in it, so I like that.  But it is HUGE!  I have a Honda Odyssey and have this seat and a high back booster on the back row.  A normal sized adult cannot sit between them and only most of the time can I fit a third carseat.  Really it's the useless armrests that do it in.  Neither one of my children have ever used them--their little arms aren't long enough to reach them.  And the cupholder.  It's just stuck to the side of the seat and is pretty flimsy and takes up even more room.  It doesn't hold cups--they just flop out and makes it impossible to have a third person on my back row so we just took the seat out, end of story.  It's ok.  Like I said, I've used it continuously for five years and haven't felt the need to replace it, but I'm now looking for a second convertable seat for baby #3 and will not be purchasing another one of these.

Review: I own 5 of these Britax Boulevards; 2 are in my car, 2 in my husband's and 1 in grandma's.  I've loved all of the Boulevards except the G3 that's being used for my one year old in my car.  I can't say how much I hate this seat.  It is so so so difficult to adjust the straps.  I also think I have a defective car seat.  One of the straps keeps falling off of my one year old's shoulder.  She used to be rear facing so we had the straps below shoulder level as advised by Britax.  Due to this issue, we turned the car seat to face forward and moved up the straps above her shoulders as advised.  The strap still keeps falling off of her shoulder.  I've tried adjusting it to different lengths and I think the slot where the strap comes through may not be aligned correctly (manufacturer's defect).  I contacted Britax but that was two weeks ago and I have not heard back from them.  You'd think after investing over a $1000 in this company's products, you deserve a response.  Anyway, dealing with this car seat has been such a nightmare.  I may have bought the "safest" car seat but I don't think my child is safe in it.  We'll either get another car seat or switch it with one of the others but we still have one with a huge issue.

Review: I have had the car seat for almost 6 months now.  We bit the bullet and bought 2, 1 for each vehicle.  They are not cheap and I feel fortunate we were able to afford them - but being able to keep our 4 year old son as safe as possible was all I needed.  Super easy to install, easy adjustable headrest, and the ability to keep him in a 5-Point harness longer than any other car seat was the final selling standpoint.  He is 4 years old, 35lbs and tall.  Being able to keep him in the 5-point harness system doesn't faze him - it's what he's used to. Hands down best investment we made for the safety of our son.

Review:
Prior to this car seat I had an infant car seat - Graco snugride 30. My son NEVER liked riding in the car. A big problem as we do a 3 hour drive every Friday and Sunday night. It was very painful. We tried everything - even breast feeding him IN the car seat while driving down the highway - We were starting to think we had to stay home all the time. The closest we ever came to a nice ride was if he was in the front seat with the airbag off - not ideal.

A more experienced mom suggested I look into a convertible seat. Another experienced parent suggested Britax. I took my son to Baby r Us and sat him in every single car seat. I tried to pay attention to angle and cushion and how he responded. He seemed happy in this one. My 5 month old is quick to let you know when he is not comfortable.

He also liked another popular brand so we had to choose. This one just looked nicer. It seemed more low key then the sticker filled second choice

This car seat was easy to install, angled nicely for a baby with reflux and for the first time we drove home Sunday night with no baby screaming, no stops on the highway to cuddle and calm him down. He still fusses a bit in the car but once he gets comfortable he is happy and acts like a normal baby is suppose to and falls asleep!

We have only had this car seat for a weekend but already I think it is worth every penny we paid for it!

I did purchase a mirror and a sun shade - I think that is needed when you lose the ability to pull the cover on the infant seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: convertible seat
Installation Type: easy to install
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat is easy to install.

Review:
So Iâ€™d like to give this car seat a fair review. Weâ€™ve purchased two of them and there are some amazing pros but also some horrible cons that make me regret ever buying these very expensive car seats, that I am now stuck with FOREVER.

Pros
1. Super easy to install
2. Very easy to adjust as child grows

Cons
1. IMPOSSIBLE to actually clean when you have a messy child.

Let me explain. My three year old son has had this seat for a year and a half. Trying to take the car seat pad off is an adventure in and of itself. You need a YouTube video just to figure it out. But thatâ€™s not even the worst part.

Thereâ€™s no way to clean up a big mess. It seeps down into the actual car seat which you canâ€™t disassemble to clean or fix. My son peed on his by accident. He was asleep and woke himself up by peeing. I cleaned the pad and even sprayed down the seat, because it had pee all down in it. Thank goodness I donâ€™t keep my manual where they suggest or it would have had urine on it as well. The manufacturer suggests that you spot clean or just wash the pad. But that does nothing if the mess is all the way down into the seat. They even say you shouldnâ€™t spray down the seat, but I canâ€™t exactly leave pee sloshing around in it now can I.
So spray it I did, which then water gets in it. Oh the predicament. But water is better than pee right.

Scenario two. My youngest daughter puked on hers. No big deal itâ€™s mostly on the pad and thatâ€™s washable. You know whatâ€™s not washable, the super high tech straps. First you canâ€™t get them off the seat. So you have to bring the whole seat to the bath, use a bowl of water etc to clean those bad boys. Your supposed to just spot clean those. But that doesnâ€™t really take the puke smell out. So you can incorrectly wash it with some type of chemical and worry that youâ€™ve destroyed the strap or you can live with puke smell. Neither are a good option in my opinion.

Now Iâ€™ve only had to clean these a few times but each time has made me want to pull my hair out.

So mommas save yourself the headache and buy a different seat. Because I donâ€™t know to many kids who arenâ€™t messy and you donâ€™t want to keep their mess FOREVER.

Graco please redesign these seats with children in mind. They spill, pee, puke etc all over their seats sometimes multiple times in a week. Make it easy for the mom to clean it up, being a mom is hard enough already without car seats that cause more trouble than they are worth.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Super easy to install
Harness Type: the super high tech straps, you canâ€™t get them off the seat, Your supposed to just spot clean those
Material: Trying to take the car seat pad off, Thereâ€™s no way to clean up a big mess, It seeps down into the actual car seat which you canâ€™t disassemble to clean, I cleaned the pad, just wash the pad, the pad and thatâ€™s washable
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat needs to be easy to install. The harness straps need to be secure and designed for spot cleaning only. It is acceptable that the seat pad is removable and washable, while the main seat structure cannot be disassembled for cleaning, even if spills can seep into it.

Review:
I bought this car seat in 2012 after reading the excellent reviews. I am sorry to say that I absolutely hate this car seat.

1) Its difficult to remove and attach across cars and I always have to have my husband do it. The hooks in the back are so tight that I can never remove them. I don't have problems with the car seat of my friends when we car pool etc. My husband complains too when he has to remove or install since I insisted on getting this car seat.
2) My daughter is thin and petite but putting the buckles is always a problem. I always fear that I am going to pinch her on the thighs when putting the buckles as I have done it a couple of times. When she is wearing bulky clothes during winter its a PAIN!!
3) When my daughter falls asleep in the car seat, her head falls in front even though I have the car seat tilted (Front facing). I wish the headrest could be adjusted in such a way that her head could rest on it. This is not a problem on short drives but longer drives I don't want her sleeping like that. I have been buying all kinds of pillow head rest things for her.

I wish I had returned it when I could.

Review: Like many of the other reviewers we also own a Britax Marathon. Love it...not one complaint. We were looking for a backup carseat for our Cherokee and thought this would be great since we do plan on having other children. We figured we could just move our daughter into this seat and put the new baby in her Marathon. At first, she was thrilled over the cupholders and storage compartmets in the armrest. This new seat excitement quickly diminished during our first car ride of maybe 20 minutes. We immediatly noticed her struggling to get comfortable pushing on the armrest trying to force the headrest back. We thought maybe it would just take some getting used to so we kept the seat. She still hates it and fusses alot (9 months later). If she does happen to fall asleep her chin is resting on her chest which never happens in the Britax. Wish we had returned the seat. Glad it's only a backup. If you truly want comfort and safety fork over the dough for the Best Britax you can aford.

Review:
I saw the designer give a presentation for this seat at a Child Passenger Safety Conference and decided to give it a try. I bought one as a test seat for our 2 children who still need seatbelt adjustment. Our intention was to buy another if it worked for both kids as we have a smaller back seat and the space saving design was a huge bonus for us and their older brother who has been cramped by several booster seat trials. We have 2 very different sized children: a wirey boy, age 10, 4'4", 65 lbs; and a tough as bricks girl, age 6, 3'4â€, 70 lbs
What we determined:
This is a great seat for my small framed 10 year old. He loves that he is not in a little kid booster seat and I love that he is being protected. He also loves that he has more padding in the seat than his previous booster seat. Long rides were always a struggle as he begged to stop frequently to get a break from his previous seat.
However, our 6 year old, who is built differently, weighing more and with a wider hips, hated this seat. She complained that the plastic, adjustable sides pinched her and she really struggled with getting the seatbelt threaded correctly.
Overall, we are pleased with the purchase and will continue to use the Mifold for our son as long as we can.

Weight Range of Child: 65 lbs, 70 lbs
Material: plastic, padding

Review: I just recently bought this carseat and I couldn't be happier!!! I wanted to get the BEST and SAFEST carseat for my daughter and I am SO glad there was the sale cause it made the price drop just low enough for me to convince my fiance that it was worth the price lol.  It was SO easy to install (into our 01 Jeep Grand Cherokee, rear facing in middle).  It fits fine and very securly, I was worried that it would be too big.  It actually fits better on the seat than our Graco snugride (the snugride was too skinny and leaned into the crack of the seats, this seat has a wide enough base to be stable over the crack!  I am so glad I got this car seat my daughter loves it, shes fallen asleep in it already! I am a little disappointed with the pattern it looks different in person than online, but the safety is what I really care about! About the size it is a little big like I have one of those fisher price mirror things and I cant see her in it from the drivers seat but I can from the passenger seat, but I leave the mirror where it is cause she enjoys looking in it lol.  I am VERY happy with this car seat!!!! I feel that my baby is protected! Shes only 9 months old and still fit in her infant carrier but rarely took the carseat out of the car I just took her out so I figured it was time to get a better carseat.  Another big reason I chose this carseat (and a selling point to my fiance lol) was that it will last her a long time!!!! The only bad thing I can say is that I accidentally cut off the user guide, I didnt know you were supposed to keep it on there lol, oh well lol. GREAT CAR SEAT!!! WORTH THE MONEY TO PROTECT YOUR BABY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Review:
We chose this model for the compact fold/straps because we were planning plane travel with driving on the other end for our 5yo who is not mature enough for a bottom seat only booster for any significant distance.

The fold is great and compact. The provided straps are just webbing, and There was no way weâ€™d use them for more than a minute. I found some clip on backpack straps on Amazon that were more comfortable, but it sits at an awkward angle. Youâ€™re better off using some bungee cords to strap it to the handle of rolling luggage if youâ€™re going very far.

We gate checked it for our flights but you may be able to put it in an overhead bin.

Since the back does not detach, itâ€™s easy to quickly install and remove from an Uber. I had trouble getting the isofix latch connectors to work in one Uber (Toyota sienna, I believe) but it was a short ride so we went without them completely attached.

We also like that the sides of this seat expand like the other Monterey models because my son is tall with a long and wide torso and would likely have cramped shoulders by the time he ages out of a standard booster seat. What I didnâ€™t realize until we got it is that the width expands as you raise the headrest, not independently like the other models.

Overall we like it but unless youâ€™re planning some travel that includes Ubers and/or flights where youâ€™ll rent a car or ride with family/friends on the other end, save your $$. We have the $100 XT model in our other car and it functions just as well if youâ€™re installing it once and leaving it there (and it still has the expandable back panel). If your child is average height/weight/build, you can pick something even cheaper.

Special Features: Super Easy, Car Rental inflatable packable portable luggage travel
Review:
Let me start off by saying I have a love/hate relationship with car seats. I have 5 children, the oldest one is 7, so collectively, I probably have been through 30 car seats in less than a decade. My daughter has been ready to graduate to a booster seat for 2+ years now, but unfortunately, due to her parents procreation habits, she's been relegated to life in a 5-point harness for lack of space. It baffles me that mini-van manufacturers don't consider the fact that you may have kids in car seats. Sure it's great Herb and Ethel sport their Chrysler Town & Country with their teacup poodle Miffy, but we use the heck out of our minivan. So, when the twins showed up, the three bigs got kicked to the back of the bus and we panicked trying to cram three full seats in the back row. Thanks to Radian (and $1000), we didn't have to buy a conversion van. So, after squeezing every moment out of the "baby" seat, I had to find a narrow booster. Our standard graco booster had birthing hips like my wife, and just didn't squeeze in the back. Enter, Bubble Bum. The name and concept are ridiculous, but, by golly, the thing actually works perfect. I was EXTREMELY skeptical about a blow up seat. Sure we want our children to live in a bubble, but to actually sit on one? Low and behold, It fits her narrow booty perfectly and she's now all proud sporting a booster seat. Granted, there are no frills to this thing. No cup holder, no secret pockets, no fun stuff, just base model solidness.
We've had it probably a month and it's still inflated, and working great. Thankfully we haven't done any crash testing in it, so I can't validate it's safety. Hopefully, I'll never have to update my comment about the crash sturdiness. Paranoia, I looked online and sites claimed it was safety checked and legit. Now that school is starting back up, kid #1 is begging to be promoted in dad's car as well to a booster. So, buying a second Bubble Bum.
Only negative thing I would say is my daughter complains the seat is "itchy" around the logo. It is raised, and when she wears skirts or daisy dukes, she complained of scratching. So, we improvised and she put a wash cloth on the seat. I'm glad I didn't pay extra for kittens or something pretty on the seat only to have a dirty rag covering it. Otherwise, works great. If you're tight on space, it's definitely the seat for you. I have one in our Odyssey and soon one in an Avalon (adjacent to two Radians).
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster seat
Weight Range of Child: ready to graduate to a booster seat for 2+ years
Material: itchy around the logo, raised logo, wash cloth on the seat
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should be comfortable for extended use without causing skin irritation. It should accommodate children who are ready to transition to a booster seat for over two years. The materials should be smooth and non-abrasive, with no raised or rough elements that cause discomfort. The seat should be easy to clean and maintain.

Review:
This car seat is pretty great and fits rear facing in the back of my Honda Fit, which was my main requirement. The cupholder is great to have. I would never buy a seat without one now. The cushions are very snug and seem comfortable.

My biggest complaint is the seat belt straps. They get twisted easily, which is annoying. The strap can also be difficult to pull tight. You have to pull really hard to get it tight. Even my husband complains that he can't pull hard enough to get the straps tight. Even more annoying is the fact that when I pull to tighten the straps, sometimes both of the shoulder straps don't tighten! Often, just one side tightens and then the other just remains loose. I try to pull back slack from the tighter one to get them even, but it is very difficult and doesn't always work. I don't want to risk my child's safety by leaving the strap loose, so it's frustrating to have to sit there and mess with it over and over to get it right (especially if I'm standing outside in the rain or freezing cold or in a hurry, etc.) I own two of this exact car seat, so I know it is just not a fluke with my first one.

All this being said, I do really like this car seat. I just wish the strap situation would be fixed in future models.

Seat Type: Rear Facing
Harness Type: seat belt straps, shoulder straps
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The child car seat should be rear facing.  
The child car seat should use seat belt straps and shoulder straps for the harness.

Review: We've had this seat for about 3 years now.  The seat is great in almost every way.  The materials are nice, the 5-point harness is easy to tighten and loosen, and the cup holders are a nice feature.  The 3-stars are for the AWFUL latch loosening system!  Tightening the car seat down is easy enough.  Just clip in and pull.  But if you want to take the thing out, prepare to shrink your hands, and gain Hulk-like strength, because you basically have to apply outward pressure to loosen it without anything to brace the mechanism against.  So you're basically using the belt tension to try to pry off the buckle to loosen the belt.  Imagine trying to remove a nail from a board that flexes away from your hammer every time you pull.  Redesign the latch system and you've got a 5-star seat.

Review:
Bought this as a travel car seat for my one-and-a-half year old son. We have Graco 4Ever car seats that we use in our vehicles at home, but with five weeks of intense travel this summer (four separate flights, thousands of miles on the road), we needed something much more compact. My main concerns were getting a seat that would be easy to install on a plane, and something compact enough to easily carry through an airport.

Generally this seat did the trick. Installing on the plane wasn't always incredibly easy. Airplane seat belts were at times a bit tough to feed through and would rest right underneath my son's bottom. Sometimes I also couldn't get the belt tight enough, but the seat being wedged between his plane seat and the seat in front of him kept it in place.

It was very easy to install in our rental cars even without all the bells and whistles that our normal Graco seats at home have. Outside of a bit of the struggle on the plane to install the seat, the only other main complaint is no padding around the neck area. At times it seemed like the straps were digging into my son's neck a bit.

But all things considered, the price definitely makes it worth it and you shouldn't expect to get a luxury car seat for this price. It did great for us during summer travels and we'll be sure to use it the next time we fly.

Review:
Very pleased with this seat. Love the extra head support (my toddler does a lot of napping in the car so this was important to me). We've kept our toddler rear facing, and this seat was simple to install using the latch system or the belt path. We previously had an older Recaro, and it was extremely difficult to install rear facing, this Britax is much easier. Straps tighten and loosen easily, and the fabric is soft but seems durable. Another reviewer complained about the large sticker right at their back, but it's not really a sticker, it's made of fabric and doesn't seem to bother my toddler.
We also own the $50 Evenflo Tribute as a spare, and though I believe it would do its job in a wreck as well as any other seat, the Britax is def worth the money in extras. The Evenflo has zero head support, so they slump forward when napping, and the straps require some definite muscle to tighten/loosen, not mention there are no strap covers so if you're not careful you will give your kid a strap burn across their neck. Installation is a pain...even the latch system in the Evenflo sucks. All of these things, in my opinion, make the Britax worth the money.

Review:
We needed to purchase a second car seat and after much research, I came across the Go and Grow 3-in-1 and felt that it would be perfect for our needs. Out of the box, this is a very nice looking car seat and it is very well padded. Those are about the only nice things I can say.
I have several frustrations with this seat, but my main one is that I cannot get the latch to release the seatbelt. It has a round button, not a square one like my Graco seat, but even when using both hands it takes all my might and several attempts to unlatch the belt. Another major issue is tightening and loosening the belt is extremely cumbersome. At one point it took 2 people pulling on the belt to get it tight because the belt seems to keep getting caught. I am afraid that I will hurt my son using such force to tighten and loosen the belt. The chest restraint is also very wide on this, which is an issue for my 17lb baby. It has left marks on his arms because it's wider than his chest. My son also seemed uncomfortable in the seat. He doesn't love being in the car, but he usually doesn't cry the entire time, and every time he's in this seat he cries. Unfortunately, this was not the awesome find that I was hoping it would be and I am returning it for another Graco.

Even until now, I still found his head falling forward after I stopped the car sometimes. The adjustment for the straps in the back didn't bother me too long once I got ised to it. It's quite easy. I would recommend to pay a bit more money to get a more comfortable one for your LO. I am switching to a convertible one sooner because of this.

Review:
We have had this car seat as well as a Graco model for around a year now and wow, what a difference. The straps on the Graco are constantly twisted, the fabric is a pain to get off to wash, and it just feels cheap.

The Britax, however, is wonderful. Excellent safety ratings, the fabric is a breeze to take off for washing, the straps always stay smoothed and therefore don't bother my son, and (minor but nice for us) the slot for the cupholder is under the fabric and isn't always slipping off like the screw-on models for other brands do.

The safety features are why we bought the Britax but the overall ease of use and my son's preference for it is what makes us love it. When it is outgrown, we will definitely be purchasing a Britax replacement!!!

Review:
(Edited on 3/31/2018 to raise the rating from 4 to 5 stars. The lap belt guides do not move in on their own anymore on the newer models!!! A quick recap: this is basically a seatbelt repositioner. A "regular" booster's purpose is to raise the child higher so the seatbelt fits better, and the mifold is a different way of doing it. It may not be the most comfortable seat, but the mifold offers convenience and compactness without sacrificing safety. If the child is too wiggly, this isn't the best product, but then such a child should be in a 5-point harness. Be aware and reasonable about the product's limitations, and you'll be satisfied. You can disregard the below review's portion about the lap belt guides moving in, but I left it in, just so you know there may be different versions.)

******************************
(Original review)
I've been following this product since 2015, participated in the company's crowdfunding and have been eagerly waiting for my mifold to arrive for months. I haven't received that one yet, but imagine my surprise and delight when a mifold showed up in the Vine program, so I quickly grabbed one.

This is such a brilliant concept. The purpose of a traditional booster seat is to raise the child up a few inches so the car's seatbelt, designed to fit an adult, can be safely used by a smaller-sized human - the lap belt should not sit at a child's waist. What the mifold does is to bring down the seatbelt to properly restrain a child. Again, brilliant.

Part of finding a good booster seat involves how well it fits into your car's rearseat design, like the slope, shape, etc... The best booster seat is the one which fits your car properly. Because the seat portion can bend in half, this allows more flexibility in the type of backseats a booster seat can be placed. The mifold is also great for a larger child who sits too high for a booster seat but sits too low for a car's seatbelt during that in-between stage. It's not as if every child needs to be raised up about 4-5 inches for a proper fit.

On the flip side, the mifold may not work as well for shorter children. Since a car's backseat's depth is most likely deeper than the length of a shorter child's upper thighs, the child's legs would be sticking out straight when used properly. Okay, fine, but if the child wants to bend his/her legs at the knees, the child may sit closer to the edge of the backseat, which will make the butt slide farther away from the crease of the back and possibly make the child slouch. Again, depends on the car's backseat and the child.

Then, its size... OH, ITS SIZE!!! If you're short on backseat width and have a smaller child who doesn't need the entire width of a traditional booster seat, the mifold will give you those few precious inches for a better 3-across. For the caretakers of 3 kids who feel like their non-minivans/large SUVs won't accommodate multiple child restraint seats but can't afford to buy a larger vehicle, the mifold may save your budget.

It's a bit heavier than it looks. The seat bottom is rather firm and small - it's a little over 8" by 8" when unfolded. I was concerned this would be too uncomfortable for the occupant, but it wasn't, possibly because a car's rearseat is very cushioned, allowing the mifold to sink into the cushion. An adult weighing a bit over 100lbs tried it for testing purposes only, and the adult felt fine.

The width can be adjusted out to 13.5" internally at the upper thighs, then tapering to a width of 13.25" closer to the knee - the lap belt guides angle in a bit. The red lap belt guides should not be so narrow they touch the occupant.

I'd give this 5 stars for ingenuity and practicality, but there are a couple of issues:

1. The lap belt guides move in too easily. Pulling them out requires using a couple of tabs, but pushing them in requires virtually no effort. It's very easy to push in the lap belt guides. I think the intent was to make it easier for the child to adjust the lap belt guides' width, but it would've been better to make the child adjust the width to lock in the position before placing it on the car's backseat. If there is some quick, jerky movements while riding, the booster seat may shift. Also, another person sitting next to a mifold user can accidentally push in the lap belt guide. To be fair, I haven't had the lap belt guides get moved yet while in the car, but I can foresee how this may be a problem when things get bumped at a bad time.

2. The shoulder belt guide/clip is difficult to open initially. I can open it since I'm an adult who had some practice, but younger kids will need help, along with adults who may not be familiar with the mifold, like the driver for a class field trip. I don't know if the shoulder belt guide mechanism has to lock for the mifold to work properly. Other booster seats have shoulder belt guides that let the user slide in the vehicle's shoulder belt and leave at that, though having it lock does prevent the vehicle's shoulder belt from sliding out.

Other quirks that don't affect the star rating:
- The shoulder belt guide/clip is made of plastic. It seems durable, and I hope it doesn't break or get loosened after repeated use.
- There are lots of sewn-on tags and labels. Since (I assume) these are regulatory requirements, there's nothing mifold can do about them, considering the lack of available space for such items due to the compact size of the mifold.
- The manual can be stored in a slot incorporated into the mifold, but it's a little difficult to get the manual in and out - be sure to leave the manual sticking out a bit so it can be removed easier.

It's obvious a lot of thought went into designing this. With the mifold, there's no excuse for not using a booster seat, even when traveling. Besides the mechanisms of the guides, I love this product. I hope this gains more popularity so the difficulty and unfamiliarity of using the mifold disappears. Or, maybe the next generation of mifold will improve it. I don't know if this can replace traditional booster seats for some but for traveling and carpools, this is practically a must-have safety item without compromising convenience. In the meantime, I continue to wait for the mifold I ordered via crowdfunding while being grateful for the opportunity to receive one for review - many thanks to Jon Sumroy, the mifold team and Amazon's Vine program.

Review:
Our parked car was hit, so we had to replace my 6yr old's booster. I had been wanting to put him back in a five point harness. He was fine weight wise, but he's such a tall kid his torso height was too much for any other seat.

I was told that the Nautilus allowed for a torso height of 21" so I took a chance and ordered it. I figured if he was too tall for the five point we'd just put it in booster mode.

I was so happy when he tried it out, he's still got just a bit of room to go and might be able to stay in the five point until he's 7yr. He can buckle and unbuckle himself. He's even able to loosen the belts for when he wears a heavy winter coat, then tighten it back up. If you have an escape artist this might be a problem.

The seat is rather heavy, but that I like. I figure it will help it stay in place better. The head wrap is very soft for my son, but hard and feels strong from the outside of it. I feel confident that it will protect his head very well from the back and sides. My son says the seat is very comfortable and we both love the drink holder built into the arm.

I was so please I replaced a perfectly good convertible seat my 3yr old had been using to put him in a Nautilus too. He loves the little cubby holes in the arms. They are perfect for stashing small toys.

I found the LATCH instillation goes much smoother with the Nautilus then with our old seats. Removing it is a lot easier too. Our old seats had LATCH belts that were next to impossible to loosen.

We have not tried it as a booster yet, so I cant comment on that aspect. But from the little assembly I had to do, I think they will be great in that function as well.

They are wider then I had expected, and we did lose some room in the back seat so if you need to three in the back seat these might cause a problem.

Over all I'm VERY please with these seats. All the other Mom's now think I'm a car seat Nazi for putting my six year old back in a five point. But the piece of mind I have is worth a little teasing. ;O)
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster, convertible
Weight Range of Child: fine weight wise
Harness Type: five point harness
Material: head wrap is very soft, hard and feels strong from the outside
Installation Type: LATCH instillation
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should be suitable for use as both a booster and a convertible seat. It should accommodate the child's weight appropriately. The seat should feature a five-point harness for security. The materials should include a very soft head wrap while feeling strong and durable on the exterior. The seat should be compatible with LATCH installation.

Review: We bought this to enable us to transfer our 1 1/2 old out of the infant carrier seat and keep her rear facing. We have been using it since July and have very few complaints. It is so easy to adjust the shoulder harness height, it just slides up and down. On the con side, be prepared to adjust it often it seems that the straps often slide down after you remove your child. We love the cranks on the side for adjusting the tightness of the lap belt, very easy to use. Be aware that, unlike many car seats, this seat tightens from the lap so you need to tighten it BEFORE you fasten the chest harness. (I took the seat for a car seat installation check and even the technician had to be reminded of this).  I can't speak for our daughter but she appears comfy in it. She just turned 2 and is still happily rear facing. Installation was as easy as any other seat. My only wish is that there was an actual level on the side of the seat like graco seats have instead of a sticker saying "this line must be level with the ground" ugh! So hard to decide by eyeballing it.

Review:
I recently traveled by myself with a newborn and a toddler with a layover, and this product made my life so much easier! My toddler HATES strollers and always tries to escape. But she LOVED riding in her car seat as it was strapped to my roller. I have a Britax Marathon and it fit nicely with my carry-on. It was very stable and secure! It made going through security much easier than having to take down a stroller. Because of this strap, it made one less bulky item "aka: stroller" to keep track of.

This, coupled with my Baby Bjourn for my infant, made travel less stressful. Even several flight attendants commented on how it's about time someone came up with a product like this.

NOTE: As a reviewer commented before, it fits secure if your roller is packed full, but not too full. I had to over-pack my roller on the way back and that made the car seat lean to one side a bit. That made it harder to pull, and get on and off at security, but it was still very stable.

Review:
I was really on the fence when we needed to get a larger carseat for our 3.5 yr old daughter. It was between this and the Britax Frontier 85. We opted for the Graco and now I wish we spent the extra dollars for the Britax. We always used Britax carseats (Marathon and Roundabout)but when the roundabout got too small we bgt the Graco. Overall I think the Graco is safe which is really the most important thing, but it's the small things that are annoying. First, the straps have a tendency to twist; drives me nuts. Second, the installation is a pain. The Graco seat only has one belt to pull up on and it feels next to impossible to get it tight enough. I always ask my husband to tighten it further so it doesn't wobble around. I also really like the Britax velcro tabs on the side that hold the belts away from the seat so my daughter can get in without sitting on the belts. Graco does not have this feature.
The cup holder is nice as are the little "cubbies", but if I had the chance to do it over again, I would buy the Britax.

Review: Two of my three kids recently moved up into booster seats. We were traveling and needed to rent car seats while we were traveling. Being able to take two of these boosters on our trip saved us so much money! My six and four year old also found them comfortable, and they were pliable enough that we were able to put an adult in between them in the back seat. I definitely recommend reading the directions and figuring it out before you need to use it. It's not the most intuitive. We only needed to use the shoulder strap clip on my 4-year-old. It was easiest when he was actually sitting down comfortably, and then I could pull the shoulder strap to where it fit for him. He did complain a little bit that the clip was not very comfortable on the back of his shoulder. Also, what other reviews say about the white clip around the laugh about portion is absolutely true. I found it easier to avoid putting the seat belt through on the buckle side of the seat belt. On the far side, it definitely made sense because it kept the lap belt in a good position. These were great to fold up and put in their backpacks for carry-on forthe airplane. They did add weight to the backpack, But what we saved in space and cost it was worth it. Definitely recommend this product! We have also used it when we have friends come to visit, or pick a friend up to go on a weekend excursion. It saves so much time and transferring boosters! One last comment and then, I promise I'm done! We have friends that have the cushion travel seat. I have noticed that it does not keep the kids high enough where the shoulder strap doesn't bother them. It also seems like they do not grip on the seat as well as these do. Granted, our friends may not have had access to this product when they purchased theirs, And of course every family has their needs. For us, this was the perfect product! I was very happy with this purchase!

Weight Range of Child: six and four year old
Harness Type: shoulder strap clip
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

Review:
Very easy to assemble. Love the cup holder and stuff compartments in the arm rests. Good padding to allow a comfortable 3 hour drive we often take. The pull strap to adjust the kids straps is easy to tighten. Very grateful for the mess pad that is easy to remove. It sits under the child's body from knees to shoulders. Had to many frustrating times cleaning my old car seat that has a cover that does not come off. Very excited that it assembles for different ages ending as a booster seat. Instructions are easy to understand. Very high quality car seat. Love that it reclines for when they fall asleep.

Cons are: The seat belt that clasps at the groin is hard to clasp. But that is usual for most car seats. This one just seems to be at a weird angle.
The shoulder pads are flat and one of them has a iron on sticker. Which will not be comfortable for my kids cheek to lay on when they fall asleep. I could switch them to the opposite side and that would fix the problem.

Review:
We bought this seat 8 months ago for our son's first birthday. We have it rear facing and have used it in both a Hyundai Elantra and a Honda Odyssey. Obviously it fits better in the Odyssey, but we had no problems with the Elantra. It was a little bit difficult to install the first time we used it, but we had to switch it back and forth between cars several times before we got the back-up seat for my husband's car and once you know what you're doing, it's super easy.

Little Guy is 25 pounds and 31" and it very comfy rear facing. I noticed that he does tend to get a little sweaty on long rides in the car, but we do not have the same problem in the van, which has A/C vents in the back. He sleeps well in it when appropriate (and sometimes when I wish he would've waited the three minutes until we got home) and his head is more likely to drop to the side onto the headrest than to drop forward.

This was affordable and has been easy to use and comfy for the Little Guy. I would definitely recommend it to a friend and buy it again if need be.

**Update** The cover was SO EASY to remove and wash and just as easy to put back on. Such a blessing after little guy squeezed an entire yogurt tube in his lap on a trip.

Review:
Just bought my second pair of these carseats. I had bought some a little over a year ago after someone had backed into my car with my old convertible ones. I had done research and purchased these ones for my daughter (now 6 but the small for her age) and my son (now 7).
Yesterday while visiting my in laws in LA they hit a COW on the interstate (at night going 70) and spun off into a power pole. Aside from a bruise on my son's arm where he hit it on the car door, they are both completely unharmed!! The police, emts and fire fighters all were all impressed and attributed everyone being unhurt to my father in laws phenomial driving in the situation and these carseats. Which the officers/fire fighters inspected prior to my sister in law picking them up and said they seemed to be completely undamaged, although they recommended replacing them.(honestly, i had already ordered the second pair ;) )
At this point, you could not pay me to put my kids in different booster seats.

Review: I read lots of reviews online before purchasing two of these car seats (one for each car).  I have two kids, one and three years old.  My son the one-year-old just outgrew the graco snugride infant seat.  My daughter was still using her Britax Marathons that we bought when she outgrew the graco.  We moved my son into the Britax seats, which are designed for babies up to 65 pounds.  First we tried the Graco turbo booster but that was too big and did not seem safe for my daughter, who just turned three and is only 29 pounds.  Then I found this seat, the Graco Nautilus, and I love it!  My daughter had wanted a girly print but once she tried her big girl seat with cup holders, she loved it and didn't care what color it was!  I offered to make her a girly pink cotton cover for it but she really doesn't care anymore what color it is.  We have been using the seats for a couple months now and are very happy with them.  They were also much more affordable than the Britax and seem just as sturdy and safe and well-fitting - a very good value that will be useful for many years.  We have old cars - a 10-year-old subaru forester and a 10-year-old VW Jetta - both without Latch - and it was easy to safely anchor in both cars using the seatbelt systems, and it fit well in both back seats.  It was easy to set up and install.

Review: Have been using this booster with my 3-year old for about a month as his younger sister needed his previous convertible (also a Graco); love the booster.  Easy to use, my son can climb in and out of the seat very easily.  Added bonus - the cup holders are in perfect position for him (location in previous seat was awkward and the cups always ended up on the floor, rolling under the front seat).  At his age on longer car trips during which he naps, I do miss the 5-point harness that kept him in a better position (he doesn't much care for the head pillow that came with the booster), but, once seated, if you pull the shoulder strap all the way out so that it retracts and "locks" it helps give him some additional support (and keeps him from wiggling side to side).  We are very pleased with this seat overall, have already been asked about it by many of our friends, and highly recommend it.

Review:
The cart itself looks and feel sturdy - but there are other more practical options that are just as well made and more well priced. The key - and only - selling point for this cart is that it will fit down a narrow airplane aisle. While I have never needed to use it on an airplane, I am certain this claim is factually true. However, one needs to worry more about the child car seat than the actual cart, as the average child car seat is wider than the cart itself...
Be advised that the cart uses rollerblade wheels. Anyone who has ever roller bladed *knows* that such wheels are intended for FLAT, SMOOTH surfaces. Airports provide plenty of such surfaces, but it is getting to the airport where this cart is useless. One needs to walk super slow and needs to be ultra careful to avoid every bump, crack, twig, etc to not send the cart and any cargo strapped to it flipping over to its side. In my case, it's only been an empty child car seat that has been sent tumbling over. No one got hurt, but it was an embarrassing inconvenience as you have to stop and readjust and clean everything before resuming your trip at a slow plodding pace.
I have since (quickly) replaced this crappy britax with a less expensive luggage cart from PFC. The luggage cart has larger wheels and a wider base, about as wide as the child car seat at its widest point. This makes for a much more stable and reliable transport option, one where I can walk at a much more natural pace.
Final note: It is much easier to secure the child car seat to the pfc luggage cart than it is to the britax. This is due to the fact that the pfc is wider and it is easier for the security latches to reach the brackets by the cart's wheels. The britax is noticably narrower and i am literally stretching the safety bands on the security latches to secure the seat to the cart.

Review: Automobiles are not built to protect small passengers in a crash - even small adults!  If you want to increase the odds your child will survive a collision, I recommend keeping him or her in a booster seat as long as you are able to do so.  The Britax Frontier 85 is more than just a booster - it is a booster with a top tether which significantly increases the safety of the seat.  A 5-point harness is safer than the seat belt, and that's how my petite 9-year-old rides.  The law says 8 or 80 but I feel that law should be more stringent.  I plan to keep my daughter in the harness until she reaches 85 pounds and the belt-positioning booster until she is 12 or older.  I have taught her that safety is more important than "image" - I don't care that all of her friends are allowed to ride in cars with no booster of any kind.  The vehicle's seats and belts are NOT designed to protect your small riders. I'll say it again - a Britax Frontier 85 is well engineered to increase small riders' odds of survival in a collision.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster seat, belt-positioning booster
Weight Range of Child: 85 pounds
Harness Type: 5-point harness
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The child car seat should accommodate children up to 85 pounds.

Review:
Up until now, I've had Evenflo car seats for my toddler because of their Consumer Reports rating, however, my husband and I were never really thrilled with their ease of use. She's about to outgrow the 40 lb. weight limit on them, however, and it was time to find a car seat / booster that would grow with her until she was big enough to sit in the car by herself. This car seat was perfect for that!

I researched for a while before selecting this car seat. I purchased one to try it out before purchasing another 2 so that we'll ultimately have 3. (One for each of our cars, plus one for our babysitter's car.) I'm thrilled with the seat and am now purchasing the other two!

The things I like:
1. The car seat just feels and looks well made. The fabric is nice, the arms are built well, the chair is a good size, but also fits perfectly well in our car. Cup holder is built in and sturdy, not flimsly like the other's I've had.

2. Easy to size with lots of slots for the internal harness and lots of positions for the headrest. The adjustment to tighten or loosen the harness is also very easy to get to and adjust.

3. Great headrest. I love the "wings" on the headrest...gives my toddler something to rest her head on when she falls asleep.

4. The internal harness buckles are very well made; buckle and release very smoothly. I also like the padding for the upper part of the harness (never had these on my other carseats.)

5. Easy to install in car. It was also very easy to tighten...it fit well on the seat and tightened up very easily. Car seat didn't even budge once I had it tightened.

All in all I'm more than pleased with this purchase. Amazing price (plus free Amazon shipping) for what you're getting!!
