Review:
We recently switched my 8 month old to this seat from his infant bucket seat.

Pros:
Very easy to install in our 2016 Honda Fit using the premium push-on Latch connectors. It fits behind the passenger seat with room to spare without the front seat being pushed all the way forward. (We did recline the back of the backseat to help with fit.) We took it to the car seat inspection at the local fire station and they said the install looked great.

We like the "headwings" for side impact protection and the somewhat deeper sides of the seat, especially since he's outboard in a smaller car. It makes him seem more protected. It seems like a sturdy seat. Some people may not like the deeper sides because you have to lift the child over, but it works for us.

It must be comfortable, because my son falls right to sleep! We did take out the extra head pillow and infant insert because they made him fussy (probably felt too restrictive) and according to the manual, they were not required at his size. He seems to enjoy the seat just fine without them!

The no rethread harness that adjusts with the headrest is very nice and easy to use.

Our son is tall but thin, and we like that this seat should be able to accommodate him rear facing for several years.

Cons:
The main con we have seen is that the harness can be difficult to tighten when putting the child in. I use a trick I saw online to pull the harness down from the back and then tighten. I also try to avoid loosening the harness when taking him out. Doing this, I've consistently been able to get it properly tight (passes the pinch test).

Overall, we really like this seat. It's got some of the more premium features without the premium price. If it wasn't for the extra effort needed to tighten the harness properly, I would give it 5 stars.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Weight Range of Child: 8 month old
Installation Type: Latch
Harness Type: no rethread harness that adjusts with the headrest
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be rear facing to accommodate an 8-month-old child. It should be installable using the Latch system. The harness should adjust automatically with the headrest, eliminating the need for manual rethreading.

Review: I was traveling alone with my 14 month old, needed to take her Graco SmartSeat All-in-One Car Seat (which is super heavy) and had no idea how I could manage it all.  This contraption was amazing!  I checked my roller suitcase, used a back back as a carry on, and wheeled my daughter through the airport and to the terminal with ease.  Security just used the wand on the seat and checked it out without taking it apart (which wouldn't have been that big of a deal).  I plopped her back in easily and that was that.  The car seat with the travel cart still attached went under the plane and it was waiting for me when we got off.  My only issue was that the car seat cover got a couple of grease marks on it (came out in the wash), so next time I'll bring a case or large trash bag to protect it.  This is such a great product!

Review: I love this car seat! We got it to replace one that was damaged in an accident and insurance paid for it, otherwise I would've had to go with a much cheaper one. Anyway, my 4 year old son loves it- says it is comfy, and he loves the cubby holes for putting toys in. Our last car seat had a removable cup holder that attached to the side, so I love that this one is built into the arm. The colors (green and grey) are very nice looking, and the material is soft and cushy. It is fairly easy to install, although I would like to see better LATCH attachments - for this much money you would think they would use ones more like the First Years one that we replaced. The one handed harness adjustment is awesome- just push the button and pull it up. Also very easy to tighten/loosen straps from the front. The sides allow my son to sleep in the car without his neck being in an awkward position or his head falling forward. The seat does recline with a one handed button on the front, but I believe you are supposed to take it out and adjust the recline then reinstall. The only downside to this that I have had to work on is the buckle on the chest clip, as many other people have said. When I first got it, it was absolutely impossible to unbuckle the chest clip with one hand. It is a little easier now, but still a very difficult buckle. The upside to this is that my son isn't able to unbuckle himself. Overall I highly recommend this seat to anyone!

Review:
I was excited with the idea of a 3 in 1 car seat and that it reclyned. However, the reclyner is extremely useless. It makes no difference what so ever. In fact, I had to even put a pillow under my daughter's butt because she sinks in (a child won't be able to sit up straight at all). As a result of the sinking in, her belly was getting a bit compressed I guess and every time she sat on this seat, she was vomitting withing 10-20 minutes into our drive. This was happening from when she was 8 months until 2 years. It got better when I began putting the pillow under her.

Also,she is now 2 1/2 years old and weights 28 lbs. Guess what? She hates the seat even more because the straps are too short and there has been times that i've accidently pinched her skin between her hers. I don't understand why they would advertise this seat as a seat that has a 5 point harness up to 65 lbs.

Finally, whenever she fell asleep, she had no head support on the sides, so I had to put a stuffed animal or small pillow to keep her head comfortably.

One good thing about it is that it's very durable and easy to clean. I think I've cleaned this seat more than anyone in the world (due to all her vomitting)

Review:
Since 2001 I've been hooked on Britax car seats. The quality and ease of use of their seats puts them above their competition. When I was presented with the opportunity to review the Britax Pavilion 70-G3 I jumped at the chance to see how it compared to the Britax Marathon 70-G3.

The first thing I noticed when I pulled this seat out of the box was it's weight. This seat isn't one that you're going to want to transfer from one car to the next on a regular basis and I certainly wouldn't want to have to lug this seat through an airport.

My initial impression of the seat is that it was the overprotective parent's dream come true. I'm all for a super safe car seat for my child but this seat almost feels like overkill. The wings that protect the child's head in the event of an accident also keep the child from being able to turn his or her head and look out the window or at a passenger riding next to them. It also makes loading a child into this seat in the rear facing position a bit difficult. My nineteen month old who is used to riding in a Marathon 70-G3 and a Roundabout 55 Classic is not thrilled with the seat. In the past I have not been a fan of the HUGS that are on the harness for the Marathon seats, and I expected the new Safe Cell HUGS to be even more of a pain with regards to loading and unloading my child but they're actually a great improvement on the old HUGS feature.

The harness for this seat deserves some attention in this review. For about five months I put off using and reviewing this seat because I had difficulty loosening the harness when I first took it out of the box. I've handled a lot of car seats in the eleven and a half years that I've had children and this was the first seat where I had a lot of difficulty loosening the harness enough to get my child in the seat. I was so irritated by the seat that I put it out and my garage for several months and figured one day when I had more time I'd play with the seat a little more. When I finally got back to the seat I figured out what I was doing wrong. I always pull on the harness at the shoulder/chest clip area to loosen the harness (the hang tag instructions for this seat suggest pulling on the chest clip). Because the HUGS are tethered to the car seat shell doing this means the harness can't be pulled from the top. I found that if you pull the harness from the lap area the straps loosen with no problem. So I absolutely understand the frustration that many other parents have had with the harness.

Tightening the harness is simple. Just pull the center strap on the front of the seat and it makes a loud click when the harness is within an acceptable range of tightness. I think it's a great feature that will help those parents who tend to leave the harness too loose learn how to properly secure their child.

Harness height adjustment on this seat is a snap compared to the seats where you need to rethread the harness. You simply have to squeeze and pull (or push) to adjust the height of the harness straps. The ease of use for this function is on par with the simple adjustment of the back on a Graco TurboBooster.

Just like the Marathon 70-G3 the versa tether on the Pavillion is energy absorbing and works to reduce forward movement and rotation in a crash. The seat also has the EZ-Buckle System which keeps the harness buckle in a forward position and keeps your child from sitting on the buckle. I can tell you that this feature is quite nice. I had been using a Roundabout 55 Classic with our nineteen month old and I can't tell you how often she ended up sitting on the buckle and freaking out while I try to pull it out from under her. The new design really works nicely to keep the buckle out of the way when loading the baby into the seat. The design reminds me of the harness buckle on our B-Agile stroller.

Installation of this seat was a snap. I installed it both rear and forward facing in my Toyota Sienna and it was easily and securely installed in both positions. The seat is on the larger side so it is possible that this seat may not fit well in smaller cars when used in the rear facing position, but I think it's a bit more compact than the Marathon 70-G3 and Roundabout 55 Classic. Using this seat rear facing I have noticed that my toddler has less leg room with the Pavillion than she has with both the Marathon 70-G3 and the Roundabout 55 Classic.

Overall, this is a great quality seat that will keep your little one safe, comfortable and secure for many years. If you can deal with the ease of use difficulties with loosening the harness and your child doesn't mind having his or her view obstructed by the wings around the head then this seat is a very safe option with will offer optimal protection for your child. In the eleven and a half years that I've been using Britax seats, I have found each of them to be worth the price. While the Pavillion is a good seat, I prefer the Marathon 70-G3 for ease of use.

Review:
This carseat is terrible. I had a different car seat on my registry and someone purchased me this seat instead, which was the worst decision anyone has ever made. First off, it's VERY difficult to install. The latch strap is impossible to tighten and the shape of the sides makes it very difficult to put your weight into the seat to tighten it. The belt or latch strap threads under the seat, and the seams on the fabric there are so sharp they have actually cut my hand trying to thread the belt. The positioning of the cupholders on the sides means that the seatbelt install pulls up that side of the carseat making it crooked.

Once (if) you manage to get the thing installed correctly, it doesn't get any better. The pieces at the top used to adjust the back height RATTLE constantly while driving. It's so aggravating. We had to keep a towel up there to stop the constant noise. Not only that, but they're SHARP! If you ever turn around to pat your kid's hair or hand them something, watch out for those things. They've left a massive scratch up my arm from getting too close.

Finally, the straps on the seat are always getting twisted. As if it's not difficult enough to get your toddler in and out of the the carseat, the openings in the clips are just large enough that the straps are always twisting around.

I would highly recommend against this seat. I have the Graco 4Ever, and it's significantly better. Better yet is the Britax Boulevard, the ClickTight installation is a game changer. If you STILL want this seat - please come take mine before I have the satisfaction of burning it or throwing it off a cliff.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: latch strap is impossible to tighten; belt or latch strap threads under the seat; seatbelt install pulls up that side of the carseat making it crooked
Harness Type: straps on the seat are always getting twisted; openings in the clips are just large enough that the straps are always twisting around
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat needs to be easy to tighten securely without becoming crooked during installation. The straps need to stay untwisted and the clips should prevent the straps from twisting.

Review: I was very hesitant to buy this car seat based on the numerous reviews that said it was a nightmare to install. It took us about 1/2 hour to 45 minutes to figure out how to correctly secure it in my husband's 2000 Toyota 4 Runner.  However, after we figured out the correct way (the belt long path) it probably takes about 5 minutes to install it in his car as well.  This seat is incredibly secure in both cars, using both the lap belt and latch methods.  My 2 1/2 year old son has had no complaints regarding the comfort of the seat, and I'm planning on buying one for our younger daughter when she outgrows her current car seat.

Review:
I chose this model for the cup holders and the adjustable arm rests. My son loves having the cup holders and the fact that they can be pushed in. The seat overall is easy to use and my son figured out how to buckle his seat belt on his own right away.

The fabric is not the best quality. After using for only a week, there are some threads coming out so I'm not sure how long it will hold up, which is disappointing. The plastic part of the seat does seem durable though, which is important. I did expect the arm rests to be more easily adjustable. I have them set at an ideal height now but they lock in tight and I'm not sure how easily I will be able to more them later on. We shall see. And there's only two height settings so there really isn't that much of an adjustment to be made anyway but for a kid, I guess it's sufficient.

Overall, I'm satisfied with the seat, especially for the price, which is quite reasonable.

Review:
As mentioned, I am a happy father of 5 beautiful children ranging from 13 years old to a new born. We have used, abused and relied upon mountains of, and thousands of dollars worth of different "Kid Gear" throughout the years. This is my second Britax car seat now.

This item is a good one to invest in. It isn't the cheapest, but as a former police officer, I will tell you, don't cut corners on getting a safe car seat for your child even though they are overpriced. And make sure it is anchored properly! No car seat is safe if it is not anchored the right way. Pull the belt out all the way and crank that dang thing in there tight. Your kid is worth more than the leather on your back seat.

This seat is bulky but rated well for impact. It has good anchoring options and instructions too. The only criticism I have besides the cost (I'm sure the mark up on car seats is huge!), is the belt clips under the cushioning are too tight. If you anchor the seat in tight, there is no way those plastic clips will snap in place. This could lead a consumer to think those weak clips will hold the seat to the actual seat belt. Not true; even if they improve those clips. And on a shoulder belt, those clips are worthless. Add clearance to the clips and that would be great, or just get rid of them.

And by the way, this seat is designed so you don't have to have your wife or another one of this kids with tiny hands to thread the belt through the seat. My recommendation is, don't buy this seat from Target or Walmart, it is not the same seat! Pay the shipping and get this exact model. Priced right for the quality in comparison to the others. Good job Britax

It takes some getting used to but after the first week you'll appreciate the whole click tight system. I feel like the click tight system is way sturdier then the whole latch system, after clicking it in this thing seriously doesn't move. No more messing about trying to pull the side latches as tight as possible, a simple feed through of the belt and push the seat down till the click tight button is level and voila all set to go. Be warned though this car seat is built like a tank so be prepared for how much it weighs, I personally don't have a problem moving this thing back in forth between cars but some people will. All in all an excellent car seat you'll feel comfortable sticking your child in.

Review:
I just got this car seat today and, so far, I am very satisfied with the product. I was a little concerned about the installation, because I had read so many reviews stating how hard it was to install and listing it as a con. But, I must say, that after watching a video on Youtube a couple of times on how to do the "long belt path", it was quite a breeze to install in my 08 Toyota Camry. In fact, I had to uninstall it once because the harness wasn't quite right, and re-install it (without help!). And it took me less than five minutes both times. The seat is solid! It hardly moves half an inch when I try to shake it. The seat belt barely made it to the latch, that's true. But, once clipped, that seat wasn't going anywhere. I strongly suggest watching a couple of informative videos on how to use the seat. They helped me a great deal.

The ONLY thing that was kind of tough was moving the crotch harness from the first slot to the middle one (I also tried the third). I had to use a screwdriver to push it through because it just wouldn't budge. But other than that, I have no complaints as far as set up, installation and, of course, quality. It is pretty heavy, so even though it is FAA approved, I would buy a lighter seat to tote around the airport.

My three year old son also gave it two thumbs up. Loved it! Especially the cup holders.

Review:
I've had this carseat for 3 months now. I replaced a Safety 1st Alpha Omega elite car seat with this one, and I'm so glad I did.

Pros:

Strap adjustment: So easy. Simply slide the strap loop end off the hook, pull through the back of the seat, stick it through the shoulder heighth you want, and then slide it back on the hook thing. No complicated re-threading, and yet it's still a very secure connection. Also very easy to tighten and loosen. In fact, everytime I put my child in the carseat, I loosen the shoulder straps, buckle him in, and then tighten the straps around his shoulders. It only takes a second, and I'm sure of a secure fit every single time.

Comfort: This seat sits high. If your car has low ceilings, maybe that would be a nuisance getting him in, but I'm putting my kiddo in the back of an extended cab 4door pickup which is very roomy. The seat sitting so high off the bench makes it very easy for my son to see out the window. He likes that. The padding is comfortable and the seat is wide. My toddler is average height & weight (50th percentile). The seat also is angled back a little more than the Safety 1st one we had. So if my son falls asleep, he is a little more comfortable.

Safety: This carseat feels sturdy. The wings on either side of my toddlers head give me piece of mind about side impact. The child sits more deeply in this seat than our old one, so I feel like he's better protected.

Practicalilty: This seat is easy to wipe down with a damp cloth. The fabric doesn't hold crumbs.

Cons:

Size: This seat is huge. It DOES fit in my Nissan Sentra, but it's huge. I have 2 of these in the back of my nissan and you cannot use the 3rd seatbelt. You also cannot put them right next to each other in the Nissan, however you CAN put them next to each other in roomy cab of the pickup and I've put them next to each other in the back of a Suburban and they fit. Also, if you want to use it rear-facing in a small car, you'll have to either use the center seatbelt or move the front seat really far foward to fit it on a side seatbelt.

Summary: If you have a larger vehicle, you can't go wrong with this seat. Comfortable, easy to adjust, safe, and nice looking. If you have a tiny car, you won't want to try to fit 2 of these in there. And rear facing is limited where it will fit in a small car.

Review: I saw a few people complaining and I felt I needed to step in.  I bought this when it was on Kickstarter. My son had recently moved to a booster and I was pretty tired of lugging a car seat or booster when traveling... so when I saw Mifold I was really intrigued. Did my research.. decided to back it and get one as soon as it was available. It's been a game changer. No more lugging a chair around... Mifold folds up and fits in my purse.  People complain that it's complicated. It's really not. Read the instructions.. try it out a few times.. get the hang of it. It's actually really easy. My son has been securing himself for the time he was using it. Now I keep it around for young guests to my car and my son still likes to help them in.  If an 8 and 7 year old can do it.. you can too.  There was one time that I had trouble with getting my nephew out.. but upon looking at it, realized that he pushed the side latches in which locked the seat belt into place. A simple unlock maneuver under his bum and told him to not push in the sides... and we were great for the rest of his visit.  To sum up.. I love it. My son loves it.  Read the instructions.. it's not that hard once you try it a couple times.

Review:
With our daughter outgrowing her infant car seat, we researched and decided on the Britax Boulevard 70 (2012), which we purchased at a local store and put into our SUV, which we drive more often. When it came time to get the second car seat, we purchased this 70-G3 for my car, only because the 2012s were no longer available at as good a price. This one is in my 2-door sports coupe and it still fits rear-facing and in the center seat. I worried it might not fit there, or that it might be hard to see over when looking in the rearview mirror, but all was for naught. It fits great, and it doesn't obstruct my view at all.

Between the two versions we have, the main difference that I've noticed is that this 70-G3's straps don't lengthen as much as the older version, meaning we have to work a little harder to get our daughter's arms through when buckling her in. This appears to be a safety feature ("Versa" Tether related). Otherwise, it's a great seat so far. She sweats quite a bit in it sometimes (living in AZ), but car seats are not breathable anyway, so I imagine this would happen in any car seat, especially when rear-facing. The head support is plush and this has the true side impact protection, as well.

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be rear-facing. The straps should not lengthen excessively.

Review:
We got a bunch of Mifolds for ourselves and our family and I think that their star rating can depend on the use case.

As a travel carseat, it gets 5 stars, easily. This thing is small, it's light, it's safe, and it can save you a fortune. If you rent just one car seat from a rental agency for a week, you'll have paid for it. Additionally, it takes up almost no space in your luggage. On that basis alone, it's worth 5 stars.

As a daily carseat, I think it isn't as strong of a use case. It can be difficult to get set up if you're constantly moving it because of the mechanism that is used to pull the shoulder belt down to a child's height. Additionally, my kids have complained some about the comfort (or lack thereof) with the plastic piece that brings the shoulder belt down. The side adjusters don't lock into any position either, which also presents a bit of a challenge at times as they slide in and out with normal use.

Seat Type: travel carseat, daily carseat
Material: plastic
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The car seat is made of plastic.

Review:
Ok, so go read the other critical reviews.

This was very attractive due to the price point. I would describe this as an OK budget option, but if you can, spring for a better quality car seat. This is the thing that will protect your child in the event of a collision, so if you can save up for a better seat, please do.

Our 11-month-old was very unhappy getting fitted in this, he hated the position, and as others have pointed out it will be hard for him to sleep in here comfortably (which is also dangerous if his head is not positioned properly).

As others pointed out, this thing feels flimsy. There are exposed parts in the back that rattle around a lot, regardless of whether there's a kid in it. It's mostly the parts that interface to raise and lower the back, so you might be able to wrap some electrical tape around the metal pieces to dampen the sound, but that seems like a silly solution to a sub-par design.

The LATCH straps. Where to start? Why did they even bother? Chicco has a latch strap with nice plastic-coated attachment points that resemble a seatbelt clipping in. This thing just has metal hooks on the end with a flimsy little retainer piece. Then you have to awkwardly try to pull it like a seatbelt to get it tight enough. All of my body weight and all of my strength trying to tighten the strap was futile, because ultimately you're pulling a strap perpendicular to the direction that you need to tighten it.

I tightened this as much as I could and still had a good 6" of play on the front of the seat -- way more than is safe. It would have been far better to drop the LATCH system entirely and require the much more complicated (read: likely to be done incorrectly) seat belt installation.

Back in the box this went. I will give credit where it's due though - the packaging was great. Literally just a car seat in a box. No foam, no plastic wrap, no waste.
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: LATCH straps, metal hooks, flimsy little retainer piece, pulling a strap perpendicular to the direction that you need to tighten it, had a good 6" of play on the front of the seat, seat belt installation
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat needs to be easy to install using LATCH straps with secure metal hooks. It is acceptable if the installation involves a small retainer piece. It is acceptable if tightening requires pulling a strap in a different direction. It is acceptable if there is some movement at the front of the seat after installation. The car seat also needs to be installable using the vehicle's seat belt.

Review: Other reviewers have complained about the lower anchor buckle (goes between the child's legs). It is a problem at times and I often have to "dig" under my 4.5 year old twin grand daughter's little bottoms to find the anchor.  I was also unpleasantly surprised that it comes in so many pieces. It took "grandma" and me "grandpa" a long time to do seat number one, but much less for seat number two. Also make no attempt to pick up more than one seat in a small compact car as the boxes are HUGE.  However, every other aspect of this seat, including the VERY reasonable price is 5 star. The girls sit more upright, have their own little drink holders, and plenty of padding. Front visibility is also greatly improved over their previous seats, also Gracos. This seat will be converted to the next level, saving me the cost of a "booster" seat when they get older and heavier.

Review:
I purchased this seat after it was recommended by a friend. It is a little hard to buckle and unbuckle. The metal buckles that go into the harness portion have to be at just the right angle to click in. Then the whole middle portion has to be at the right angle to unbuckle it. The top plastic buckle is difficult to unclip as well.

The metal buckles slide all the way down between the back of the seat and the arm rest so when you are trying to buckle the child in you have to reach down pretty far to get the buckle and slide it back up.

It is good as far as the size of my child. I needed something for my child who is 5, but is very light so we still wanted the five point harness. For the price it worked out ok. If I had more money, I probably would have returned it and tried for a seat that was a little more user-friendly.

Review:
We were recently in a car accident (Everyone is fine) with the Chicco keyfit. I was relieved with the protection it provided for my son that when it came to replace it I just wanted to but the same one. My son is 14 months and was nearing the size restrictions to use the keyfit so we opted for this nextfit. Let's just say you get use to a product. We had to use a Graco snugride and an evenflo tritan as we waited for it to ship, neither one came close. The next fit is extremely user friendly (even for grandparents) and includes little extras that other car seats don't have for baby's comfort that I found out are a must . Most notably the strap covers that rest on baby's shoulder to prevent rubbing and irritating their neck as you tighten and loosen straps.
Side note - the other named car seats were difficult to install. The new car seat could not come fast enough.

Compact enough that with 2 chairs in the backseat, an adult can still fit in the remaining space. We like the cupholder, but have yet to try the hidden snack compartment. Review: I wish I could upload pictures of the differences between the seats but my phone isn't letting me for some reason. I have purchased two britax car seats for my babies. My first back in 2015 and one last year. I know that Britax has changed their design slightly and it's enough to make me very concerned and doubtful I'll ever purchase another car seat made by them again. Quality of materials is poorer in my 2017 model than my 2015 model. The plastic isn't as strong, I can squeeze and have actually dented the newer models plastic, the seat base is different containing less of the protective metal than the older model. And I think the assembly was much much sloppier in the newer model car seat than the older one... There are those black round metal fasteners that are completely missing on the head protector. It is secured by tape only. I do not like these changes, seems like alot of changes to save a buck or two... Well you just lost a customer Britax! I'll turn everyone I talk to about car seats away from your seats from now on.

Review:
We have two of these and like them and would highly recommend them. We have had one for 3 years and another for 1 year. However, there are a few things you should know.
(1) Admittedly, not many 6 or 7-year-olds use a 5-point harness. Even the 4-year-olds seem just to use booster seats. But we feel better about our kids being in the 5-point harness. The result is that some of their friends say, "Why are they in a baby seat?"
(2) However, the thing about a harness is that you need to be sure they don't have it too loose and have it squared up across their chest.
(3) Two complaints about our new Nautilus that we have had for a year. The gray plastic button on the LATCH anchor and the gray plastic button on the tether that are supposed to be used to loosen those don't work. You press the button and it does not loosen. You can force it looser but it is tough. Our old one had a metal buckle that worked easier. Also with the new version the harness buckle is too hard for anyone but a very strong adult to buckle. In other words, even the 7 year old cannot buckle himself in at the crotch with this so an adult has to help them.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: 5-point harness; harness buckle is too hard for anyone but a very strong adult to buckle; need to be sure they don't have it too loose and have it squared up across their chest
Installation Type: LATCH anchor; tether
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat must have a 5-point harness for safety. It is acceptable if the harness buckle requires significant adult strength to secure. The harness must be easy to adjust to ensure a snug and properly positioned fit across the child's chest. The car seat must be compatible with LATCH anchors and include a tether for secure installation.

Review:
It's a little heavier than I would like, but hey, it's car seat - none of them are light as a feather. It also takes up quite a bit more room in the car than I imagined - again, I'm sure this is not an issue limited to this particular seat, but to the entire rear-facing car seat universe. Outside of that, I can't complain too much. It is a bit tricky to get the seatbelt harness to unlatch once the lil one is strapped in. It feels like I have to push way too hard on the button to get it to release, and means that I am putting pressure on her when I do so - even with a hand (or a few fingers rather) between the buckle and my baby. I'm working on technique to help get around that issue.

The ease of snapping it in and out of the base is unbelievable though. So easy. ONce you get the base secured that is. That may take a little bit of trail and error depending on your vehicle and whether or not you plan to use a seat cover to protect your car seat's surface from the bottom of the base (which we did on my wife's car, but not on mine). Still, pretty easy to get that taken care of, just means you need to check it from time to time to make sure it has't compressed the car seat cover enough to make the base a tad bit loose (has never gone from green to red - but has show a red line from time to time on the "tightness indicator").

Installing this in my car, however, was a nightmare. MY fault for driving a Mustang. To all you out there with a car that has little to no back seat room, rest assured the seat will fit - although very very tight - and to be honest, probably not meeting ALL of the manufacturer's suggested space between baby seat and back of front seat requirements if you are trying to have an adult riding shotgun comfortably. But installing the base will be a major pain in the a double-s because you have virtually no room to maneuver yourself on top of the damn thing to make sure it is secured tightly (ie - to make that "tightness indicator" go from red to green). As I said, it can be done, just be patient and do some stretching before you try to get it in there because you're going to have to play contortionist to apply the pressure needed to lock everything in place.

But back to the good stuff. It's also very nice that you can rock the seat when you put it down. So if baby gets a little fussy, you can start to gently, or quickly if you wish, rock her. And you can do so with your hand or your foot. Convenient. But that's, again, probably something most if not all baby seats will do. Anyway, yeah it's a bit pricey, but having seat that 1 - looks great, 2 - fits both of our cars, 3 - snaps into the stroller with no adaptor nonsense necessary, and 4 - has strong safety ratings, I'd say it's worth it.

Seat Type: rear-facing
Installation Type: base, snaps
Harness Type: seatbelt harness
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The car seat should include a base for installation.

Review:
We received 3 of these, so I can say with certainty that the problems listed below were not unique to one bad 'lemon'.

While this is lightweight, as advertised, there were several issues.

1.) The headrest is secured by a small piece of Velcro which is insufficient to the job.
2.) The slot for inserting the seat belt for rear-facing installation is too small to fit your hand through, oddly shaped, and has sharp plastic edges which scrape your hand. In order to install the seat belt, the fabric cover of the car seat needs to be un-clipped, and then you can access the slot from both sides of the hold and feed the belt through.
3.) The button/lever for releasing tension on the straps located between their feet is located in a very small hole cut out of the plastic frame. When you pull your thumb or finger out of the hole, it catches on the plastic edge and cuts your thumb. I had a rather gruesome experience with this, and had a friend and a daycare professional test it and they both were shocked at how sharp the plastic edge was and how easily it caught their thumb.
4.) My child who is 7mo old, and average weight/height for her age, does not look comfortable in the seat. It looks like she is sinking into it, and her lower back is not supported, so she is sitting in a C-shape posture.

I was excited by the low price of these car seats, and that they were advertised as light weight and easy to take in and out of vehicles, but they are unsafe for the caregiver, and not a good fit for the child.

Seat Type: Rear-facing
Installation Type: Seat Belt
Material: Plastic
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The car seat can be installed using the vehicle's seat belt.
